title: Definition:Above (Number)
definition:
In the context of numbers, above means greater than.

Note that this applies to:
:the natural numbers â„•
:the integers â„¤
:the rational numbers â„š
:the real numbers â„

but specifically not the complex numbers â„‚ because the complex numbers do not have a usual ordering.

title: Definition:Above (Solid Geometry)
definition:
Let a and b be points in 3-dimensional Euclidean space â„^3.

Let P be an arbitrary plane embedded in S be distinguished and defined as horizontal.

Then:
:a is above b
 if and only if :
:the height of a   P is greater than the height of b   P.

title: Definition:Above (Plane Geometry)
definition:
Let a and b be points in the cartesian plane â„^2.

Then:
:a is above b
 if and only if :
:the y coordinate of a is greater than the y coordinate of b.

title: Definition:Action (Physics)
definition:
Let B_1 and B_2 be bodies in space.

Let B_1 apply a force ğ… on B_2.

The force ğ… is known as the action that B_1 applies to B_2.

title: Definition:Action (Dynamics)
definition:
The action for a given segment from point A to point B on the trajectory of a dynamical system is defined by the line integral:

:âˆ‘_i âˆ«_A^B p_i  d q_i

where:
:q_i are the generalized coordinates
:p_i are the generalized momenta.

title: Definition:Action Applied by System
definition:
The action applied by a system from state 1 to state 2 is defined as the definite integral of the Lagrangian over time from state 1 to state 2:

:S_12 = âˆ«_t_1^t_2â„’ d t
where:
:S_12 is the action from 1 to 2
:t is time
:â„’ is the Lagrangian.

definition:

definition:

title: Definition:Acyclic Graph
definition: An acyclic graph is a graph or digraph with no cycles.

title: Definition:Additive Function (Algebra)
definition:
Let f: S â†’ S be a mapping on an algebraic structure ( S, + ).


Then f is an additive function  if and only if  it preserves the addition operation:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: f (   )x + y = f (   )x + f (   )y

:m âŠ¥ n  f (   )m n = f (   )m + f (   )n

title: Definition:Completely Additive Function
definition:
Let ( R, +, Ã—) be a ring.

Let f: R â†’ R be a mapping on R.


Then f is described as completely additive  if and only if :

:âˆ€ m, n âˆˆ R: f (   )m Ã— n = f (   )m + f (   )n


That is, a completely additive function is one where the value of a product of two numbers equals the sum of the value of each one individually.

definition:
Let ğ’® be an algebra of sets.

Let f: ğ’®â†’R be a function, where R denotes the set of extended real numbers.


Then f is defined to be an additive function  if and only if :

:âˆ€ S, T âˆˆğ’®: S âˆ© T = âˆ… f (   )S âˆª T = f (   )S + f (   )T

definition:
Let x3a3 be a Ïƒ-algebra.

where âŸ¨ E_n âŸ© is any sequence of pairwise disjoint elements of x3a3.


That is, for any countably infinite set of pairwise disjoint elements of x3a3, f of their union equals the sum of f of the individual elements.

title: Definition:Adjacent (Graph Theory)/Vertices
definition:
=== Undirected Graph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be an undirected graph.

Two vertices u, v âˆˆ V of G are adjacent  if and only if  there exists an edge e = { u, v }âˆˆ E of G to which they are both incident.


Otherwise they are non-adjacent.

=== Digraph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Two vertices u, v âˆˆ V of G are adjacent  if and only if  there exists an arc e = ( u, v ) âˆˆ E of G to which they are both incident.


Otherwise they are non-adjacent.

=== Non-Adjacent ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Two vertices u, v âˆˆ V of G are non-adjacent  if and only if  they are not adjacent.

title: Definition:Adjacent (Graph Theory)/Edges
definition:
=== Undirected Graph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be an undirected graph.

Two edges e_1, e_2 âˆˆ E of G adjacent  if and only if  there exists a vertex v âˆˆ V to which they are both incident.


Otherwise they are non-adjacent.

=== Digraph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Two arcs e_1, e_2 âˆˆ E of G adjacent  if and only if  there exists a vertex v âˆˆ V to which they are both incident.


Otherwise they are non-adjacent.

=== Non-Adjacent ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Two edges u, v âˆˆ V of G are non-adjacent  if and only if  they are not adjacent.

title: Definition:Adjacent (Graph Theory)/Faces
definition:
:

Let G = ( V, E ) be a planar graph.

Two faces of G are adjacent  if and only if  they are both incident to the same edge (or edges).

In the above diagram, BCEF and ABF are adjacent, but BCEF and AFG are not adjacent.


Note that faces which are both incident to the same vertex are not considered adjacent unless they are also both incident to the same edge.

title: Definition:Angle/Adjacent
definition:
Two angles are adjacent if they have an intersecting line in common:

:

title: Definition:Polygon/Adjacent/Side to Vertex
definition:
Each vertex of a polygon is formed by the intersection of two sides.

The two sides that form a particular vertex are referred to as the adjacents of that vertex, or described as adjacent to that vertex.

title: Definition:Polygon/Adjacent/Vertex to Side
definition:
Each side of a polygon intersects two other sides, and so is terminated at either endpoint by two vertices.

The two vertices that terminate a particular side are referred to as the adjacents of that side, or described as adjacent to that side.

title: Definition:Adjacent (Graph Theory)/Faces
definition:
:

Let G = ( V, E ) be a planar graph.

Two faces of G are adjacent  if and only if  they are both incident to the same edge (or edges).

In the above diagram, BCEF and ABF are adjacent, but BCEF and AFG are not adjacent.


Note that faces which are both incident to the same vertex are not considered adjacent unless they are also both incident to the same edge.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Adjacent/Faces
definition: Two faces of a polyhedron that meet at the same vertex are adjacent to each other.

title: Definition:Adjoint Linear Transformation
definition:
Let â„‹ and ğ’¦ be Hilbert spaces.

Let â„¬(   )â„‹, ğ’¦ be the set of bounded linear transformations from â„‹ to ğ’¦.

Let A âˆˆâ„¬(   )â„‹, ğ’¦ be a bounded linear transformation.


By Existence and Uniqueness of Adjoint, there exists a unique bounded linear transformation A^* âˆˆâ„¬(   )ğ’¦, â„‹ such that:

:âˆ€ h âˆˆâ„‹, k âˆˆğ’¦: âŸ¨ A (   )h,   âŸ© k_ğ’¦ = âŸ¨ h,   âŸ©A^* (   )k_â„‹

where âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·_â„‹ and âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·_ğ’¦ are inner products on â„‹ and ğ’¦ respectively.


A^* is called the adjoint of A.


The operation of assigning A^* to A may be referred to as adjoining.

title: Definition:Galois Connection/Upper Adjoint
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) and ( T, â‰¾) be ordered sets.

Let g: S â†’ T, d: T â†’ S be mappings.

Let ( g, d ) be a Galois connection.


Then:

:g is called the upper adjoint of the Galois connection.

title: Definition:Galois Connection/Lower Adjoint
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) and ( T, â‰¾) be ordered sets.

Let g: S â†’ T, d: T â†’ S be mappings.

Let ( g, d ) be a Galois connection.


Then:

:d is called the lower adjoint of the Galois connection.

title: Definition:Left Adjoint Functor
definition:
Let ğ‚, ğƒ be locally small categories.

Let F : ğƒâ†’ğ‚ and G : ğ‚â†’ğƒ be functors.

F is a left adjoint functor of G  if and only if  there exists an adjunction ( F, G, Î±).

title: Definition:Right Adjoint Functor
definition:
Let ğ‚, ğƒ be locally small categories.

Let F : ğƒâ†’ğ‚ and G : ğ‚â†’ğƒ be functors.

G is a right adjoint functor of F  if and only if  there exists an adjunction ( F, G, Î±).

title: Definition:Adjoint Equation
definition:
Let ğ’® be a system of n linear first order ODEs:
:ğ²' = ğ€ğ²

The adjoint equation of ğ’® is:
:ğ±' = adj( ğ€) ğ±

where adj( ğ€) is the adjugate matrix of ğ€.

title: Definition:Affine Geometry
definition:
Affine geometry is the study of the geometry of affine spaces.

Hence it is the study of properties and types of geometric figures which are invariant under an affine transformation.

It provides a modern axiomatic approach to the study of configurations of lines, planes and hypersurfaces.

In particular an affine space can be thought of as a finite dimensional vector space with no distinguished origin, and its affine transformations are those that preserve collinearity.

It can be considered as projective geometry which preserves the line at infinity.

title: Definition:Affine Algebraic Set
definition:
Let K be a field.

Let A = K [ X_1, â€¦, X_n ] be the ring of polynomial functions in n variables over K.


Then a subset X âŠ† K^n is an affine algebraic set  if and only if  it is the zero locus of some set T âŠ† A.

title: Definition:Affine Algebraic Variety
definition:
Let k be a field.

Let n â‰¥ 1 be an Integer.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let k be a field.

Let n â‰¥ 1 be an Integer.


A subset X âŠ† k^n is an affine algebraic variety if the following hold:

:(1):    X is an affine algebraic set 

:(2):    X is irreducible   the Zariski topology.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let k be a field.

Let n â‰¥ 1 be an Integer.


An affine algebraic variety in k^n is a subset defined by polynomial equations in x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n.

title: Definition:Affine Scheme
definition: An affine scheme is a ringed space which is isomorphic to the spectrum of a commutative ring with unity.

title: Definition:Affine Frame
definition:
Let â„° be an affine space with difference space V.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„° be an affine space with difference space V.


An affine frame in â„° is an ordered tuple ( p_0, e_1, â€¦, e_n ), where:
:p_0 is an element of â„° called the origin
:( e_1, â€¦, e_n ) is an ordered basis for V.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„° be an affine space with difference space V.


An affine frame may be given by the set of n + 1 points:
:( q_0, â€¦, q_n ) = ( p_0, p_0 + e_1, â€¦, p_0 + e_n )

The frame ( p_0, e_1, â€¦, e_n ) is then recovered by:
:( q_0, q_1 - q_0, â€¦, q_n - q_0 )

Category:Definitions/Affine Geometry

title: Definition:Affine Hull
definition:
Let S be a set.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let S be a set.

The affine hull of S is the smallest affine set containing S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let S be a set.

The affine hull of S is the intersection of all affine sets of which S is a subset.

title: Definition:Age (Time)
definition:
The age of a physical object is defined as the period of time over which it has been in existence.


Category:Definitions/Applied Mathematics

title: Definition:Age (Model Theory)
definition:
Let â„³ be an â„’-structure.


An age of â„³ is a class K of â„’-structures such that:
* if ğ’œ is a finitely generated â„’-structure such that there is an â„’-embedding ğ’œâ†’â„³, then ğ’œ is isomorphic to some structure in K,
* no two structures in K are isomorphic, and
* K does not contain any structures which are not finitely generated or do not embed into â„³.

That is, K is an age of â„³  if and only if  it contains exactly one representative from each isomorphism type of the finitely-generated structures that embed into â„³.


 

Category:Definitions/Model Theory for Predicate Logic

title: Definition:Parenthesis
definition:
Parenthesis is a syntactical technique to disambiguate the meaning of a logical formula.

It allows one to specify that a logical formula should (temporarily) be regarded as being a single entity, being on the same level as a statement variable.

Such a formula is referred to as being in parenthesis.

Typically, a formal language, in defining its formal grammar, ensures by means of parenthesis that all of its well-formed words are uniquely readable.


Generally, brackets are used to indicate that certain formulas are in parenthesis.

The brackets that are mostly used are round ones, the left (round) bracket ( and the right (round) bracket ).

title: Definition:Set
definition:
A set is intuitively defined as any aggregation of objects, called elements, which can be precisely defined in some way or other.

We can think of each set as a single entity in itself, and we can denote it (and usually do) by means of a single symbol.


That is, anything you care to think of can be a set. This concept is known as the  .


However, there are problems with the  . If we allow it to be used without any restrictions at all, paradoxes arise, the most famous example probably being Russell's Paradox.


Hence some sources define a set as a  'well-defined' collection of objects, leaving the concept of what constitutes well-definition to later in the exposition.

title: Definition:Aggregation (Physics)
definition:
An aggregation, in the context of physics, is a set of bodies (but usually particles) all of which are under the same or similar conditions, and which are assumed to behave (in certain aspects) as one body.

The concept is deliberately left vague.

title: Definition:Algebra (Mathematical Branch)
definition: Algebra is the branch of mathematics which studies the techniques of manipulation of objects and expressions.

title: Definition:Abstract Algebra
definition:
Abstract algebra is a branch of mathematics which studies algebraic structures and algebraic systems.

It can be roughly described as the study of sets equipped with operations.

title: Definition:Algebraic Structure
definition:
An algebraic structure with n operations is an ordered tuple:
:( S, âˆ˜_1, âˆ˜_2, â€¦, âˆ˜_n )
where:
:S is a set
:âˆ˜_1, âˆ˜_2, â€¦, âˆ˜_n are n binary operations which are defined on all the elements of S Ã— S.


=== One Operation ===
An algebraic structure with 1 operation is an ordered pair:
:( S, âˆ˜)
where:
:S is a set
:âˆ˜ is a binary operation defined on all the elements of S Ã— S.

=== Two Operations ===
An algebraic structure with 2 operations is an ordered triple:
:( S, âˆ˜, * )
where:
:S is a set
:âˆ˜ and * are binary operations defined on all the elements of S Ã— S.

title: Definition:Linear Algebra (Mathematical Branch)
definition: Linear algebra is the branch of algebra which studies vector spaces and linear transformations between them.

title: Definition:Vector Algebra
definition: Vector Algebra is the branch of mathematics which studies the algebra of vector spaces.

title: Definition:Algebra Loop
definition:
An algebra loop ( S, âˆ˜) is a quasigroup with an identity element.
:âˆƒ e âˆˆ S: âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ e = x = e âˆ˜ x

title: Definition:Algebraic Topology
definition: Algebraic topology is a branch of topology which uses tools from abstract algebra to study topological spaces.

title: Definition:Algebraic Geometry
definition:
Algebraic geometry is the branch of geometry which studies objects in multi-dimensional space using the techniques of abstract algebra.

In particular, techniques from commutative algebra are mainly used.

It also encompasses the study of algebraic varieties.

title: Definition:Algebraic Variety
definition: An algebraic variety is the solution set of a system of simultaneous polynomial equations:

title: Definition:Algebraically Independent
definition:
Let L / K be a field extension.

Let A âŠ† L be a subset of L.

Let K (   ){ X_Î±: Î±âˆˆ A } be the field of rational functions in the indeterminates âŸ¨ X_Î±âŸ©_Î±âˆˆ A.


Then A is algebraically independent over K  if and only if  there exists a homomorphism:
:Ï•: K (   ){ X_Î±: Î±âˆˆ A }â†’ L
such that, for all Î±âˆˆ A:
:Ï•(   )X_Î± = Î±

title: Definition:Algebraic Number Theory
definition:
Algebraic number theory is the branch of abstract algebra which studies structures in which the usual number fields are embedded.

As such it can also be considered to be a branch of number theory.

title: Definition:Algebraic Integer
definition:
Let K / â„š be an algebraic number field.

 


Then Î±âˆˆ K is an algebraic integer  if and only if  it satisfies a monic polynomial f âˆˆâ„¤[ X ].

The set of all algebraic integers in K is denoted ğ’ª_K.


By Ring of Algebraic Integers it is a ring, hence usually referred to as the ring of algebraic integers of K.


=== Quadratic Integer ===
Let K / â„š be an algebraic number field.

Let K / â„š have degree two.


Then an algebraic integer in K is a quadratic integer.

title: Definition:Disjunction/Disjunct
definition:
Let p  q be a compound statement whose main connective is the disjunction:
:p  q  if and only if  p is true or q is true or both are true.


The substatements p and q are known as the disjuncts.

title: Definition:Alternant (Linear Algebra)
definition:
An alternant is a determinant of order n such that the element in the ith row and jth column is defined as:
:f_i (   )r_j
where:
:the f_i are n mappings
:the r_j are n elements.

title: Definition:Disjunction/Disjunct
definition:
Let p  q be a compound statement whose main connective is the disjunction:
:p  q  if and only if  p is true or q is true or both are true.


The substatements p and q are known as the disjuncts.

title: Definition:Alternative Operation
definition:
Let âˆ˜ be a binary operation.


Then âˆ˜ is defined as being alternative on S  if and only if :

:âˆ€ T := { x, y }âŠ† S: âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ T: ( x âˆ˜ y ) âˆ˜ z = x âˆ˜( y âˆ˜ z )

That is, âˆ˜ is associative over any two elements of S.


For example, for any x, y âˆˆ S:
:( x âˆ˜ y ) âˆ˜ x = x âˆ˜( y âˆ˜ x )
:( x âˆ˜ x ) âˆ˜ y = x âˆ˜( x âˆ˜ y )
and so on.

title: Definition:Altitude of Polygon
definition: An altitude of a polygon is the longest perpendicular from the base to a vertex most distant from the base.

title: Definition:Altitude of Triangle
definition:
Let ABC be a triangle.

Let a perpendicular be dropped from âˆ  A to its opposite side a or its production:

:

The line h_a so constructed is called the altitude of âˆ  A.


=== Foot of Altitude ===
Let ABC be a triangle.

Let h_a be the altitude of A:

:


The point at which h_a meets BC (or its production) is the foot of the altitude h_a.


Category:Definitions/Triangles

title: Definition:Parallelogram/Altitude
definition:
:

An altitude of a parallelogram is a line drawn perpendicular to its base, through one of its vertices to the side opposite to the base (which is extended if necessary).

In the parallelogram above, line DE is an altitude of the parallelogram ABCD.


The term is also used for the length of such a line.

title: Definition:Altitude of Polyhedron
definition: An altitude of a polyhedron is the longest perpendicular from the base to a vertex most distant from the base.

title: Definition:Cone (Geometry)/Altitude
definition:
:

Let a perpendicular AE be dropped from the apex of a cone to the plane containing its base.

The line segment AE is an altitude of the cone.

title: Definition:Altitude of Cylinder
definition:
:

An altitude of a cylinder is a line segment drawn perpendicular to the base and its opposite plane.


In the above diagram, HJ is an altitude of the cylinder ACBDFE.

title: Definition:Periodic Real Function/Amplitude
definition:
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a periodic real function.


The amplitude of f is the maximum absolute difference of the value of f from a reference level.

title: Definition:Incomplete Elliptic Integral of the First Kind/Amplitude
definition:
Let u = F (   )k, Ï• denote the incomplete elliptic integral of the first kind.

The parameter Ï• of u = F (   )k, Ï• is called the amplitude of u.


=== Symbol ===

title: Definition:Simple Harmonic Motion/Amplitude
definition:
Consider a physical system S in a state of simple harmonic motion:
:x = A sin(   )Ï‰ t + Ï•


The parameter A is known as the amplitude of the motion.

title: Definition:Annulus (Geometry)
definition:
An annulus is a plane figure whose boundary consists of 2 concentric circles:

:

In the above diagram, the annulus is the colored area.


=== Center of Annulus ===
:

The center of an annulus is the common center of the 2 concentric circles that form its boundary.

In the above diagram, the center is the point O.


Category:Definitions/Annuli

=== Inner Radius of Annulus ===
:

The inner radius of an annulus is the radius of the smaller of the 2 concentric circles that form its boundary.

In the above diagram, the inner radius is denoted r.

=== Outer Radius of Annulus ===
:

The outer radius of an annulus is the radius of the larger of the 2 concentric circles that form its boundary.

In the above diagram, the outer radius is denoted R.

=== Width of Annulus ===
:

The width of an annulus is the difference between its outer radius and the inner radius

In the above diagram, the width of the annulus is R - r.

title: Definition:Annulus (Topology)
definition:
An annulus in the context of topology is a topological space which is homeomorphic with an annulus in the context of geometry.

:

title: Definition:Ring (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
A ring ( R, *, âˆ˜) is a semiring in which ( R, * ) forms an abelian group.


That is, in addition to ( R, * ) being closed, associative and commutative under *, it also has an identity, and each element has an inverse.


=== Ring Axioms ===
 

Note that a ring is still a semiring (in fact, an additive semiring), so all properties of these structures also apply to a ring.


=== Addition ===
The distributand * of a ring ( R, *, âˆ˜) is referred to as ring addition.


The conventional symbol for this operation is +, and thus a general ring is usually denoted ( R, +, âˆ˜).


=== Additive Group ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.


The group ( R, + ) is known as the additive group of R.

=== Additive Inverse ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring whose ring addition operation is +.

Let a âˆˆ R be any arbitrary element of R.


The additive inverse of a is its inverse under ring addition, denoted -a:

:a + ( -a ) = 0_R

where 0_R is the zero of R.


=== Additive Inverse of Number ===

The concept is often encountered in the context of numbers:
Let F be one of the standard number systems: â„•, â„¤, â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let a âˆˆ F be any arbitrary number.


The additive inverse of a is its inverse under addition, denoted -a:

:a + ( -a ) = 0

=== Product ===
Let ( R, *, âˆ˜) be a ring.


The distributive operation âˆ˜ in ( R, *, âˆ˜) is known as the ring product.

=== Binding Priority ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.


In order to simplify expressions involving both + and âˆ˜, it is the convention that ring product has a higher precedence than ring addition:

:a âˆ˜ b + c := ( a âˆ˜ b ) + c


Category:Definitions/Ring Theory

=== Ring Less Zero ===
Let ( R, *, âˆ˜) be a ring whose zero is 0.

It is convenient to have a symbol for R âˆ–{ 0 }, that is, the set of all elements of the ring without the zero.

Thus we usually use:
:R_ 0 = R âˆ–{ 0 }

title: Definition:Archimedean Polyhedron
definition:
An Archimedean polyhedron is a convex polyhedron with the following properties:
:(1): Each of its faces is a regular polygon
:(2): It is isogonal
:(3): The faces are not all congruent.
:(4): It is not a uniform prism or a uniform antiprism.

title: Definition:Archimedean Spiral
definition:
The Archimedean spiral is the locus of the equation expressed in polar coordinates as:
:r = a Î¸


:


=== Archimedes' Definition ===
 ' definition of his Archimedean spiral is as follows:

:If a straight line of which one extremity remains fixed be made to revolve at a uniform rate in a plane until it returns to the position from which it started, and if, at the same time as the straight line revolves, a point moves at a uniform rate along the straight line, starting from the fixed extremity, the point will describe a spiral in the plane.

Let X be a vector space over R, with zero 0_X.


A non-Archimedean norm on X is a mapping from X to the non-negative reals:

The pair ( X, â€– Â· â€–) is a non-Archimedean normed vector space.


=== Archimedean ===
A norm â€– Â· â€– on a vector space X is Archimedean  if and only if  it is not non-Archimedean.

=== Non-Archimedean Norm (Division Ring) ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a division ring whose zero is denoted 0_R.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a division ring whose zero is denoted 0_R.


A norm â€– Â· â€– on R is non-Archimedean  if and only if  â€– Â· â€– satisfies the axiom:

A metric d on a metric space X is non-Archimedean  if and only if :

for all x, y, z âˆˆ X.

title: Definition:Artinian Ring
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Then A is Artinian  if and only if  it is Artinian as an A-module.

title: Definition:Artinian Module
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module.


M is a Artinian module  if and only if :
:M satisfies the descending chain condition.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module


M is a Artinian module  if and only if :
:M satisfies the minimal condition.

title: Definition:Associative Operation
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let âˆ˜ : S Ã— S â†’ S be a binary operation.


Then âˆ˜ is associative  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: ( x âˆ˜ y ) âˆ˜ z = x âˆ˜( y âˆ˜ z )

title: Definition:Power-Associative Operation
definition:
Let âˆ˜ be a binary operation.

Then âˆ˜ is defined as being power-associative on S  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: ( x âˆ˜ x ) âˆ˜ x = x âˆ˜( x âˆ˜ x )

title: Definition:Semigroup
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a magma.


Then ( S, âˆ˜) is a semigroup  if and only if  âˆ˜ is associative on S.


That is:

:A semigroup is an algebraic structure which is closed and whose operation is associative.


=== Semigroup Axioms ===

The properties that define a semigroup can be gathered together as follows:

 

=== Multiplicative Semigroup ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a semigroup whose operation is multiplication.


Then ( S, âˆ˜) is a multiplicative semigroup.


It is implicit in this definition that the elements of S are numbers, or objects derived from numbers upon which the concept of multiplication is applicable.

=== Additive Semigroup ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a semigroup whose operation is addition.


Then ( S, âˆ˜) is an additive semigroup.


It is implicit in this definition that the elements of S are numbers, or objects derived from numbers upon which the concept of addition is applicable.

title: Definition:Associative Algebra
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring.

Let ( A_R, * ) be an algebra over R.


Then ( A_R, * ) is an associative algebra  if and only if  * is an associative operation.

That is:

:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ A_R: ( a * b ) * c = a * ( b * c )

title: Definition:Atom (Logic)
definition:
In a particular branch of logic, certain concepts are at such a basic level of simplicity they can not be broken down into anything simpler.

Those concepts are called atoms or described as atomic.


Different branches of logic admit different atoms.


=== Propositional Logic ===
In propositional logic, the atoms are simple statements.

title: Definition:Atom of Measure
definition:
Let ( X, x3a3, Î¼) be a measure space.


An element x âˆˆ X is said to be an atom (of Î¼)  if and only if :

:(1):   { x }âˆˆx3a3
:(2):   Î¼(   ){ x } > 0

title: Definition:Atom of Sigma-Algebra
definition:
Let ( X, x3a3) be a measurable space.

Let E âˆˆx3a3 be non-empty.


E is said to be an atom (of x3a3)  if and only if  it satisfies:

:âˆ€ F âˆˆx3a3: F âŠŠ E  F = âˆ…


Thus, atoms are the minimal non-empty sets in x3a3 with respect to the subset ordering.

title: Definition:Atom of Lattice
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.


An atom of ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is an element A âˆˆ S such that:
:âˆ€ B âˆˆ S: B â‰¼ A, B  A  B =
:A
where  denotes the bottom of ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼).

title: Definition:Atom (Physics)
definition:
An atom (in the context of physics and chemistry) is the smallest piece of matter that can exist of a particular type of substance.


Atoms can be subdivided into smaller particles, but then it ceases to be that substance.


=== Diameter ===
The diameter of an atom (considered approximately spherical) is between about 1 and 5 angstroms.

title: Definition:Automorphism (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
An automorphism is an isomorphism from an algebraic structure to itself.

This applies to the term isomorphism as used both in the sense of bijective homomorphism as well as that of an order isomorphism.


Hence an automorphism is a permutation which is either a homomorphism or an order isomorphism, depending on context.


=== Semigroup Automorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a semigroup.

Let Ï•: S â†’ S be a (semigroup) isomorphism from S to itself.


Then Ï• is a semigroup automorphism.

=== Group Automorphism ===
Let ( G, âˆ˜) be a group.

Let Ï•: G â†’ G be a (group) isomorphism from G to itself.


Then Ï• is a group automorphism.

=== Ring Automorphism ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let Ï•: R â†’ R be a (ring) isomorphism.


Then Ï• is a ring automorphism.

That is, a ring automorphism is a (ring) isomorphism from a ring to itself.

=== Field Automorphism ===
Let ( F, +, âˆ˜) be a field.

Let Ï•: F â†’ F be a (field) isomorphism from F to itself.


Then Ï• is a field automorphism.

=== R-Algebraic Structure Automorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ—_1, âˆ—_2, â€¦, âˆ—_n, âˆ˜)_R be an R-algebraic structure.

Let Ï•: S â†’ S be an R-algebraic structure isomorphism from S to itself.


Then Ï• is an R-algebraic structure automorphism.


This definition continues to apply when S is a module, and also when it is a vector space.


=== Module Automorphism ===
Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be an R-module.

Let Ï•: G â†’ G be a module isomorphism to itself.


Then Ï• is a module automorphism.

=== Vector Space Automorphism ===
Let V be a K-vector space.

Let Ï•: V â†’ V be a vector space isomorphism to itself.


Then Ï• is a vector space automorphism.

=== Ordered Structure Automorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) be an ordered structures.

Let Ï•: S â†’ S be an ordered structure isomorphism from S to itself.


Then Ï• is an ordered structure automorphism.


=== Ordered Semigroup Automorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) be an ordered semigroup.

An ordered semigroup automorphism from ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to itself is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ S that is both:

:(1): A semigroup automorphism, that is, a semigroup isomorphism from the semigroup ( S, âˆ˜) to itself

:(2): An order isomorphism from the ordered set ( S, â‰¼) to itself.

=== Ordered Group Automorphism ===
Let ( G, âˆ˜, â‰¼) be an ordered group.

An ordered group automorphism from ( G, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to itself is a mapping Ï•: G â†’ G that is both:

:(1): A group automorphism, that is, a group isomorphism from the group ( G, âˆ˜) to itself

:(2): An order isomorphism from the ordered set ( G, â‰¼) to itself.

=== Ordered Ring Automorphism ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜, â‰¼) be an ordered ring.


An ordered ring automorphism from ( R, +, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to itself is a mapping Ï•: R â†’ R that is both:

:(1): An ordered group automorphism from the ordered group ( R, +, â‰¼) to itself

:(2): A semigroup automorphism from the semigroup ( R, âˆ˜) to itself.

title: Definition:Embedding (Model Theory)
definition:
Let â„³ and ğ’© be â„’-structures with universes M and N respectively.


j: â„³â†’ğ’© is an â„’-embedding  if and only if  it is an injective map M â†’ N which preserves interpretations of all symbols in â„’; that is, such that:
:j (   )f^â„³(   )a_1, â€¦, a_n_f = f^ğ’©(   )j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_f for all function symbols f in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_f in M
:( a_1, â€¦, a_n_R) âˆˆ R^â„³( j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_R) âˆˆ R^ğ’© for all relation symbols R in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_R in M
:j (   )c^â„³ = c^ğ’© for all constant symbols c in â„’.


=== Partial Embedding ===

A common method of constructing isomorphisms and elementary embeddings in proofs is to recursively define them a finite number of elements at a time.  For this  purpose, it is useful to have a definition of embeddings using functions which are only defined on a subset of M:


Let A âŠ† M be a subset of M.


j: A â†’ğ’© is a partial â„’-embedding  if and only if  it is an injective map A â†’ N which preserves interpretations of all symbols in â„’ applied to elements of A; that is, such that:
:j (   )f^â„³(   )a_1, â€¦, a_n_f = f^ğ’©(   )j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_f for  all function symbols f in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_f in A
:( a_1, â€¦, a_n_R) âˆˆ R^â„³( j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_R) âˆˆ R^ğ’© for all relation symbols R in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_R in A
:j (   )c^â„³ = c^ğ’© for all constant symbols c in â„’.


=== Isomorphism ===

j: â„³â†’ğ’© is an â„’-isomorphism  if and only if  it is a bijective â„’-embedding.


=== Automorphism ===

j: â„³â†’ğ’© is an â„’-automorphism  if and only if  it is an â„’-isomorphism and â„³ = ğ’©.


It is often useful to talk about automorphisms which are constant on subsets of M.  So, there is a definition and a notation for doing so:

Let A âŠ† M be a subset of M, and let b âˆˆ M.


An â„’-automorphism j is an A-automorphism  if and only if  j (   )a = a for all aâˆˆ A.

An â„’-automorphism j is an A, b-automorphism  if and only if  it is an ( A âˆª{ b })-automorphism; that is: j (   )a = a for all a âˆˆ A and also j (   )b = b.

title: Definition:Auxiliary Equation
definition:
Let:
:(1):    y' ' + p y' + q y = 0
be a constant coefficient homogeneous linear second order ODE.


The auxiliary equation of (1) is the quadratic equation:
:m^2 + p m + q = 0

Let L = ( S, âˆ¨, â‰¼) be a bounded below join semilattice.

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation on S.


Then â„› is an auxiliary relation  if and only if  â„› satisfies the auxiliary relation axioms:

title: Definition:Auxiliary Circle
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a central conic, that is, an ellipse or a hyperbola.

The auxiliary circle of ğ’¦ is the eccentric circle whose diameter coincides with the major axis of ğ’¦.


=== Auxiliary Circle of Ellipse ===
Let E be an ellipse.

The auxiliary circle of E is the eccentric circle whose diameter coincides with the major axis of E:

:

In the above diagram, the auxiliary circle of E is the circle C.

=== Auxiliary Circle of Hyperbola ===
Let H be a hyperbola.

The auxiliary circle of H is the eccentric circle whose diameter coincides with the major axis of H:

:

In the above diagram, the auxiliary circle of H is the circle C.

title: Definition:Auxiliary Angle
definition:
Consider the expression:

:(1):    p sin x + q cos x

where x âˆˆâ„.

Let (1) be expressed in the form:
:(2):    R cos(   )x + Î±

or:
:(3):    R sin(   )x + Î±


The angle Î± is known as the auxiliary angle of either (2) or (3) as appropriate.

title: Definition:Baire Space (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is a Baire space  if and only if  the union of any countable set of closed sets of T whose interiors are empty also has an empty interior.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is a Baire space  if and only if  the intersection of any countable set of open sets of T which are everywhere dense is everywhere dense.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is a Baire space  if and only if  the interior of the union of any countable set of closed sets of T which are nowhere dense is empty.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is a Baire space  if and only if , whenever the union of any countable set of closed sets of T has an interior point, then one of those closed sets must have an interior point.

title: Definition:Baire Space (Set Theory)
definition:
The Baire space ğ is defined as the set of all infinite sequences of natural numbers.

It can also be defined as the Cartesian product of a countably infinite number of copies of the set of natural numbers.

title: Definition:Bar Chart
definition:
A bar chart is a form of graph which consists of a finite set of (usually) vertical bars whose length determines the statistic being communicated.


:

title: Definition:Bar (Unit)
definition:
The bar is a CGS unit of pressure.


It is defined as being:

:The amount of pressure equal to exactly 100   000 pascals.


=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Bar (Mechanics)
definition: A bar is a straight rigid body whose length in one dimension is such that its width in the other two dimensions is negligible.

title: Definition:Base of Geometric Figure
definition:
The base of a geometric figure is a specific part of that figure which is distinguished from the remainder of that figure and placed (actually or figuratively) at the bottom of a depiction or visualisation.

In some cases the base is truly qualitiatively different from the rest of the figure.

In other cases the base is selected arbitrarily as one of several parts of the figure which may equally well be so chosen.

title: Definition:Triangle (Geometry)/Base
definition:
:


For a given triangle, one of the sides can be distinguished as being the base.

It is immaterial which is so chosen.

The usual practice is that the triangle is drawn so that the base is made horizontal, and at the bottom.

In the above diagram, it would be conventional for the side AC to be identified as the base.

title: Definition:Triangle (Geometry)/Isosceles/Base
definition:
:


The base of an isosceles triangle is specifically defined to be the side which is a different length from the other two.

In the above diagram, BC is the base.

title: Definition:Parallelogram/Base
definition:
:

In a given parallelogram, one of the sides is distinguished as being the base.

It is immaterial which is so chosen, but usual practice is that it is one of the two longer sides.

In the parallelogram above, line AB is considered to be the base.

title: Definition:Segment of Circle/Base
definition:
:

The base of a segment of a circle is the straight line forming one of the boundaries of the seqment.

In the above diagram, AB is the base of the highlighted segment.

title: Definition:Cone (Geometry)/Base
definition:
Consider a cone consisting of the set of all straight lines joining the boundary of a plane figure PQR to a point A not in the same plane of PQR:


:


The plane figure PQR is called the base of the cone.

title: Definition:Basis (Topology)
definition:
=== Analytic Basis ===
=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


An analytic basis for Ï„ is a subset â„¬âŠ†Ï„ such that:
:âˆ€ U âˆˆÏ„: âˆƒğ’œâŠ†â„¬: U = â‹ƒğ’œ

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let â„¬âŠ†Ï„.


Then â„¬ is an analytic basis for Ï„  if and only if :
:âˆ€ U âˆˆÏ„: âˆ€ x âˆˆ U: âˆƒ V âˆˆâ„¬: x âˆˆ V âŠ† U

=== Synthetic Basis ===
Let S be a set.


A synthetic basis on S is a subset â„¬âŠ†ğ’«( S ) of the power set of S such that:

 
 
 
 

That is, the intersection of any pair of elements of â„¬ is a union of sets of â„¬.

title: Definition:Basis of Vector Space
definition:
Let K be a division ring.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be a vector space over K.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let R be a division ring.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be an vector space over R.


A basis of G is a linearly independent subset of G which is a generator for G.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let R be a division ring.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be an vector space over R.


A basis is a maximal linearly independent subset of G.

title: Definition:Basis of Module
definition:
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be a unitary R-module.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be a unitary R-module.


A basis of G is a linearly independent subset of G which is a generator for G.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be a unitary R-module.

Let â„¬ = âŸ¨ b_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of elements of M.

title: Definition:Basis (Hilbert Space)
definition:
Let H be a Hilbert space.


A basis for H is a maximal orthonormal subset of H.

Thus, B is a basis for H  if and only if  for all orthonormal subsets B' of H:

:B âŠ† B'  B = B'

title: Definition:Below (Number)
definition:
In the context of numbers, below means less than.

Note that this applies to:
:the natural numbers â„•
:the integers â„¤
:the rational numbers â„š
:the real numbers â„

but specifically not the complex numbers â„‚ because the complex numbers do not have a usual ordering.

title: Definition:Below (Solid Geometry)
definition:
Let a and b be points in 3-dimensional Euclidean space â„^3.

Let P be an arbitrary plane embedded in S be distinguished and defined as horizontal.

Then:
:a is below b
 if and only if :
:the height of a   P is less than the height of b   P.

:

=== Fourth Binomial ===

:

title: Definition:Binomial (Algebra)

title: Definition:Binomial Coefficient
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let n âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 and k âˆˆâ„¤.

:n k = n!k! ( n - k )!    : 0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ n 
   
 0     :  otherwise

=== Definition 2 ===
Let n âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 and k âˆˆâ„¤.

The number of different ways k objects can be chosen (irrespective of order) from a set of n objects is denoted:
:n k

This number n k is known as a binomial coefficient.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let n âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 and k âˆˆâ„¤.

Then the binomial coefficient n k is defined as the coefficient of the term a^k b^n - k in the expansion of ( a + b )^n.

Let X be a discrete random variable on a probability space ( Î©, x3a3, ).

Note that the binomial distribution gives rise to a probability mass function satisfying (   )Î© = 1, because:
:âˆ‘_k âˆˆâ„¤ n k p^k ( 1 - p )^n - k = ( p + ( 1 - p )  )^n = 1

This is apparent from the Binomial Theorem.

:X âˆ¼B( n,   )p

title: Definition:Bottom of Lattice
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.

title: Definition:Bottom (Logic)
definition:
Bottom is a constant of propositional logic interpreted to mean the canonical, undoubted contradiction whose falsehood nobody could possibly ever question.

The symbol used is .

title: Definition:Boundary (Geometry)
definition:
For example, the endpoints of a line segment are its boundaries.


=== Containment ===
A geometric figure is said to be contained by its boundary or boundaries.

title: Definition:Boundary (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


=== Definition from Closure and Interior ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


The boundary of H consists of all the points in the closure of H which are not in the interior of H.

Thus, the boundary of H is defined as:
:âˆ‚ H := H^- âˆ– H^âˆ˜
where H^- denotes the closure and H^âˆ˜ the interior of H.

=== Definition from Neighborhood ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


 

x âˆˆ S is a boundary point of H  if and only if  every neighborhood N of x satisfies:
:H âˆ© N âˆ…
and
:Hâˆ© N âˆ…
where H is the complement of H in S.

The boundary of H consists of all the boundary point of H.

=== Definition from Intersection of Closure with Closure of Complement ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


The boundary of H is the intersection of the closure of H with the closure of the complement of H in T:

:âˆ‚ H = H^- âˆ©( H)^-

=== Definition from Closure and Exterior ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


The boundary of H consists of all the points in H which are not in either the interior or exterior of H.

Thus, the boundary of H is defined as:
:âˆ‚ H := H âˆ–( H^âˆ˜âˆª H^e )
where:
:H^âˆ˜ denotes the interior of H
:H^e denotes the exterior of H.

definition:

Let G = ( V, E ) be a simple graph.

Then the boundary of v is the set of all vertices of G which are adjacent to v:
:B (   )v = { u âˆˆ V: { u, v }âˆˆ E }

title: Definition:Bounded Set/Real Numbers
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.


Let T âŠ†â„ be both bounded below and bounded above in â„.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.


Let T âŠ†â„ be a subset of â„ such that:
:âˆƒ K âˆˆâ„: âˆ€ x âˆˆ T: | x |â‰¤ K

title: Definition:Bounded Class
definition:
Let B be a class.


=== Bounded by Set ===
Let B be a class.

Let x be a set.

B is bounded by x  if and only if :
:every element of B is a subset of x.

=== Bounded Subset of Class ===
Let B be a class.

Let B be a subclass of a class A.

Then B is a bounded subset of A  if and only if :
:there exists a set x âˆˆ A such that B is bounded by x 


That is,  if and only if  every element of B is a subset of x.

definition:
Let f: S â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let f: S â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


f is bounded on S  if and only if :
:f is bounded above on S

:f is bounded below on S.

=== Definition 2 ===

f is bounded on S  if and only if :
:âˆƒ K âˆˆâ„_â‰¥ 0: âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: | f (   )x |â‰¤ K

=== Definition 3 ===

f is bounded on S  if and only if :
:âˆƒ a, b âˆˆâ„_â‰¥ 0: âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: f (   )x âˆˆ[ a  . . ]b
where [ a  . . ]b denotes the (closed) real interval from a to b.

=== Function Attaining its Bounds ===

:âˆƒ a, b âˆˆ T: âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: f (   )a â‰¤ f (   )x â‰¤ f (   )b

title: Definition:Bounded Sequence/Real
definition:
Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a real sequence.

:m â‰¤ x_i
:x_i â‰¤ M

=== Unbounded ===

âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© is unbounded  if and only if  it is not bounded.

title: Definition:Bounded Region of Plane
definition:
Let D âŠ†â„^2 be a subset of the plane.

D is bounded  if and only if  there exists a circle in the plane which completely encloses D.

title: Definition:Bounded Metric Space
definition:
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let M' = ( B, d_B ) be a subspace of M.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let M' = ( B, d_B ) be a subspace of M.


M' is bounded (in M)  if and only if :
:âˆƒ a âˆˆ A, K âˆˆâ„: âˆ€ x âˆˆ B: d (   )x, aâ‰¤ K

That is, there exists an element of A within a finite distance of all elements of B.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let M' = ( B, d_B ) be a subspace of M.


M' is bounded (in M)  if and only if :
:âˆƒ K âˆˆâ„: âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ M': d_B (   )x, yâ‰¤ K

That is, there exists a finite distance such that all pairs of elements of B are within that distance.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let M' = ( B, d_B ) be a subspace of M.

:âˆƒ x âˆˆ A, Ïµâˆˆâ„_>0: B âŠ† B_Ïµ(   )x

where B_Ïµ(   )x is the open Ïµ-ball of x.

=== Definition 4 ===

M' is bounded (in M)  if and only if :
:âˆƒ K âˆˆâ„: âˆ€ x âˆˆ B: d (   )x, a'â‰¤ K

title: Definition:Bounded Above Set/Real Numbers
definition:
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

A subset T âŠ†â„ is bounded above (in â„)  if and only if  T admits an upper bound (in â„).


=== Unbounded Above ===
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

Let T âŠ†â„ be a subset of â„ .

f is bounded above on S by the upper bound H  if and only if :

definition:

:âˆƒ M âˆˆâ„: âˆ€ i âˆˆâ„•: x_i â‰¤ M

title: Definition:Bounded Below Set/Real Numbers
definition:
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

A subset T âŠ†â„ is bounded below (in â„)  if and only if  T admits a lower bound (in â„).


=== Unbounded Below ===
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

Let T âŠ†â„ be a subset of â„ .


T âŠ†â„ is unbounded below (in â„)  if and only if  it is not bounded below.

definition:
Let f: S â†’â„ be a real-valued function.

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: L â‰¤ f (   )x

definition:

Then âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© is bounded below  if and only if :
:âˆƒ m âˆˆâ„: âˆ€ i âˆˆâ„•: m â‰¤ x_i


=== Unbounded Below ===
Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a real sequence.


âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© is unbounded below  if and only if  there exists no m in â„ such that:
:âˆ€ i âˆˆâ„•: m â‰¤ x_i

Category:Definitions/Real Sequences

title: Definition:Rooted Tree/Branch
definition:
Let T be a rooted tree with root node r_T.

A subset Î“ of T is a branch  if and only if  all the following conditions hold:
:(1): The root node r_T belongs to Î“
:(2): The parent of each node in Î“âˆ–{ r_T } is in Î“
:(3): Each node in Î“ either:
::(a): is a leaf node of T
:or:
::(b): has exactly one child node in Î“.


Informally, a branch of a rooted tree is the path from the root to a leaf.


=== Finite ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root node r_T.

Let Î“ be a branch of T.


Then Î“ is finite  if and only if  it has exactly one leaf node.

=== Infinite ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root node r_T.

Let Î“ be a branch of T.


Then Î“ is infinite  if and only if  it has no leaf node at the end.

title: Definition:Tree (Set Theory)/Branch
definition:
Let ( T, â‰¼) be a tree.

A branch of ( T, â‰¼) is a maximal chain in ( T, â‰¼).

title: Definition:Branch Point
definition:
Let U âŠ†â„‚ be an open set.

A branch point of f is a point a in U such that:

:f has more than one value at one or more points in every neighborhood of a
:f has exactly one value at a itself.

title: Definition:Branch of Curve
definition: A branch of a curve ğ’ is a part of ğ’ which is separated from another part of ğ’ by a discontinuity or a singular point.

title: Definition:Bridge (Graph Theory)
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a connected graph.

Let e âˆˆ E be an edge of G such that the edge deletion G - e is disconnected.


Then e is known as a bridge of G.

title: Definition:Bridge (Game)
definition:
Bridge is a game for 4 players whose mechanism depends on the fact that each of the 4 players are dealt a hand of 13 cards from the standard deck of 52 cards.


For the purposes of   at its current stage of evolution, details of the play of Bridge are not immediately relevant.

As and when a deeper analysis of Bridge becomes appropriate, further details can be incorporated.

title: Definition:Cancellable Element
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element x âˆˆ( S, âˆ˜) is cancellable  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ a = x âˆ˜ b  a = b
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ x = b âˆ˜ x  a = b


That is,  if and only if  it is both left cancellable and right cancellable.


=== Left Cancellable ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


An element x âˆˆ( S, âˆ˜) is left cancellable  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ a = x âˆ˜ b  a = b

=== Right Cancellable ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


An element x âˆˆ( S, âˆ˜) is right cancellable  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ x = b âˆ˜ x  a = b

title: Definition:Cancellable Operation
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


The operation âˆ˜ in ( S, âˆ˜) is cancellable  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ b = a âˆ˜ c  b = c
:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ c = b âˆ˜ c  a = b


That is,  if and only if  it is both a left cancellable operation and a right cancellable operation.


=== Left Cancellable Operation ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


The operation âˆ˜ in ( S, âˆ˜) is left cancellable  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ b = a âˆ˜ c  b = c

That is,  if and only if  all elements of ( S, âˆ˜) are left cancellable.

=== Right Cancellable Operation ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


The operation âˆ˜ in ( S, âˆ˜) is right cancellable  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ c = b âˆ˜ c  a = b

That is,  if and only if  all elements of ( S, âˆ˜) are right cancellable.

definition:
A chain is an inelastic thread whose stiffness and width are approximated to zero.

The mass of a chain is usually defined in terms of linear mass density.

title: Definition:Imperial/Length/Chain

title: Definition:Sociable Chain

:a_r = a_0

definition:

title: Definition:Dirichlet Character
definition:
Let q âˆˆâ„¤_>1.

Let ( â„¤ / q â„¤) denote the ring of integers modulo q.

Let G = ( â„¤ / q â„¤)^Ã— be the group of units of ( â„¤ / q â„¤).

Let â„‚^Ã— be the group of units of â„‚.

A Dirichlet character modulo q is a group homomorphism:
:Ï‡: G â†’â„‚^Ã—


 

By Reduced Residue System under Multiplication forms Abelian Group, a + q â„¤âˆˆ G  if and only if  (   )a, q = 1.

It is standard practice to extend Ï‡ to a function on â„¤ by setting:

:Ï‡(   )a = Ï‡(   )a + q â„¤    : (   )a, q = 1 

0     : otherwise

 


=== Trivial Character ===
 

=== Primitive Character ===
Let q âˆˆâ„¤_>1.

Let ( â„¤ / q â„¤) denote the ring of integers modulo q.

Let G = ( â„¤ / q â„¤)^Ã— be the group of units of ( â„¤ / q â„¤).

Let â„‚^Ã— be the group of units of â„‚.


Let Ï‡_0 be the trivial (Dirichlet) character modulo q.

Let q^* be the least divisor of q such that:
:Ï‡ = Ï‡_0 Ï‡^*
where Ï‡^* is some character modulo q^*.

If q = q^* then Ï‡ is called primitive, otherwise Ï‡ is imprimitive.

title: Definition:Character (Banach Algebra)
definition:

title: Definition:Characteristic of Ring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.

For a natural number n âˆˆâ„•, let n Â· x be defined as the power of x in the context of the additive group ( R, + ):

:n Â· x = 
0_R     : n = 0 
( ( n - 1 ) Â· x ) + x     : n > 0


The characteristic Char( R ) of R is the smallest n âˆˆâ„•_>0 such that n Â· 1_R = 0_R.

If there is no such n, then Char( R ) = 0.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.

Let g: â„¤â†’ R be the initial homomorphism, with g (   )n = n Â· 1_R.

Let ( p ) be the principal ideal of ( â„¤, +, Ã—) generated by p.


The characteristic Char( R ) of R is the positive integer p âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 such that ( p ) is the kernel of g.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.


The characteristic of R, denoted Char( R ), is defined as follows.

Let p be the order of 1_R in the additive group ( R, + ) of ( R, +, âˆ˜).

If p âˆˆâ„¤_>0, then Char( R ) := p.

If 1_R is of infinite order, then Char( R ) := 0.

title: Definition:Characteristic Subgroup
definition:
Let G be a group.

:âˆ€Ï•âˆˆAut( G ): Ï•[ H ] = H

title: Definition:Characteristic Matrix

:ğˆ_n x - ğ€

title: Definition:Characteristic Polynomial
definition:
A characteristic polynomial is a member of the class of polynomials which in some way allows one to sum up a number of characteristics of a particular mathematical object.


 

=== Matrix ===
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let ğ€ be a square matrix over R of order n > 0.

Let ğˆ_n be the n Ã— n identity matrix.

Let R [ x ] be the polynomial ring in one variable over R.


The characteristic polynomial of ğ€ is the determinant of the characteristic matrix of ğ€ over R [ x ]:
:p_ğ€(   )x = (   )ğˆ_n x - ğ€

=== Linear Operator ===

Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be a free module over A of finite rank n > 0.

Let Ï• : M â†’ M be a linear operator.

Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be a free module over A of finite rank n > 0.

Let Ï• : M â†’ M be a linear operator.


The characteristic polynomial of Ï• is the characteristic polynomial of the relative matrix of Ï• with respect to a basis of M.

=== Field Extension ===
Let K be a field.

Let L / K be a finite field extension of K.

Then by Vector Space on Field Extension is Vector Space, L is naturally a vector space over K.

Let Î±âˆˆ L, and Î¸_Î± be the linear operator:

:Î¸_Î±: L â†’ L : Î²â†¦Î±Î²

:[ X I_L - Î¸_Î±]

where:
: denotes the determinant of a linear operator
:X is an indeterminate 
:I_L is the identity mapping on L.

=== Element of Algebra ===
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let B be an algebra over A such that B is a finite-dimensional free module over A.

Let b âˆˆ B.


The characteristic polynomial of b is the characteristic polynomial of the regular representation Î»_b : B â†’ B over A.

title: Definition:Characteristic Equation of Matrix
definition:

title: Definition:Auxiliary Equation
definition:
Let:
:(1):    y' ' + p y' + q y = 0
be a constant coefficient homogeneous linear second order ODE.


The auxiliary equation of (1) is the quadratic equation:
:m^2 + p m + q = 0

title: Definition:Characteristic Function (Set Theory)
definition:
=== Set ===
Let E âŠ† S.

The characteristic function of E is the function Ï‡_E: S â†’{ 0, 1 } defined as:
:Ï‡_E (   )x =  1     : x âˆˆ E  
  0     : x âˆ‰ E

That is:
:Ï‡_E (   )x =  1     : x âˆˆ E  
 0     : x âˆˆâˆ_S(   )E
where âˆ_S(   )E denotes the complement of E relative to S.


=== Support ===
Let S be a set

Let E âŠ† S be a subset.

Let Ï‡_E: S â†’{ 0, 1 } be the characteristic function of E.


The support of Ï‡_E, denoted supp(   )Ï‡_E, is the set E.

That is:

:supp(   )Ï‡_E = { x âˆˆ S: Ï‡_E (   )x = 1 }

=== Relation ===
The concept of a characteristic function of a subset carries over directly to relations.


Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.

The characteristic function of â„› is the mapping Ï‡_â„›: S Ã— T â†’{ 0, 1 } defined as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )x, y =  1     : ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›
 0     : ( x, y ) âˆ‰â„›


It can be expressed in Iverson bracket notation as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )x, y = [ ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›]


More generally, let ğ•Š = âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i = S_1 Ã— S_2 Ã—â€¦Ã— S_n be the cartesian product of n sets S_1, S_2, â€¦, S_n.

Let â„›âŠ†ğ•Š be an n-ary relation on ğ•Š.

The characteristic function of â„› is the mapping Ï‡_â„›: ğ•Šâ†’{ 0, 1 } defined as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n =  1     : ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›
 0     : ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆ‰â„›


It can be expressed in Iverson bracket notation as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n = [ ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›]

title: Definition:General Logarithm/Common/Characteristic
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„ be a positive real number such that 0 < n < 1.

:a Ã— 10^d

c m     : d < 0

definition:
Let E âŠ† S.

  0     : x âˆ‰ E

:Ï‡_E (   )x =  1     : x âˆˆ E  
 0     : x âˆˆâˆ_S(   )E
where âˆ_S(   )E denotes the complement of E relative to S.


=== Support ===
Let S be a set

:supp(   )Ï‡_E = { x âˆˆ S: Ï‡_E (   )x = 1 }

title: Definition:Characteristic Function (Set Theory)/Relation
definition:
The concept of a characteristic function of a subset carries over directly to relations.


Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.

The characteristic function of â„› is the mapping Ï‡_â„›: S Ã— T â†’{ 0, 1 } defined as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )x, y =  1     : ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›
 0     : ( x, y ) âˆ‰â„›


It can be expressed in Iverson bracket notation as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )x, y = [ ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›]


More generally, let ğ•Š = âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i = S_1 Ã— S_2 Ã—â€¦Ã— S_n be the cartesian product of n sets S_1, S_2, â€¦, S_n.

Let â„›âŠ†ğ•Š be an n-ary relation on ğ•Š.

The characteristic function of â„› is the mapping Ï‡_â„›: ğ•Šâ†’{ 0, 1 } defined as:
:Ï‡_â„›(   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n =  1     : ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›

title: Definition:Characteristic Function of Random Variable
definition:
Let ( Î©, x3a3, ) be a probability space.

title: Definition:Class Theory
definition: Class theory is an extension of set theory which allows the creation of collections that are not sets by classes.

title: Definition:Class (Class Theory)
definition:
A class is a collection of all sets such that a particular condition holds.


In class-builder notation, this is written as:

:{ x: p (   )x }

where p (   )x is a statement containing x as a free variable.  

This is read:
:All x such that p (   )x holds.

title: Definition:Class Interval
definition:
Let D be a finite set of n observations of a quantitative variable.


=== Integer Data ===
Let D be a finite collection of n data regarding some quantitative variable.

Let the data in D be described by integers.

Let d_min be the value of the smallest datum in D.

Let d_max be the value of the largest datum in D.
 
Let P = { x_0, x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n - 1, x_n }âŠ†â„¤ be a subdivision of [ a  . . ]b, where a â‰¤ x_0 â‰¤ x_n â‰¤ b.


The integer interval [ a  . . ]b, where a â‰¤ d_minâ‰¤ d_maxâ‰¤ b, is said to be divided into class intervals of integer intervals of the forms [ x_i  . . ]x_i + 1 or [ x_i  . . ]x_i  if and only if :

:Every datum is assigned into exactly one class interval

:Every class interval is disjoint from every other class interval

:The union of all class intervals contains the entire integer interval [ x_0  . . ]x_n

By convention, the first and last class intervals are not empty class intervals.

=== Real Data ===
Let D be a finite collection of n data regarding some quantitative variable.

Let the data in D be described by rational numbers or by real numbers.

Let d_min be the value of the smallest datum in D.

Let d_max be the value of the largest datum in D.
 
Let P = { x_0, x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n - 1, x_n }âŠ†â„ be a subdivision of [ a  . . ]b, where a â‰¤ x_0 â‰¤ x_n â‰¤ b.


The closed real interval [ a  . . ]b, where a â‰¤ d_minâ‰¤ d_maxâ‰¤ b, is said to be divided into class intervals of real intervals with endpoints x_i and x_i + 1  if and only if :

:Every datum is assigned into exactly one class interval

:Every class interval is disjoint from every other class interval

:The union of all class intervals contains the entire real interval [ x_0  . . ]x_n


The class intervals may be any combination of open, closed, or half-open intervals that fulfill the above criteria, but usually:

:Every class interval except the last is of the form [ x_i  . . ]x_i + 1

:The last class interval is of the form [ x_n - 1 . . ]x_n 

By convention, the first and last class intervals are not empty class intervals.

=== Boundary of Class Interval ===
The class boundaries of a class interval are the endpoints of the integer interval or real interval which defines the class interval.

=== Class Mark ===
A class mark is a value within a class interval used to identify that class interval uniquely.

It is usual to use the midpoint.


=== Class Midpoint ===
When a class mark is defined to be the midpoint of the class interval it identifies, it is often called the class midpoint.

=== Empty Class Interval ===
A class interval is empty  if and only if  it is of frequency zero.

=== Relative Sizes of Class Interval ===

title: Definition:Differentiability Class
definition:
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function.

Then f (   )x is of differentiability class C^k  if and only if :
:d^kd x^k f (   )x âˆˆ C

where C denotes the class of continuous real functions.


That is, f is in differentiability class k  if and only if  there exists a kth derivative of f which is continuous.


If d^kd x^k f (   )x is continuous for all k âˆˆâ„•, then f (   )x is of differentiability class C^âˆ.

title: Definition:Homotopy Class
definition:
Let X and Y be topological spaces.

Let K âŠ† X be any subset.

Let f : X â†’ Y be a continuous mapping.

The K-homotopy class of f is the equivalence class of f under the equivalence relation defined by homotopy relative to K.


=== Homotopy Class of Path ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let f: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ S be a path in T.


The homotopy class of the path f is the homotopy class of f relative to { 0, 1 }.


That is, the equivalence class of f under the equivalence relation defined by path-homotopy.

title: Definition:Equivalence Class
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be an equivalence relation on S.

Let x âˆˆ S.


Then the equivalence class of x under â„› is the set:
:[[ x ]]_â„› = { y âˆˆ S: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}


If â„› is an equivalence on S, then each t âˆˆ S that satisfies ( x, t ) âˆˆâ„› (or ( t, x ) âˆˆâ„›) is called a â„›-relative of x.


That is, the equivalence class of x under â„› is the set of all â„›-relatives of x.


=== Representative of Equivalence Class ===
Let S be a set.

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be an equivalence relation on S.

Let x âˆˆ S.


Let [[ x ]]_â„› be the equivalence class of x under â„›.

Let y âˆˆ[[ x ]]_â„›.

Then y is a representative of [[ x ]]_â„›.

title: Definition:Conjugacy Class
definition:
The equivalence classes into which the conjugacy relation divides its group into are called conjugacy classes.

The conjugacy class of an element x âˆˆ G can be denoted C_x.

title: Definition:NP Complexity Class
definition:
In computability theory, NP is a complexity class in which there exists some nondeterministic Turing machine that will either:
:halt within p (   )| x | steps
or:
:run forever

where:
:p is a polynomial
:| x | is the length of the input to the Machine.

title: Definition:Truth Table/Column
definition:
A row of a truth table is one of the vertical lines headed by a statement form presenting all the truth values that the statement form takes.

Each entry in the column corresponds to one specific combination of truth values taken by the propositional variables that the statement form comprises.

title: Definition:Matrix/Column
definition:
Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix.

For each j âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]n, the columns of ğ€ are the ordered m-tuples:
:c_j = ( a_1 j, a_2 j, â€¦, a_m j)

where c_j is called the jth column of ğ€.


A column of an m Ã— n matrix can also be treated as a m Ã— 1 column matrix in its own right:
:c_j = [ a_1 j; a_2 j;     â‹®; a_m j ]
for j = 1, 2, â€¦, n.

title: Definition:Latin Square/Column
definition:
Let ğ‹ be a Latin square.

The columns of ğ‹ are the lines of elements reading down the page.

title: Definition:General Logarithm/Common
definition:
Logarithms base 10 are often referred to as common logarithms.


=== Notation for Negative Logarithm ===
Let n âˆˆâ„ be a real number such that 0 < n < 1.

Let n be presented (possibly approximated) in scientific notation as:
:a Ã— 10^-d
where d âˆˆâ„¤_>0 is a (strictly) positive integer.

Let log_10 n denote the common logarithm of n.

Then it is the standard convention to express log_10 n in the form:
:log_10 n = d m

where m := log_10 a is the mantissa of log_10 n.


The overline notation is commonly read as bar, that is:
:2 is read as bar two.

title: Definition:Arithmetic Mean
definition:
Let x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n âˆˆâ„ be real numbers.

The arithmetic mean of x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n is defined as:

:A_n :=  1 n âˆ‘_k  = 1^n x_k

That is, to find out the arithmetic mean of a set of numbers, add them all up and divide by how many there are.

title: Definition:Common Denominator/Lowest
Definition:Common Divisor/Real Numbers
definition:
Let S be a finite set of real numbers, that is:

:S = { x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n: âˆ€ k âˆˆâ„•^*_n: x_k âˆˆâ„}


Let c âˆˆâ„ such that c divides all the elements of S, that is:

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: c \ x


Then c is a common divisor of all the elements in S.

title: Definition:Greatest Common Divisor/Real Numbers
definition:
Let a, b âˆˆâ„ be commensurable.

Then there exists a greatest element d âˆˆâ„_>0 such that:
:d \ a
:d \ b
where d \ a denotes that d is a divisor of a.


This is called the greatest common divisor of a and b and denoted { a, b }.

title: Definition:Common Multiple
definition:
Let S be a finite set of non-zero integers, that is:

:S = { x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n: âˆ€ k âˆˆâ„•^*_n: x_k âˆˆâ„¤, x_k  0 }


Let m âˆˆâ„¤ such that all the elements of S divide m, that is:

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x \ m


Then m is a common multiple of all the elements in S.

title: Definition:Commutative Algebra (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring.

Let ( A_R, âŠ•) be an algebra over R.


Then ( A_R, âŠ•) is a commutative algebra  if and only if  âŠ• is a commutative operation.

That is:

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ A_R: a âŠ• b = b âŠ• a

title: Definition:Commutative Algebra (Mathematical Branch)
definition: Commutative algebra is the branch of abstract algebra concerned with commutative and unitary rings.

title: Definition:Relation Compatible with Operation
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a closed algebraic structure.

Let â„› be a relation on S.


Then â„› is compatible with âˆ˜  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: x â„› y ( x âˆ˜ z ) â„›( y âˆ˜ z )

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: x â„› y ( z âˆ˜ x ) â„›( z âˆ˜ y )

title: Definition:Relation Strongly Compatible with Operation
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a closed algebraic structure.

Let â„› be a relation in S.


Then â„› is strongly compatible with âˆ˜  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: x â„› y ( x âˆ˜ z ) â„›( y âˆ˜ z )

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: x â„› y ( z âˆ˜ x ) â„›( z âˆ˜ y ).


That is,  if and only if  â„› is compatible with âˆ˜ and conversely compatible with âˆ˜.

title: Definition:Operation Compatible with Set Equivalence
definition:
Let F be a (unary) operation which can be applied to sets.


Then F is compatible with set equivalence  if and only if :

:F [ A ] = F [ B ]  A âˆ¼ B

where:
:A and B are arbitrary sets
:F [ A ] denotes the image of A under F
:âˆ¼ denotes set equivalence.

title: Definition:Ordering Compatible with Ring Structure
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring whose zero is 0_R.


An ordering â‰¼ on R is compatible with the ring structure of R  if and only if  â‰¼ satisies the ring compatible ordering axioms:

title: Definition:Gradation Compatible with Ring Structure
definition:
Let ( M, Â·) be a semigroup.

Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let âŸ¨ R_n âŸ©_n âˆˆ M be a gradation of type M on the additive group of R.


The gradation is compatible with the ring structure  if and only if 
:âˆ€ m, n âˆˆ M : âˆ€ x âˆˆ S_m, y âˆˆ S_n: x âˆ˜ y âˆˆ S_m Â· n

and so:

:S_m S_n âŠ† S_ m Â· n

title: Definition:Relation Conversely Compatible with Operation
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a closed algebraic structure.

Let â„› be a relation in S.


Then â„› is conversely compatible with âˆ˜  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: ( x âˆ˜ z ) â„›( y âˆ˜ z )  x â„› y

:âˆ€ x, y, z âˆˆ S: ( z âˆ˜ x ) â„›( z âˆ˜ y )  x â„› y

title: Definition:Complementary Angles
definition:
:

Let âˆ  BAC be a right angle.

Let âˆ  BAD + âˆ  DAC = âˆ  BAC.

That is:
:âˆ  DAC = âˆ  BAC - âˆ  BAD


Then âˆ  DAC is the complement of âˆ  BAD.


Hence, for any angle Î± (whether less than a right angle or not), the complement of Î± is Ï€ 2 - Î±.

Measured in degrees, the complement of Î± is 90^âˆ˜ - Î±.


If Î± is the complement of Î², then it follows that Î² is the complement of Î±.

Hence we can say that Î± and Î² are complementary.


It can be seen from this that the complement of an angle greater than a right angle is negative.


Thus complementary angles are two angles whose measures add up to the measure of a right angle.

That is, their measurements add up to 90 degrees or Ï€ 2 radians.

title: Definition:Complements of Parallelograms
definition:
Let ABDC and EFHG be two parallelograms with the same angles, which share a diagonal, such that ABDC âˆ© EFHG âˆ….

:

Then the two parallelograms CIGK and BJHL are known as the complements of the parallelograms ABDC and EFHG.

title: Definition:Complement of Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.


The complement of â„› is the relative complement of â„› with respect to S Ã— T:
:âˆ_S Ã— T(   )â„› := {( s, t ) âˆˆ S Ã— T: ( s, t ) âˆ‰â„›}


If the sets S and T are implicit, then âˆ(   )â„› can be used.

title: Definition:Set Complement
definition:
The set complement (or, when the context is established, just complement) of a set S in a universal set ğ•Œ is defined as:

:âˆ(   )S = âˆ_ğ•Œ(   )S = ğ•Œâˆ– S

See the definition of Relative Complement for the definition of âˆ_ğ•Œ(   )S.


Thus the complement of a set S is the relative complement of S in the universal set, or the complement of S relative to the universal set.

A common alternative to the symbology âˆ(   )S, which we will sometimes use, is S.

title: Definition:Relative Complement
definition:
Let S be a set, and let T âŠ† S, that is: let T be a subset of S.

Then the set difference S âˆ– T can be written âˆ_S(   )T, and is called the relative complement of T in S, or the complement of T relative to S.

Thus:
:âˆ_S(   )T = { x âˆˆ S : x âˆ‰ T }

title: Definition:Logical Complement
definition:
The (logical) complement of a propositional formula ğ€ is the negation of ğ€, that is, ğ€.

Conversely, the complement of ğ€ is defined to be ğ€.


=== Complementary Pair ===
For any propositional formula ğ€, the set {ğ€, ğ€} is called a complementary pair of formulas.

title: Definition:Complement (Lattice Theory)
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded lattice.

Denote by  and âŠ¤ the bottom and top of S, respectively.

Let a âˆˆ S.


Then b âˆˆ S is called a complement of a  if and only if :

:b âˆ¨ a = âŠ¤
:b âˆ§ a =


If a has a unique complement, it is denoted by a.


=== Complemented Lattice ===
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded lattice.

Suppose that every a âˆˆ S admits a complement.


Then ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is called a complemented lattice.

title: Definition:Complement (Graph Theory)
definition:
=== Simple Graph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a simple graph.

The complement of G is the simple graph G = ( V, E) which consists of:
:The same vertex set V of G
:The set E defined such that { u, v }âˆˆE{ u, v }âˆ‰ E, where u and v are distinct.

=== Loop-Graph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a loop-graph.

The complement of G is the loop-graph G = ( V, E) which consists of:
:The same vertex set V of G;
:The set E defined such that:
::{ u, v }âˆˆE{ u, v }âˆ‰ E
::{ v, v }âˆˆE{ v, v }âˆ‰ E


That is, the complement G of a loop-graph G has loops on all vertices where there are no loops in G.

title: Definition:Complete Metric Space
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A metric space M = ( A, d ) is complete  if and only if  every Cauchy sequence is convergent.

=== Definition 2 ===
A metric space M = ( A, d ) is complete  if and only if  the intersection of every nested sequence of closed balls whose radii tend to zero is non-empty.

title: Definition:Topologically Complete Space
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let M = ( S, d ) be a complete metric space such that ( S, Ï„) is the topological space induced by d.


If there exists such a complete metric space, then T is described as topologically complete.

title: Definition:Complete Lattice
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a lattice.


Then ( S, â‰¼) is a complete lattice  if and only if :

:âˆ€ T âŠ† S: T admits both a supremum and an infimum.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.


Then ( S, â‰¼) is a complete lattice  if and only if :

:âˆ€ S' âŠ† S: inf S', sup S' âˆˆ S

That is,  if and only if  all subsets of S have both a supremum and an infimum.

title: Definition:Dedekind Completeness Property
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Then ( S, â‰¼) has the Dedekind completeness property  if and only if  every non-empty subset of S that is bounded above admits a supremum (in S).

title: Definition:Inductive Ordered Set
definition: An inductive ordered set is an ordered set in which every chain has an upper bound.

title: Definition:Functionally Complete
definition:
Let S be a set of truth functions.


Then S is functionally complete  if and only if  all possible truth functions are definable from S.

title: Definition:Order Completion
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼_S ) be an ordered set.


An ordered set ( T, â‰¼_T ) is an order completion of S  if and only if :

:(1):   S âŠ† T

:(2):  â‰¼_T _S = â‰¼_S, where  denotes restriction

:(3):  ( T, â‰¼_T ) is a complete ordered set

:(4): For all ordered sets ( T', â‰¼_T') satisfying (1), (2) and (3), there is a unique increasing injection Ï•: T' â†’ T

definition:
Let ( X, x3a3, Î¼), ( XÌƒ, x3a3^*, Î¼Ì…) be measure spaces.
