title: Definition:Completion (Metric Space)
definition:
Let M_1 = ( A, d ) and M_2 = ( Ãƒ, dÌƒ) be metric spaces.

Then M_2 is a completion of M_1, or M_2 completes M_1,  if and only if :
:(1):    M_2 is a complete metric space
:(2):    A âŠ†Ãƒ
:(3):    A is dense in M_2
:(4):   âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ A : dÌƒ(   )x, y = d (   )x, y. In terms of restriction of functions, this says that dÌƒ_A(   )= d.


It is immediate from this definition that a completion of a metric space M_1 consists of:
:A complete metric space M_2
:An isometry Ï• : A â†’Ãƒ
such that Ï•(   )A = {Ï•(   )x: x âˆˆ A } is dense in M_2.

An isometry is often required to be bijective, so here one should consider Ï• as a mapping from A to the image of Ï•.

Therefore to insist that Ï• be an isometry, in this context, is to say that Ï• must be an injection that preserves the metric of M_1.

title: Definition:Completion (Normed Division Ring)
definition:
Let ( R_1, â€– Â· â€–_1 ) and ( R_2, â€– Â· â€–_2 ) be normed division rings.

Let M_1 = ( R_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( R_2, d_2 ) be the metric spaces where d_1: R_1 Ã— R_1 â†’â„_â‰¥ 0 and d_2: R_2 Ã— R_2 â†’â„_â‰¥ 0 are the metrics induced by â€– Â· â€–_1 and â€– Â· â€–_2 respectively.


Then ( R_2, â€– Â· â€–_2 ) is a completion of ( R_1, â€– Â· â€–_1 )  if and only if :
:(1): there exists a distance-preserving ring monomorphism Ï•: R_1 â†’ R_2
:(2):    M_2 is a metric completion of Ï•(   )M_1.


That is, ( R_2, â€– Â· â€–_2 ) is a completion of ( R_1,â€– Â· â€–_1 )  if and only if :
:(a):    M_2 is a complete metric space
:(b): there exists a distance-preserving ring monomorphism Ï•: R_1 â†’ R_2
:(c):   Ï•(   )R_1 is a dense subspace in M_2.

title: Definition:Analysis/Complex
definition: Complex analysis is a branch of mathematics that studies complex functions.

title: Definition:Complex Number
definition:
=== Informal Definition ===
A complex number is a number in the form a + b i or a + i b where:
:a and b are real numbers
:i is a square root of -1, that is, i = âˆš(-1).

=== Formal Definition ===
A complex number is an ordered pair ( x, y ) where x, y âˆˆâ„ are real numbers, on which the operations of addition and multiplication are defined as follows:


=== Complex Addition ===
Let ( x_1, y_1 ) and ( x_2, y_2 ) be complex numbers.

Then + is a binary operation defined as:

:( x_1, y_1 ) + ( x_2, y_2 ):= ( x_1 + x_2, y_1 + y_2 )

=== Complex Multiplication ===
Let ( x_1, y_1 ) and ( x_2, y_2 ) be complex numbers.


Then ( x_1, y_1 ) ( x_2, y_2 ) is defined as:

:( x_1, y_1 ) ( x_2, y_2 ) := ( x_1 x_2 - y_1 y_2, x_1 y_2 + y_1 x_2 )

=== Scalar Product ===
Let ( x, y ) be a complex number.

Let m âˆˆâ„ be a real number.


Then m ( x, y ) is defined as:

:m ( x, y ) := ( m x, m y )

=== Construction from Cayley-Dickson Construction ===
The complex numbers can be defined by the Cayley-Dickson construction from the set of real numbers â„.

From Real Numbers form Algebra, â„ forms a nicely normed *-algebra.

Let a, b âˆˆâ„.

Then ( a, b ) âˆˆâ„‚, where:

:( a, b ) ( c, d ) = ( a c - d b, a d + c b )
:( a, b )  = ( a, -b )
where:
:a is the conjugate of a
and 
:( a, b ) is the conjugation operation on â„‚.

From Real Numbers form Algebra, a = a and so the above translate into:

:( a, b ) ( c, d ) = ( a c - d b, a d + c b )
:( a, b )  = ( a, -b )


It is clear by direct comparison with the formal definition that this construction genuinely does generate the complex numbers.

title: Definition:Complex Function
definition:
A complex function is a function whose domain and codomain are subsets of the set of complex numbers â„‚.


=== Independent Variable ===
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be a complex function.

Let f (   )z = w.


Then z is referred to as an independent variable (of f).

=== Dependent Variable ===
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be a complex function.

Let f (   )z = w.


Then w is referred to as the dependent variable (of f).

title: Definition:Complex Conjugate
definition:
Let z = a + i b be a complex number.


Then the (complex) conjugate of z is denoted z and is defined as:

:z := a - i b


That is, you get the complex conjugate of a complex number by negating its imaginary part.


=== Complex Conjugation ===
The operation of complex conjugation is the mapping:
: Â·: â„‚â†’â„‚: z â†¦z.
where z is the complex conjugate of z.


That is, it maps a complex number to its complex conjugate.


Category:Definitions/Complex Conjugates

title: Definition:Subset Product
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


We can define an operation on the power set ğ’«( S ) as follows:

:âˆ€ A, B âˆˆğ’«( S ): A âˆ˜_ğ’« B = { a âˆ˜ b: a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B }


This is called the operation induced on ğ’«( S ) by âˆ˜, and A âˆ˜_ğ’« B is called the subset product of A and B.


It is usual to write A âˆ˜ B for A âˆ˜_ğ’« B.


=== Subset Product with Singleton ===

When one of the subsets in a subset product is a singleton, we can (and often do) dispose of the set braces. Thus:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


Let A âŠ† S be a subset of S.

Then:
:(1):    a âˆ˜ S := { a }âˆ˜ S
:(2):    S âˆ˜ a := S âˆ˜{ a }

where { a }âˆ˜ S and S âˆ˜{ a } denote the subset product of { a } with S.


That is:
:a âˆ˜ S = { a âˆ˜ s: s âˆˆ S }
:S âˆ˜ a = { s âˆ˜ a: s âˆˆ S }

title: Definition:Complex (Group Theory)
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let K âŠ† G be a subset of G.


Then K is referred to by some sources as a complex of elements of G.

title: Definition:Differential Complex
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M = âŠ•_n âˆˆâ„¤ M^n be a â„¤-graded R-module that is also a differential module with differential d.


Then M is a differential complex if d satisfies:

:d(   )M^nâŠ† M^n + 1

for all n âˆˆâ„¤.


The notation d_n := d_M_n is often seen.

title: Definition:Fraction/Complex
definition: A complex fraction is a fraction such that the numerator or denominator or both are themselves fractions.

title: Definition:Compound Statement/Substatement
definition: A substatement of a compound statement is one of the statements that comprise it.

title: Definition:Set Partition/Component
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let ğ•Š = { S_1 | S_2 |â‹¯} be a partition of S.


The elements S_1, S_2, â€¦âˆˆğ•Š are known as the components of the partition.


Category:Definitions/Set Partitions

title: Definition:Component (Topology)
definition:
Let T = (S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let the relation âˆ¼ be defined on T as follows:

:x âˆ¼ y  if and only if  x and y are connected in T.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a connected set of T that contains both x and y.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let the relation âˆ¼ be defined on T as follows:

:x âˆ¼ y  if and only if  x and y are connected in T.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a connected set of T that contains both x and y.


From Connectedness of Points is Equivalence Relation, âˆ¼ is an equivalence relation.

From the Fundamental Theorem on Equivalence Relations, the points in T can be partitioned into equivalence classes.

These equivalence classes are called the (connected) components of T.


If x âˆˆ S, then the component of T containing x (that is, the set of points y âˆˆ S with x âˆ¼ y) is denoted by Comp_x (   )T.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let the relation âˆ¼ be defined on T as follows:

:x âˆ¼ y  if and only if  x and y are connected in T.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a connected set of T that contains both x and y.


The component of T containing x is defined as:

:Comp_x (   )T = â‹ƒ{ A âŠ† S: x âˆˆ A  A . is connected .  }

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let the relation âˆ¼ be defined on T as follows:

:x âˆ¼ y  if and only if  x and y are connected in T.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a connected set of T that contains both x and y.


The component of T containing x is defined as:
: the maximal connected set of T that contains x.

title: Definition:Path Component
definition:
Let T be a topological space.


=== Equivalence Class ===
Let T be a topological space.


Let âˆ¼ be the equivalence relation on T defined as:

:x âˆ¼ y  x and y are path-connected.

The equivalence classes of âˆ¼ are called the path components of T.

If x âˆˆ T, then the path component of T containing x (that is, the set of points y âˆˆ T with x âˆ¼ y) can be denoted by PC_x (   )T.


From Path-Connectedness is Equivalence Relation, âˆ¼ is an equivalence relation. 

From the Fundamental Theorem on Equivalence Relations, the points in T can be partitioned into equivalence classes.

=== Union of Path-Connected Sets ===
Let T be a topological space.


The path component of T containing x is defined as:

:PC_x (   )T = â‹ƒ{ A âŠ† S: x âˆˆ A  A . is path-connected .  }

Category:Definitions/Path-Connected Spaces

=== Maximal Path-Connected Set ===
Let T be a topological space.


The path component of T containing x is defined as:
:the maximal path-connected set of T that contains x.

title: Definition:Arc Component
definition:
Let T be a topological space.

Let us define the relation âˆ¼ on T as follows:

:x âˆ¼ y  x and y are arc-connected.


We have that âˆ¼ is an equivalence relation, so from the Fundamental Theorem on Equivalence Relations, the points in T can be partitioned into equivalence classes.

These equivalence classes are called the arc components of T.


If x âˆˆ T, then the arc component of T containing x (that is, the set of points y âˆˆ T with x âˆ¼ y) can be denoted by AC_x (   )T.

title: Definition:Irreducible Component
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


A subset Y âŠ† S is an irreducible component of T  if and only if :
:Y is irreducible
:Y is not a proper subset of an irreducible subset of S.

That is,  if and only if :
:Y is maximal in the ordered set of irreducible subsets of S, ordered by the subset relation.

title: Definition:Composite Number
definition:
A composite number c is a positive integer that has strictly more than two positive divisors.

That is, an integer greater than 1 which is not prime is defined as composite.

definition:

:

=== General Definition ===
Let f_1: S_1 â†’ S_2, f_2: S_2 â†’ S_3, â€¦, f_n: S_n â†’ S_n + 1 be mappings such that the domain of f_k is the same set as the codomain of f_k - 1.


Then the composite of f_1, f_2, â€¦, f_n is defined and denoted as:

 
 
 
 

=== Commutative Diagram ===
Let S_1, S_2 and S_3 be sets.

=== Composition as a Binary Operation ===
Let [ S â†’ S ] be the set of all mappings from a set S to itself.

Then the concept of composite mapping defines a binary operation on [ S â†’ S ]:

:âˆ€ f, g âˆˆ[ S â†’ S ]: g âˆ˜ f = {( s, t ): s âˆˆ S, ( f ( s ), t ) âˆˆ g }âˆˆ[ S â†’ S ]


Thus, for every pair ( f, g ) of mappings in [ S â†’ S ], the composition g âˆ˜ f is another element of [ S â†’ S ].

title: Definition:Composition of Relations
definition:

title: Definition:Composition of Morphisms
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.

Let (g, f) be a pair of composable morphisms.


Then the composition of f and g is a morphism g âˆ˜ f of ğ‚ subject to:

:dom(g âˆ˜ f) = dom f
:cod(g âˆ˜ f) = cod g


This composition of morphisms can be thought of as an abstraction of both composition of mappings and transitive relations.

definition:

:For all objects C of ğ‚: 2.9cm GF (C) := G (FC)
:For all morphisms f: C_1 â†’ C_2 of ğ‚: GF (f) := G (Ff)

GF is said to be a composite functor.

title: Definition:Concave Polygon
definition:
Let P be a polygon.

P is a concave polygon  if and only if :
:at least one internal angle of P is greater than 180 ^âˆ˜.

title: Definition:Concave Polyhedron
definition:
Let P be a polyhedron.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let P be a polyhedron.

P is a concave polyhedron  if and only if :
:at least one face of P lies in a plane which intersects at least one other face.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let P be a polyhedron.

P is a concave polyhedron  if and only if :
:at least one face of P lies in a plane such that P does not lie completely on one side of that plane.

title: Definition:Concave Real Function
definition:
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is concave on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ I: âˆ€Î±, Î²âˆˆâ„_>0, Î± + Î² = 1: f (   )Î± x + Î² yâ‰¥Î± f (   )x + Î² f (   )y


:

=== Strictly Concave ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is strictly concave on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ I, x  y: âˆ€Î±, Î²âˆˆâ„_>0, Î± + Î² = 1: f (   )Î± x + Î² y > Î± f (   )x + Î² f (   )y


:


The geometric interpretation is that any point on the chord drawn on the graph of any strictly concave function always lies below the graph.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is concave on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2, x_3 âˆˆ I: x_1 < x_2< x_3: f (   )x_2 - f (   )x_1/x_2 - x_1â‰¥f (   )x_3 - f (   )x_2/x_3 - x_2


Hence a geometrical interpretation: the slope of P_1 P_2 is greater than that of P_2 P_3:


:


=== Strictly Concave ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is strictly concave on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2, x_3 âˆˆ I: x_1 < x_2 < x_3: f (   )x_2 - f (   )x_1x_2 - x_1 > f (   )x_3 - f (   )x_2x_3 - x_2


Hence a geometrical interpretation: the slope of P_1 P_2 is greater than that of P_2 P_3:


:

=== Definition 3 ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is concave on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2, x_3 âˆˆ I: x_1 < x_2< x_3: f (   )x_2 - f (   )x_1x_2 - x_1â‰¥f (   )x_3 - f (   )x_1x_3 - x_1


Hence a geometrical interpretation: the slope of P_1 P_2 is greater than that of P_1 P_3:


:


=== Strictly Concave ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is strictly concave on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2, x_3 âˆˆ I: x_1 < x_2 < x_3: f (   )x_2 - f (   )x_1x_2 - x_1 > f (   )x_3 - f (   )x_1x_3 - x_1


Hence a geometrical interpretation: the slope of P_1 P_2 is greater than that of P_1 P_3:


:

title: Definition:Cone (Geometry)
definition:
A cone is a three-dimensional geometric figure which consists of the set of all straight lines joining the boundary of a plane figure PQR to a point A not in the same plane of PQR:


:

title: Definition:Cone (Category Theory)
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.

Let D: ğ‰â†’ğ‚ be a ğ‰-diagram in ğ‚.


A cone to D comprises an object C of ğ‚, and a morphism:

is a commutative diagram.

title: Definition:Congruence (Geometry)
definition:
In the field of Euclidean geometry, two geometric figures are congruent  if and only if :

:they are, informally speaking, both "the same size and shape"

:they differ only in position in space

:one figure can be overlaid on the other figure with a series of rotations, translations, and reflections.


Specifically:
:all corresponding angles of the congruent figures must have the same measurement
:all corresponding sides of the congruent figures must be be the same length.

title: Definition:Congruence (Metric Spaces)
definition:
Let ( X, d ) be a metric space.

Two subsets A, B âŠ† X of X are said to be congruent  if and only if  there exists an isometry f: X â†’ X such that f^â†’(   )A = B.

Such an isometry is called a congruence.

title: Definition:Congruence Modulo an Ideal
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring, and let J be an ideal of R.


The notation:

:a â‰¡ b  J

is used to mean:

:a + ( -b ) âˆˆ J

title: Definition:Congruence Relation
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

Let â„› be an equivalence relation on S.


Then â„› is a congruence relation for âˆ˜  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2, y_1, y_2 âˆˆ S: ( x_1 â„› x_2 ) ( y_1 â„› y_2 ) ( x_1 âˆ˜ y_1 ) â„›( x_2 âˆ˜ y_2 )

title: Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)
definition:
Let z âˆˆâ„.


=== Definition by Remainder after Division ===
Let z âˆˆâ„.


We define a relation â„›_z on the set of all x, y âˆˆâ„:
:â„›_z := {( x, y ) âˆˆâ„Ã—â„: âˆƒ k âˆˆâ„¤: x = y + k z }


This relation is called congruence modulo z, and the real number z is called the modulus.


When ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›_z, we write:
:x â‰¡ y  z
and say:
:x is congruent to y modulo z.


Similarly, when ( x, y ) âˆ‰â„›_z, we write:
:x â‰¢y  z
and say:
:x is not congruent (or incongruent) to y modulo z.

=== Definition by Modulo Operation ===
Let z âˆˆâ„.

Let  be defined as the modulo operation:

:x  y :=  x - y âŒŠ x y âŒ‹    : y  0 
 x     : y = 0


Then congruence modulo z is the relation on â„ defined as:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆâ„: x â‰¡ y  z  x  z = y  z 


The real number z is called the modulus.

=== Definition by Integer Multiple ===
Let z âˆˆâ„.

Let x, y âˆˆâ„.


Then x is congruent to y modulo z  if and only if  their difference is an integer multiple of z:
:x â‰¡ y  z âˆƒ k âˆˆâ„¤: x - y = k z

title: Definition:Matrix Congruence
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let n be a positive integer.

Let ğ€ and ğ be square matrices of order n over R.


Then:
:ğ€ and ğ are congruent
 if and only if :
:there exists a nonsingular matrix ğâˆˆ R^n Ã— n such that ğ = ğ^âŠºğ€ğ
where ğ^âŠº denotes the transpose of ğ.

title: Definition:Conjugate Angles
definition:
The conjugate of an angle Î¸ is the angle Ï• such that:
:Î¸ + Ï• = 2 Ï€
where Î¸ and Ï€ are expressed in radians.

That is, it is the angle that makes the given angle equal to a full angle.


Equivalently, the conjugate of an angle Î¸ is the angle Ï• such that:
:Î¸ + Ï• = 360 ^âˆ˜
where Î¸ and Ï€ are expressed in degrees.


Thus, conjugate angles are two angles whose measures add up to the measure of 4 right angles.

That is, their measurements add up to 360 degrees or 2 Ï€ radians.

title: Definition:Hyperbola/Conjugate Axis
definition:
Â 

:


Consider a hyperbola K whose foci are F_1 and F_2.


Let PQ and RS be line segments constructed through the vertices of K parallel to the minor axis of K and intersecting the asymptotes of K at P, Q, R and S as above.

Construct the line segments PR and QS.

Let C_1 and C_2 be the points of intersection of PR and QS with the minor axis of K.


The conjugate axis of K is the line segment C_1 C_2.

title: Definition:Conjugate Points (Geometry)
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a conic section.

Let P and Q be points in the plane of ğ’¦.

Let:
:P lie on the polar of Q
:Q lie on the polar of P.


P and Q are known as conjugate points   ğ’¦.


=== Conjugate Points with respect to Circle ===
Let ğ’ be a circle.

Let P and Q be points in the plane of ğ’.

Let:
:P lie on the polar of Q
:Q lie on the polar of P.


P and Q are known as conjugate points with respect to ğ’.

title: Definition:Conjugate Lines
definition:
Let ğ’ be a circle.

Let ğ’« and ğ’¬ be the straight lines in the plane of ğ’.


Let P and Q be the poles of ğ’« and ğ’¬ with respect to ğ’ respectively.

Let P and Q be such that P lies on ğ’¬ and Q lies on ğ’«.

Then ğ’« and ğ’¬ are known as conjugate lines with respect to ğ’.

title: Definition:Conjugate Diameters
definition:
Let K be a conic section.

Let D_1 and D_2 be diameters of K such that:
:D_1 belongs to the system of parallel chords whose midpoints define D_2
and:
:D_2 belongs to the system of parallel chords whose midpoints define D_1.

Then D_1 and D_2 are known as conjugate diameters.

title: Definition:Conjugation on Algebra/Conjugate
definition:
Let A = ( A_F, âŠ•) be an algebra over a field F.

Let C: A_F â†’ A_F be a conjugation on A.

Let a âˆˆ A.


Then C (   )a is called the conjugate of a.

title: Definition:Connected Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation on a set S.


Then â„› is connected  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a  b ( a, b ) âˆˆâ„›( b, a ) âˆˆâ„›


That is,  if and only if  every pair of distinct elements is comparable.

title: Definition:Connected (Topology)/Topological Space
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a non-empty topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is connected  if and only if  it admits no separation.


That is, T is connected  if and only if  there exist no open sets A, B âˆˆÏ„ such that A, B âˆ…, A âˆª B = S and A âˆ© B = âˆ….

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is connected  if and only if  it has no two disjoint nonempty closed sets whose union is S.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is connected  if and only if  its only subsets whose boundary is empty are S and âˆ….

=== Definition 4 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is connected  if and only if  its only clopen sets are S and âˆ….

=== Definition 5 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a non-empty topological space.


T is connected  if and only if  there are no two non-empty separated sets whose union is S.

=== Definition 6 ===

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is connected  if and only if  there exists no continuous surjection from T onto a discrete two-point space.

=== Definition 7 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is connected  if and only if :
:there do not exist disjoint, non-empty open sets X and Y of T such that X âˆª Y = S.

title: Definition:Connected (Topology)/Set
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


=== Definition 1 ===

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


H is a connected set of T  if and only if  it is not the union of any two non-empty separated sets of T.


=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


H is a connected set of T  if and only if  it is not disconnected in T.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


H is a connected set of T  if and only if :
:the topological subspace ( H, Ï„_H ) of T is a connected topological space.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


H is a connected set of T  if and only if :
:there do not exist disjoint, non-empty subsets X and Y of H such that X âˆª Y = H such that:
::no limit point of X is an element of Y
::no limit point of Y is an element of X.

=== Definition 5 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


H is a connected set of T  if and only if :
:H cannot be partitioned into 2 non-empty subsets so that each subset has no element in common with the closure of the other.

title: Definition:Connected (Topology)/Points
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let a, b âˆˆ S.


Then a and b are connected (in T)  if and only if  there exists a connected set in T containing both a and b.

title: Definition:Connected Sum
definition:
The connected sum of two manifolds A^n, B^n of dimension n is defined as follows:

Let D^n be a closed n-ball.

Let Î±:  D^n â†’ A^n be a continuous (or, in the case of smooth manifolds, a smooth) injection.

Let Î²:  D^n â†’ B^n be a similar function.  


Define the set:
:S = ( A^n âˆ–Î±(   )(  D^n )^âˆ˜) âˆª( B^n âˆ–Î²(   )(  D^n )^âˆ˜)
where:
:âˆ– denotes set difference
:(  D^n )^âˆ˜ denotes the interior of D^n.


Define an equivalence relation âˆ¼ on S as:
:x âˆ¼ y ( ( x = y ) ( Î±^-1(   )x = Î²^-1(   )y )  )


Since the interiors of the closed balls were removed from the manifolds, it necessarily follows that:
:Î±^-1(   )x, Î²^-1(   )y âˆˆâˆ‚ D^n


The connected sum A^n # B^n is defined as the quotient space of S under âˆ¼.

Category:Definitions/Topology

title: Definition:Connected Set (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let D âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the set of complex numbers.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let D âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the set of complex numbers.


D is connected  if and only if  every pair of points in D can be joined by a staircase contour.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let D âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the set of complex numbers.


D is connected  if and only if  every pair of points in D can be joined by a polygonal path all points of which are in D.

title: Definition:Connected (Graph Theory)/Graph
definition:
Let G be a graph.

Then G is a connected graph  if and only if  every pair of vertices in G is a pair of connected vertices.


=== Disconnected ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Then G is a disconnected graph  if and only if  it is not a connected graph.

That is,  if and only if  there exists (at least) two vertices u, v âˆˆ V such that u and v are not connected vertices.

title: Definition:Connected (Graph Theory)/Vertices
definition:
Let G be a graph.

Two vertices u, v âˆˆ G are connected  if and only if  either:

:(1):    u = v
:(2):    u  v, and there exists a walk between them.

title: Definition:Provable Consequence
definition:
Let ğ’« be a proof system for a formal language â„’.

Let â„± be a collection of WFFs of â„’.


Denote with ğ’«(   )â„± the proof system obtained from ğ’« by adding all the WFFs from â„± as axioms.

Let Ï• be a theorem of ğ’«(   )â„±.


Then Ï• is called a provable consequence of â„±, and this is denoted as:

:â„±âŠ¢_ğ’«Ï•


Note in particular that for â„± = âˆ…, this notation agrees with the notation for a ğ’«-theorem:

:âŠ¢_ğ’«Ï•

definition:
Let â„³ be a formal semantics for a formal language â„’.

Let â„± be a collection of WFFs of â„’.


Let â„³(   )â„± be the formal semantics obtained from â„³ by retaining only the structures of â„³ that are models of â„±.

Let Ï• be a tautology for â„³(   )â„±.


Then Ï• is called a semantic consequence of â„±, and this is denoted as:

:â„±_â„³Ï•


That is to say, Ï• is a semantic consequence of â„±  if and only if , for each â„³-structure â„³:

:â„³_â„³â„± implies â„³_â„³Ï•

where _â„³ is the models relation.


Note in particular that for â„± = âˆ…, the notation agrees with the notation for a â„³-tautology:

:_â„³Ï•


The concept naturally generalises to sets of formulas ğ’¢ on the  :

:â„±_â„³ğ’¢

 if and only if  â„±_â„³Ï• for every Ï•âˆˆğ’¢.

title: Definition:Consequence (Game Theory)
definition: A consequence is a state in a game which results from a move made by a player in that game made according to the rules.

title: Definition:Consequence Function
definition:
Let G be a game.

Let P be a player of G.

Let A be the set of moves available to P.

Let C be the set of consequences of those moves.


A consequence function for P is a mapping from the set A to the set C:
:g: A â†’ C

title: Definition:Consistent (Logic)
definition:
Let â„’ be a logical language.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’.


=== Proof System ===
Let â„’ be a logical language.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’.


Then ğ’« is consistent  if and only if :

:There exists a logical formula Ï• such that âŠ¬_ğ’«Ï•

That is, some logical formula Ï• is not a theorem of ğ’«.


=== Propositional Logic ===
Let â„’_0 be the language of propositional logic.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’_0.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„’_0 be the language of propositional logic.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’_0.


Then ğ’« is consistent  if and only if :

:There exists a logical formula Ï• such that âŠ¬_ğ’«Ï•

That is, some logical formula Ï• is not a theorem of ğ’«.


Category:Definitions/Proof Systems
Category:Definitions/Propositional Logic

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„’ be the language of propositional logic.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’_0.

Suppose that in ğ’«, the Rule of Explosion (Variant 3) holds.


Then ğ’« is consistent  if and only if :

:For every logical formula Ï•, not both of Ï• and Ï• are theorems of ğ’«

=== Set of Formulas ===
Let â„’ be a logical language.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’.

Let â„± be a collection of logical formulas.


Then â„± is consistent for ğ’«  if and only if :

:There exists a logical formula Ï• such that â„±âŠ¬_ğ’«Ï•.

That is, some logical formula Ï• is not a provable consequence of â„±.


=== Propositional Logic ===
 
Let â„’_0 be the language of propositional logic.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’_0.

Let â„± be a collection of logical formulas.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„’_0 be the language of propositional logic.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’_0.

Let â„± be a collection of logical formulas.


Then â„± is consistent for ğ’«  if and only if :

:There exists a logical formula Ï• such that â„±âŠ¬_ğ’«Ï•

That is, some logical formula Ï• is not a ğ’«-provable consequence of â„±.


Category:Definitions/Proof Systems
Category:Definitions/Propositional Logic

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„’ be the language of propositional logic.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’_0.

Let â„± be a collection of logical formulas.

Suppose that in ğ’«, the Rule of Explosion (Variant 3) holds.


Then â„± is consistent for ğ’«  if and only if :

:For every logical formula Ï•, not both of Ï• and Ï• are ğ’«-provable consequences of â„±

title: Definition:Consistent Simultaneous Equations
definition:
A system of simultaneous equations is referred to as consistent  if and only if  it has at least one solution.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a set of values for its variables such that all the equations are satisfied.


=== Inconsistent ===
A set of equations is described as inconsistent  if and only if  they are not consistent

That is, there exists no set of values for its variables such that all the equations are satisfied.

title: Definition:Consistent Estimator
definition:
Let X_1, X_2, â€¦, X_n be random variables.

Let the joint distribution of X_1, X_2, â€¦, X_n be indexed by a population parameter Î¸.

Let Î¸Ì‚ be an estimator of Î¸.

Then Î¸Ì‚ is consistent  if and only if :
:lim_n â†’âˆ(   )|Î¸Ì‚- Î¸|â‰¥Ïµ = 0
for all Ïµ > 0.

title: Definition:Content of Polynomial/Integer
definition:
Let f âˆˆâ„¤[ X ] be a polynomial with integer coefficients.

Then the content of f, denoted cont( f ), is the greatest common divisor of the coefficients of f.

title: Definition:Content of Polynomial/Rational
definition:
Let f âˆˆâ„š[ X ] be a polynomial with rational coefficients.


The content of f is defined as:
:cont( f ) := cont( n f )  n
where n âˆˆâ„• is such that n f âˆˆâ„¤[ X ].

title: Definition:Continuous Mapping
definition:
The concept of continuity makes precise the intuitive notion that a function has no "jumps" at a given point.

Loosely speaking, in the case of a real function, continuity at a point is defined as the property that the graph of the function does not have a "break" at the point.

Thus, a small change in the independent variable causes a similar small change in the dependent variable

This concept appears throughout mathematics and correspondingly has many variations and generalizations.

title: Definition:Continuous Lattice Subframe
definition:
Let L = (X, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let S = (Y, â‰¼') be an ordered subset of L.


Then S is continuous lattice subframe of L  if and only if 
:S inherits infima and directed suprema.

title: Definition:Sample Statistic/Continuous
definition: Data which can be described with a continuous variable obtained by the process of measurement are known as continuous data.

title: Definition:Continuous Real Function
definition:
=== Informal Definition ===
The concept of continuity makes precise the intuitive notion that a function has no "jumps" or "holes" at a given point.

Loosely speaking, a real function f is continuous at a point p  if and only if  the graph of f does not have a "break" at p.

=== Continuity at a Point ===
Let A âŠ†â„ be a subset of the real numbers.

Let f: A â†’â„ be a real function.

Let x âˆˆ A be a point of A.


f is continuous at x  if and only if  the limit lim_y â†’ x f (   )y exists and:
:lim_y â†’ x f (   )y = f (   )x

=== Continuous Everywhere ===
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function.


Then f is everywhere continuous  if and only if  f is continuous at every point in â„.

=== Continuity on a Subset of Domain ===
Let A âŠ†â„ be any subset of the real numbers.

Let f: A â†’â„ be a real function.


Then f is continuous on A  if and only if  f is continuous at every point of A.

title: Definition:Continuous Real Function/Left-Continuous
definition:
Let A âŠ†â„ be an open subset of the real numbers â„.

Let f: A â†’â„ be a real function.


Let x_0 âˆˆ A. 

Then f is said to be left-continuous at x_0  if and only if  the limit from the left of f (   )x as x â†’ x_0 exists and:

:lim_x â†’ x_0^- 
 x_0 âˆˆ A f (   )x = f (   )x_0

where lim_x â†’ x_0^- is a limit from the left.


Furthermore, f is said to be left-continuous  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_0 âˆˆ A, f is left-continuous at x_0

title: Definition:Continuous Real Function/Right-Continuous
definition:
Let S âŠ†â„ be an open subset of the real numbers â„.

Let f: S â†’â„ be a real function.


Let x_0 âˆˆ S. 

Then f is said to be right-continuous at x_0  if and only if  the limit from the right of f (   )x as x â†’ x_0 exists and:

:lim_x â†’ x_0^+ 
 x_0 âˆˆ A f (   )x = f (   )x_0

where lim_x â†’ x_0^+ is a limit from the right.


Furthermore, f is said to be right-continuous  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_0 âˆˆ S, f is right-continuous at x_0

title: Definition:Convex Geometric Figure
definition:
A geometric figure is convex  if and only if  a line segment joining two points on its boundary lies entirely inside it.


=== Convex Polygon ===
Let P be a polygon.

P is a convex polygon  if and only if :
:For all points A and B located inside P, the line AB is also inside P.

=== Convex Polyhedron ===
Let P be a polyhedron.


P is a convex polyhedron  if and only if :
:For all points A and B located inside P, the line AB is also inside P.

title: Definition:Convex Polygon
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let P be a polygon.

P is a convex polygon  if and only if :
:For all points A and B located inside P, the line AB is also inside P.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let P be a polygon.

P is a convex polygon  if and only if :
:every internal angle of P is not greater than 180 ^âˆ˜.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let P be a polygon.

P is a convex polygon  if and only if :
:the region enclosed by P lies entirely on the same side of each side of P


 

=== Definition 4 ===
Let P be a polygon.

P is a convex polygon  if and only if :
:the region enclosed by P is the intersection of a finite number of half-planes.


Note that an intersection of a finite number of half-planes is not necessarily a polygon.

 

=== Definition 5 ===
Let P be a polygon.

P is a convex polygon  if and only if :
:the region enclosed by P is the intersection of all half-planes that contain P and that are created by all the lines that are tangent to P.


By tangent we mean any line l that contain one or more point of P and has P entirely in one of the half-planes created by l. 

In this sense any line, that is spanned by a side of P, is tangent to P.

title: Definition:Convex Polyhedron
definition:
Let P be a polyhedron.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let P be a polyhedron.


P is a convex polyhedron  if and only if :
:For all points A and B located inside P, the line AB is also inside P.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let P be a polyhedron.


P is a convex polyhedron  if and only if :
:For every face of P, the plane in which it is embedded does not intersect the interior of P.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let P be a polyhedron.


P is a convex polyhedron  if and only if :
:For each face of P, the whole of P lies on one side of the plane of that face.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let P be a polyhedron.


P is a convex polyhedron  if and only if :
:For each face of P, the plane containing that face does not intersect any other face of P.

title: Definition:Convex Set (Order Theory)
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A subset A of an ordered set ( S, â‰¼) is convex (in S)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ A: âˆ€ z âˆˆ S: x â‰¼ z â‰¼ y  z âˆˆ A

=== Definition 2 ===
A subset A of an ordered set ( S, â‰¼) is convex (in S)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ A: âˆ€ z âˆˆ S: x â‰º z â‰º y  z âˆˆ A

title: Definition:Convex Set (Vector Space)
definition:
Let F âˆˆ{â„, â„‚}.

Let C âŠ† V.

for each t âˆˆ[ 0  . . ]1, where t C + ( 1 - t ) C denotes a linear combination of subsets.


=== Line Segment ===
Let V be a vector space over â„ or â„‚.

Let x, y âˆˆ V.


The set:

:{ t x + ( 1 - t ) y: t âˆˆ[ 0  . . ]1 } 

is called the (straight) line segment joining x and y.


A convex set can thus be described as a set containing all straight line segments between its elements.

definition:

:


The geometric interpretation is that any point on the chord drawn on the graph of any convex function always lies on or above the graph.


=== Strictly Convex ===
Let f be a real function which is defined on a real interval I.


f is strictly convex on I  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ I, x  y: âˆ€Î±, Î²âˆˆâ„_>0, Î± + Î² = 1: f (   )Î± x + Î² y < Î± f (   )x + Î² f (   )y


:


The geometric interpretation is that any point on the chord drawn on the graph of any convex function always lies above the graph.

=== Definition 2 ===

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2, x_3 âˆˆ I: x_1 < x_2 < x_3: f (   )x_2 - f (   )x_1x_2 - x_1â‰¤f (   )x_3 - f (   )x_2x_3 - x_2

f is strictly convex on I  if and only if :

title: Definition:Convolution Integral
definition:
Let f and g be real functions which are integrable.

The convolution integral of f and g is defined as:
:f (   )t * g (   )t := âˆ«_-âˆ^âˆ f (   )u g (   )t - u d u


=== Positive Real Domain ===

definition:

definition:

The Dirichlet convolution of f and g is the arithmetic function:
:( f * g )  (   )n = âˆ‘_d \ n f (   )d g (   )n/d
where the summation runs over the set of positive divisors d of n.

=== Definition 2 ===

:( f * g )  (   )n = âˆ‘_a b  = n f (   )a g (   )b
where the summation runs over all pairs of positive integers ( a, b ) with a b = n.

definition:
Let ( M, Â·) be a divisor-finite monoid.

title: Definition:Coterminal Angles
definition:
Coterminal angles are angles which are rotations between the same 2 lines.

That is, they are angles with the same arms.

title: Definition:Polygon/Adjacent/Sides
definition: Two sides of a polygon that meet at the same vertex are adjacent to each other.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Adjacent/Edge to Edge
definition: Two edges of a polyhedron that intersect at a particular vertex are referred to as adjacent to each other.

title: Definition:Adjacent (Graph Theory)/Edges
definition:
=== Undirected Graph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be an undirected graph.

Two edges e_1, e_2 âˆˆ E of G adjacent  if and only if  there exists a vertex v âˆˆ V to which they are both incident.


Otherwise they are non-adjacent.

=== Digraph ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Two arcs e_1, e_2 âˆˆ E of G adjacent  if and only if  there exists a vertex v âˆˆ V to which they are both incident.


Otherwise they are non-adjacent.

=== Non-Adjacent ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Two edges u, v âˆˆ V of G are non-adjacent  if and only if  they are not adjacent.

title: Definition:Couple (Mechanics)
definition:
A couple, in the context of mechanics, is a system of 2 forces that are:
:equal in magnitude
:exactly opposite in direction
:with different lines of action.

title: Definition:Tusi Couple
definition:
A Tusi couple is a hypocycloid with 2 cusps.


:

title: Definition:Critical Point (Topology)
definition:
Let f: X â†’ Y be a smooth map of manifolds.


A point x âˆˆ X is called a critical point of f  if and only if  d f_x: T_x [ X ] â†’ T_y [ Y ] is not surjective at x.

 

Category:Definitions/Topology

title: Definition:Critical Point/Smooth Manifold
definition:
Let M be a smooth manifold.

Let f âˆˆğ’^âˆ(   )M : M â†’â„ be a smooth real-valued function.

Let p âˆˆ M be a base point in M.

Let d f_p be the differential of f at p.

Suppose d f_p = 0.


Then p is called a critical point of f.

title: Definition:Critical Point of Riemannian Length
definition:
Let ( M, g ) be a Riemannian manifold.

Let I = [ a  . . ]b be a closed real interval.

Let J âŠ†â„ be an open real interval.

Let Î³ : I â†’ M be an admissible curve.

Let L_g be the Riemannian length of some admissible curve.

Let Î“ : J Ã— I â†’ M be the proper variation of Î³ such that:

:âˆ€ s âˆˆ J, âˆ€ t âˆˆ I : ( s, t ) Î“â†¦Î“_s (   )t

Suppose:

:âˆ€Î“ :  d d s L_g (   )Î“_s = 0


Then Î³ is called the critical point of L_g.

title: Definition:Critical Point (Analysis)
definition:
A critical point is a point on a graph where the curve has a vertical tangent.

That is, where limit of the derivative tends to infinity.

title: Definition:Cut (Analysis)
definition:
Let Î±âŠ‚â„š be a subset of the set of rational numbers â„š which has the following properties:

:(1):   Î±âˆ… and Î±â„š, that is: Î± contains at least one rational number but not all rational numbers

:(2): If p âˆˆÎ± and q âˆˆâ„š such that q < p, then q âˆˆÎ±

:(3):   Î± does not contain a greatest element.


Then Î± is called a cut.


=== Lower Number ===
Let Î± be a cut.

Let p âˆˆÎ±.


Then p is referred to as a lower number of Î±.

=== Upper Number ===
Let Î± be a cut.

Let q âˆˆâ„š such that q âˆ‰Î±.


Then p is referred to as an upper number of Î±.

=== Rational Cut ===
Let r âˆˆâ„š be a rational number.

Let Î± be the cut consisting of all rational numbers p such that p < r.


Then Î± is referred to as a rational cut.


To express the fact that Î± is a rational cut, the notation Î± = r^* can be used.

title: Definition:Dedekind Cut
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.


A Dedekind cut of ( S, â‰¼) is a non-empty proper subset L âŠŠ S such that:
:(1):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆ€ y âˆˆ S: y â‰º x  y âˆˆ L (L is a lower section in S)
:(2):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆƒ y âˆˆ L: x â‰º y

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.


A Dedekind cut of ( S, â‰¼) is an ordered pair ( L, R ) such that:
:(1):   { L, R } is a partition of S.
:(2):    L does not have a greatest element.
:(3):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆ€ y âˆˆ R: x â‰º y.

title: Definition:Cut-Vertex
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a connected graph.

Let v be a vertex of G.


Then v is a cut-vertex of G  if and only if  the vertex deletion G - v is a vertex cut of G.

That is, such that G - v is disconnected.


Thus, a cut-vertex of G is a singleton vertex cut of G.

title: Definition:Cut Point
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a connected set in T and let p âˆˆ H.

Let p âˆˆ H such that H âˆ–{ p } is disconnected, where âˆ– denotes set difference.


Then p is a cut point of H.

title: Definition:Vertex Cut
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.


A vertex cut of G is a set of vertices W âŠ† V (   )G such that the vertex deletion G âˆ– W is disconnected.

title: Definition:Edge Cut
definition:
Let G be a graph.


An edge cut of G is a set of edges W âŠ† E (   )G such that the edge deletion G âˆ– W is disconnected.

title: Definition:Permutation on n Letters/Cycle Notation
definition:
Let â„•_k be used to denote the initial segment of natural numbers:
:â„•_k = [ 1  . . ]k = { 1, 2, 3, â€¦, k }

Let Ï: â„•_n â†’â„•_n be a permutation of n letters.


The k-cycle Ï is denoted:
:[             i       Ï(   )i             â€¦ Ï^k - 1(   )i ]


From Existence and Uniqueness of Cycle Decomposition, all permutations can be defined as the product of disjoint cycles.

As Disjoint Permutations Commute, the order in which they are performed does not matter.


So, for a given permutation Ï, the cycle notation for Ï consists of all the disjoint cycles into which Ï can be decomposed, concatenated as a product.

It is conventional to omit 1-cycles from the expression, and to write those cycles with lowest starting number first.


=== Canonical Representation ===
The permutation:

:[ 1 2 3 4 5; 2 1 4 3 5 ]

can be expressed in cycle notation as:

:[ 1 2 ][ 3 4 ]

or as:

:[ 3 4 ][ 5 ][ 1 2 ]

or as:

:[ 4 3 ][ 2 1 ]

etc.

However, only the first is conventional.

This is known as the canonical representation.

title: Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)
definition:
A cycle is a circuit in which no vertex except the first (which is also the last) appears more than once.


An n-cycle is a cycle with n vertices.


=== Subgraph ===
The set of vertices and edges which go to make up a cycle form a subgraph.

This subgraph itself is also referred to as a cycle.

=== Odd Cycle ===
An odd cycle is a cycle with odd length, that is, with an odd number of edges.

=== Even Cycle ===
An even cycle is a cycle with even length, that is, with an even number of edges.

title: Definition:Cycle (Periodic Solution)
definition:
A cycle, or periodic solution, is a solution of a differential equation which is a periodic function.

Category:Definitions/Differential Equations

title: Definition:Periodic Continued Fraction/Cycle
definition:
The repeating block in a periodic (or purely periodic) continued fraction F is called the cycle of F.


=== Cycle Length ===
The number of partial denominators in a cycle of a periodic continued fraction is called the cycle length.

title: Definition:Cyclic Group
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
The group G is cyclic  if and only if  every element of G can be expressed as the power of one element of G:
:âˆƒ g âˆˆ G: âˆ€ h âˆˆ G: h = g^n
for some n âˆˆâ„¤.

=== Definition 2 ===
The group G is cyclic  if and only if  it is generated by one element g âˆˆ G:
:G = âŸ¨ g âŸ©

title: Definition:Cyclic Polygon
definition: A cyclic polygon is a polygon P which can be inscribed in a circle.

title: Definition:Cyclic Quadrilateral
definition:
A cyclic quadrilateral is a quadrilateral which can be circumscribed:

:


This is an example of a quadrilateral which cannot be circumscribed, and so therefore is not cyclic:

:

title: Definition:Degenerate Case
definition: A degenerate case is a specific manifestation of a particular type of object being included in another, usually simpler, type of object.

title: Definition:Point-Circle
definition:
A point-circle is the locus in the Cartesian plane of an equation of the form:

:(1):   ( x - a )^2 + ( y - b )^2 = 0

where a and b are real constants.


There is only one point in the Cartesian plane which satisfies (1), and that is the point ( a, b ).

It can be considered to be a circle whose radius is equal to zero.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Intersection with Cone/Degenerate Hyperbola

Let Ï• be the inclination of D to the axis of C.

title: Definition:Degenerate Parabola
definition:
A degenerate parabola is the conic section whose slicing plane passes through the apex of the cone and is thus tangent to the cone

Hence it consists of a single straight line.

title: Definition:Degenerate Bilinear Form
definition:
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Then b is degenerate   there exists v âˆˆ Vâˆ–{ 0 } such that b (   )v, u = 0 for all u âˆˆ V.


=== Nondegenerate Bilinear Form ===
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.


A bilinear form on V which is not degenerate is nondegenerate.

definition:

definition:

=== Infinite ===

title: Definition:Everywhere Dense
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a subset.


The subset H is (everywhere) dense in T  if and only if :
:H^- = S
where H^- is the closure of H.


That is,  if and only if  every point in S is a point or a limit point of H.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a subset.


The subset H is (everywhere) dense in T  if and only if  the intersection of H with every non-empty open set of T is non-empty:
:âˆ€ U âˆˆÏ„âˆ–{âˆ…}: H âˆ© U âˆ…

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a subset.


The subset H is (everywhere) dense in T  if and only if  every neighborhood of every point of S contains at least one point of H.

title: Definition:Dense-in-itself
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


Then H is dense-in-itself  if and only if  it contains no isolated points.

title: Definition:Nowhere Dense
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if :
:( H^- )^âˆ˜ = âˆ…
where H^- denotes the closure of H and H^âˆ˜ denotes its interior.


That is, H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if  the interior of its closure is empty.

Another way of putting it is that H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if  it consists entirely of boundary.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if :
:H^- contains no open set of T which is non-empty
where H^- denotes the closure of H.

title: Definition:Densely Ordered
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.


Then ( S, â‰¼) is defined as densely ordered  if and only if  strictly between every two elements of S there exists another element of S:

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a â‰º b âˆƒ c âˆˆ S: a â‰º c â‰º b

A subset T âŠ† S is said to be densely ordered in ( S, â‰¼)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a â‰º b âˆƒ c âˆˆ T: a â‰º c â‰º b

title: Definition:Dense (Lattice Theory)
definition:
Let L = ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded below meet semilattice.

=== Dense Element ===
Let L = ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded below meet semilattice.

Let x âˆˆ S.


Then x is dense  if and only if 
:âˆ€ y âˆˆ S: y  x âˆ§ y

where  denotes the smallest element in L.

=== Dense Subset ===
Let L = ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded below meet semilattice.

Let A be a subset of S.


Then A is dense  if and only if  it includes only dense elements.

That means that  if and only if  âˆ€ x âˆˆ A: x is a dense element.

Category:Definitions/Lattice Theory

title: Definition:Mass Density
definition:
Mass density is a physical quantity.

The mass density of a body is its mass per unit volume.

Mass density is a scalar quantity.


For a homogeneous body it is found by finding its total mass and dividing it by its total volume:
:Ï =  m V
where:
:m is the body's mass
:V is the body's volume

However, if the substance of the body varies throughout, then its mass density may be a function of position within the body.


=== Symbol ===


=== Dimension ===
The dimension of (mass) density is ğ–¬ ğ–«^-3: mass per unit volume.


Category:Definitions/Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement

=== Units ===
* The SI units of mass density are kg m^-3 (kilograms per cubic metre).

* The CGS units of mass density are g cm^-3 or, less formally: g / cc (grams per cubic centimetre).

* The FPS units of mass density are lb ft^-3 (pounds per cubic foot).


=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Mass Density/Area
definition:
The area mass density of a two-dimensional body is its mass per unit area.


=== Symbol ===
The usual symbol used to denote area mass density is Ï_A (Greek letter rho).

However, some sources simply use Ï if the context makes it clear that it refers to area mass density rather than volume mass density.

Occasionally, Ïƒ (Greek letter sigma) is also used, but this is more commonly used for surface charge density.


Category:Definitions/Area Mass Density

=== Dimension ===
The dimension of area mass density is ğ–¬ğ–«^-2: mass per unit area.


Category:Definitions/Area Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement

=== Units ===
* The SI units of area mass density are kg m^-2 (kilograms per square metre).

* The CGS units of area mass density are g cm^-2 (grams per square centimetre).

Thus:
:1  g cm^-2 = 10  kg m^-2


Category:Definitions/Area Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Units of Measurement

title: Definition:Mass Density/Linear
definition:
The linear mass density of a one-dimensional body is its mass per unit length.


=== Symbol ===
The usual symbol used to denote linear mass density is Î¼ (Greek letter mu).

Sometimes Î» (Greek letter lambda) is also used.


Category:Definitions/Linear Mass Density

=== Dimension ===
The dimension of linear mass density is ğ–¬ğ–«^-1: mass per unit length.


Category:Definitions/Linear Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement

=== Units ===
* The SI units of linear mass density are kg m^-1 (kilograms per metre).

* The CGS units of linear mass density are g cm^-1 (grams per centimetre).

Thus:
:1  kg m^-1 = 10  g cm^-1


Category:Definitions/Linear Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Units of Measurement

title: Definition:Diagonal of Polyhedron
definition: A diagonal of a polyhedron P is a straight line connecting 2 vertices of P which are not adjacent to the same face.

definition:

:Î”_S = {( x, x ): x âˆˆ S }âŠ† S Ã— S

:Î”_S = {( x, y ): x, y âˆˆ S: x = y }

:Î”_V = {( x, x ): x âˆˆ V }

definition:
Let S be a set.

Let S Ã— S be the Cartesian product of S with itself.


Then the diagonal mapping on S is defined as Î”: S â†’ S Ã— S:

Clearly Î” is an injection, and is not a surjection unless S is a singleton.

title: Definition:Main Diagonal/Diagonal Elements
definition: The elements of the main diagonal of a matrix or a determinant are called the diagonal elements.

definition:
Let ğ€ = [ a_11 a_12    â‹¯ a_1n; a_21 a_22    â‹¯ a_2n;    â‹®    â‹®    â‹±    â‹®; a_n1 a_n2    â‹¯ a_nn;      ] be a square matrix of order n.

Then ğ€ is a diagonal matrix  if and only if  all elements of ğ€ are zero except for possibly its diagonal elements.


Thus ğ€ = [ a_11    0    â‹¯    0;    0 a_22    â‹¯    0;    â‹®    â‹®    â‹±    â‹®;    0    0    â‹¯ a_nn;      ].


It follows by the definition of triangular matrix that a diagonal matrix is both an upper triangular matrix and a lower triangular matrix.

definition:
A diagonalizable matrix ğ€ is a square matrix which is similar to a diagonal matrix.

That is, ğ€ is diagonalizable  if and only if  there exists a nonsingular matrix ğ— such that ğ—^-1ğ€ğ— is a diagonal matrix.

title: Definition:Diagram (Graphical Technique)
definition:
A diagram is a graphical technique for illustrating a concept in picture form.

It is generally considered that its use should be limited to that of an aid to understanding, and should not be used in order to prove something.

title: Definition:Diagram (Category Theory)

=== Index Category ===

In this context, ğ‰ is referred to as the index category.

Similarly, for Î±: i â†’ j a morphism one writes D_Î± in place of D (Î±).

title: Definition:Sphere/Geometry/Diameter
definition:
By the definition of a sphere, there is one point inside it such that the distance between that point and any given point on the surface of the sphere are equal, and that point is called the center of the sphere.


The diameter of a sphere is the length of any straight line drawn from a point on the surface to another point on the surface through the center.

:A diameter of the sphere is any straight line drawn through the centre and terminated in both directions by the surface of the sphere.

title: Definition:Geometric Figure/Diameter
definition: The diameter of a geometric figure is the greatest length that can be formed between two opposite parallel straight lines that can be drawn tangent to its boundary.

title: Definition:Diameter of Subset of Metric Space
definition:
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let S âŠ† A be subset of A.

 + âˆ    : otherwise


Thus, by the definition of the supremum, the diameter is the smallest real number D such that any two points of S are at most a distance D apart.

If d: S^2 â†’â„ does not admit a supremum, then diam(   )S is infinite.

title: Definition:Dimension (Geometry)
definition: The dimension of a (geometrical) space is the minimum number of coordinates needed to specify a point in it.

title: Definition:Dimension (Linear Algebra)
definition:
=== Module ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let G be a unitary R-module which has a basis of n elements.

Then G is said to have a dimension of n or to be n-dimensional.


=== Symbol ===


=== Finite Dimensional Module ===
Let G be a (unitary) module which is n-dimensional for some n âˆˆâ„•_>0.

Then G is finite dimensional.

=== Vector Space ===

Let K be a division ring.

Let V be a vector space over K.

Let K be a division ring.

Let V be a vector space over K.


The dimension of V is the cardinality of an arbitrary basis for V.

title: Definition:Matrix/Order
definition:

=== Square Matrix ===
Let ğ€ be an n Ã— n square matrix.

That is, let ğ€ have n rows (and by definition n columns).


Then the order of ğ€ is defined as being n.

=== Column Matrix ===
Let ğ€ be an n Ã— 1 column matrix.

Then the order of ğ€ is defined as being n.


Category:Definitions/Orders of Matrices

Then the order of ğ€ is defined as being n.

title: Definition:Digraph
definition:
A digraph is a graph each of whose edges has a direction:



In the above digraph, the vertices are v_1, v_2, v_3 and v_4.


=== Arc ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

The arcs are the elements of E.

Informally, an arc is a line that joins one vertex to another.


If e âˆˆ E is an arc joining the vertex u to the vertex v, it is denoted u v.


=== Endvertex ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let e = u v be an arc of D, that is, e âˆˆ E.


The endvertices of e are the vertices u and v.


=== Initial Vertex ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let e = u v be an arc of D, that is, e âˆˆ E.


The initial vertex of e is the endvertex u which e is incident from.

=== Final Vertex ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let e = u v be an arc of D, that is, e âˆˆ E.


The final vertex of e is the endvertex v which e is incident to.

In the above graph, the arcs are v_1 v_2, v_2 v_4, v_4 v_3, v_4 v_1 and v_1 v_4.


As can be seen, in this general definition it is allowable for an arc to go in both directions between a given pair of vertices.


=== Formal Definition ===



A directed graph or digraph D is a non-empty set V together with an antireflexive relation E on V.

The elements of E are the arcs.


Thus the above digraph can be defined as:

:D = ( V, E ):
::V = { v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4 }
::E = {( v_1, v_2 ), ( v_2, v_4 ), ( v_4, v_3 ), ( v_4, v_1 ), ( v_1, v_4 )  }

=== Category-Theoretic Definition ===
Let ğ’ğğ­ be the category of sets.

A digraph is an arrangement of the following form in ğ’ğğ­:

::<0em,0em>*E = "E",
<5em,0em>*V = "V",

"E"+/^.3em/+/r1em/;"V"+/^.3em/+/l1em/ **@- ?>*@> ?*!/_.6em/s,
"E"+/_.3em/+/r1em/;"V"+/_.3em/+/l1em/ **@- ?>*@> ?*!/^.6em/t,

=== Symmetric Digraph ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph such that the relation E in D is symmetric.

Then D is called a symmetric digraph.


It follows from the definition of a (simple) graph that a symmetric digraph is in fact the same thing as an undirected graph.

=== Simple Digraph ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

If the relation E in D is also specifically asymmetric, then D is called a simple digraph.

That is, in a simple digraph there are no pairs of arcs (like there are between v_1 and v_4 in the diagram above) which go in both directions between two vertices.

title: Definition:Directed Preordering
definition:

Then H is a directed subset of S  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ H: âˆƒ z âˆˆ H: x â‰¾ z and y â‰¾ z

title: Definition:Directed Smooth Curve
definition:

The directed smooth curve with parameterization Ï is defined as an equivalence class of smooth paths as follows:

A smooth path Ïƒ: [a  . .  b] â†’â„^n belongs to the equivalence class of Ï  if and only if :

:: Ï•: [c  . .  d] â†’[a  . .  b]
: such that Ïƒ = Ïâˆ˜Ï•.


It follows from Directed Smooth Curve Relation is Equivalence and Fundamental Theorem on Equivalence Relations that this does in fact define an equivalence class.


If a directed smooth curve is only defined by a smooth path Ï, then it is often denoted with the same symbol Ï.


=== Parameterization ===
Let â„^n be a real cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let C be a directed smooth curve in â„^n.

Let Ï: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„‚ be a smooth path in â„^n.


Then Ï is a parameterization of C  if and only if  Ï is an element of the equivalence class that constitutes C.


=== Complex Plane ===

The definition carries over to the complex plane, in which context it is usually applied:

Let C be a directed smooth curve in the complex plane â„‚.

Let Î³: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„‚ be a smooth path in â„‚.


Then Î³ is a parameterization of C  if and only if  Î³ is a representative of the equivalence class that constitutes C.


=== Reparameterization ===
Let Î³ : [ a  . . ]b â†’â„‚ be a smooth path in â„‚.

Let C be a directed smooth curve in the complex plane â„‚ parameterized by Î³.

Let Ï•: [ c  . . ]d â†’[ a  . . ]b be a bijective differentiable strictly increasing real function.

Let Ïƒ : [ c  . . ]d â†’â„‚ be defined by:

:Ïƒ = Î³âˆ˜Ï• 


Then Ïƒ is called a reparameterization of C.

=== Endpoints ===
Let â„^n be a real cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let C be a directed smooth curve in â„^n.


Let C be parameterized by a smooth path Ï: [a  . .  b] â†’â„‚.


Then:
: Ï(a) is the start point of C

: Ï(b) is the end point of C.


Collectively, Ï(a) and Ï(b) are known as the endpoints of Ï.


=== Complex Plane ===

The definition carries over to the complex plane, in which context it is usually applied:

Let C be a directed smooth curve in the complex plane â„‚.

Let C be parameterized by a smooth path Î³: [a  . .  b] â†’â„‚.


Then:
: Î³(a) is the start point of C

: Î³(b) is the end point of C.


Collectively, Î³(a) and Î³(b) are known as the endpoints of Ï.

title: Definition:Directed Line Segment
definition:
A directed line segment is a line segment endowed with the additional property of direction.

It is often used in the context of applied mathematics to represent a vector quantity.

title: Definition:Directed Hamilton Cycle Problem
definition:
There are two versions of the Directed Hamilton Cycle Problem.


=== Function Version ===
:Given a digraph G with n vertices, to find a Hamilton cycle in G.

=== Decision Version ===
:Given a digraph G with n vertices, to determine whether G has a Hamilton cycle.

title: Definition:Directrix of Ruled Surface
definition:
A directrix is a curve which defines the generators of a ruled surface.


=== Directrix of Cone ===
Let K be a cone.

Let B be the base of K.


The boundary of B is known as the directrix of K.

=== Directrix of Cylindrical Surface ===
The directrix of a cylindrical surface S is the curve C through which pass all the parallel straight lines forming S.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Directrix
definition:
Let K be a conic section specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant e

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = e p


The line D is known as the directrix of the conic section.

title: Definition:Conchoid/Directrix
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a conchoid.

Let ğ’ be the curve   which the conchoid is constructed.


ğ’ is known as the directrix of ğ’¦.


=== Also known as ===

title: Definition:Discrete Mathematics
definition: Discrete mathematics is the branch of mathematics which studies mathematical structures that are discrete rather than continuous.

title: Definition:Discrete Category
definition:
Let ğ’ be a metacategory.


Then ğ’ is said to be discrete  if and only if  it comprises only identity morphisms.

If the collection ğ’ constitutes the objects of ğ‚, then ğ‚ may also be denoted ğƒğ¢ğ¬(   )ğ’.

title: Definition:Discrete Topology
definition:
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Then Ï„ is called the discrete topology on S and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) the discrete space on S, or just a discrete space.


=== Finite Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be a finite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is a finite discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is a finite discrete space.

=== Infinite Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be an infinite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is an infinite discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is an infinite discrete space.


=== Countable Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be an infinite set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be a countably infinite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is a countable discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is a countable discrete space.

=== Uncountable Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be an uncountably infinite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is an uncountable discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is an uncountable discrete space.

title: Definition:Discrete Group
definition:
A discrete group is a topological group whose topology is discrete.

Category:Definitions/Topological Groups

title: Definition:Discrete Subgroup/Real Numbers
definition:
Let G be a subgroup of the additive group of real numbers.


Then G is discrete  if and only if :
:âˆ€ g âˆˆ G: âˆƒÏµâˆˆâ„_>0: ( g - Ïµ . . )g + Ïµâˆ© G = { g }

That is, there exists a neighborhood of g which contains no other elements of G.


Category:Definitions/Subgroups
Category:Definitions/Topological Groups
Category:Definitions/Real Numbers

title: Definition:Standard Discrete Metric
definition:
The standard discrete metric on a set S is the metric satisfying:

:d (   )x, y =  0     : x = y 
 1     : x  y


This can be expressed using the Kronecker delta notation as:
:d (   )x, y = 1 - Î´_x y


The resulting metric space M = ( S, d ) is the standard discrete metric space on S.

title: Definition:Discriminant of Polynomial
definition:
Let k be a field.

Let f (   )X âˆˆ k [ X ] be a polynomial of degree n.

Let k be an algebraic closure of k.

Let the roots of f in k be Î±_1, Î±_2, â€¦, Î±_n.


Then the discriminant Î”(   )f of f is defined as:

:Î”(   )f := âˆ_1 â‰¤ i  < j â‰¤ n( Î±_i - Î±_j )^2


=== Quadratic Equation ===

The concept is usually encountered in the context of a quadratic equation a x^2 + b x + c = 0:
Consider the quadratic equation:
:a x^2 + b x + c = 0

The expression b^2 - 4 a c is called the discriminant of the equation.

=== Cubic Equation ===

In the context of a cubic equation a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d = 0:

title: Definition:Discriminant of Bilinear Form
definition:
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚ of finite dimension n>0.

Let b : VÃ— V â†’ğ•‚ be a bilinear form on V.

Let A be the matrix of b relative to an ordered basis of V.


If b is nondegenerate, its discriminant is the equivalence class of the determinant A in the quotient group ğ•‚^Ã—( ğ•‚^Ã—)^2.

If b is degenerate, its discriminant is 0.

title: Definition:Discriminant of Conic Section
definition:
Let K be a conic section embedded in a Cartesian plane with the general equation:
:a x^2 + 2 h x y + b y^2 + 2 g x + 2 f y + c = 0
where a, b, c, f, g, h âˆˆâ„.


The discriminant of K is defined as the determinant calculated as:
:Î” =  a     h     g 
 h     b     f 
 g     f     c

title: Definition:Discriminant Function
definition:
A discriminant function is a function which assigns a given individual to one of a number of populations according to the data appertaining to that individual.

It is based on measurements on individuals for whom the population to which each one belongs is known.

It is chosen to minimize the probabilities or costs of misclassification.

title: Definition:Dispersion (Statistics)
definition:
Let S be a sample of a population in the context of statistics.

The dispersion of S is a general term meaning how much the data describing the sample are spread out.


The word can also be applied to a random variable.


Measures of dispersion include the following:


=== Range ===
Range is a measure of dispersion of a set of observations.


Let S be a set of observations of a quantitative variable.

The range of S is defined as:
:R (   )S := max(   )S - min(   )S

where max(   )S and min(   )S are the greatest value of S and the least value of S respectively.


=== Infinite Range ===
For certain random variables, it is possible that the range may be infinite, in the sense that it is technically unbounded.


 

=== Interquartile Range ===
The interquartile range is a measure of dispersion in statistics.


Let Q_1 and Q_3 be first quartile and third quartile respectively.

The interquartile range is defined and denoted as:

:IQR := Q_3 - Q_1

=== Semi-Interquartile Range ===
The semi-interquartile range is a measure of dispersion in statistics.


Let Q_1 and Q_3 be first quartile and third quartile respectively.

The semi-interquartile range is defined as:

:Q_3 - Q_1 2

That is, half the interquartile range.

=== Mean Absolute Deviation ===
Let S = { x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n } be a set of observations.

Let xÌ… denote a measure of central tendency of S.


The mean absolute deviation   xÌ… of S is defined as the arithmetic mean of the absolute values of the deviation of the elements of S from xÌ… :

:âˆ‘_i  = 1^n  1 n | x_i - xÌ…|


=== Discrete Random Variable ===
Let X be a discrete random variable.

Let xÌ… denote a measure of central tendency of X.


The mean absolute deviation of X is the first absolute moment of X about xÌ….

=== Continuous Random Variable ===
Let X be a continuous random variable.

Let m denote the median of X.

Let the frequency function of X be f.


The mean absolute deviation of X is defined as:
:âˆ«_-âˆ^+âˆ| x - m | f (   )x  d x

=== Variance ===
Let X be a continuous random variable. 

Then the variance of X, written ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ), is a measure of how much the values of X varies from the expectation ğ–¤( X ), and is defined as:

:ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ) := ğ–¤( ( X - ğ–¤( X ) )^2 )

That is, the expectation of the squares of the deviations from the expectation.


Letting Î¼ = ğ–¤( X ), this is often given as: 

:ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ) = ğ–¤( ( X - Î¼)^2 )

=== Standard Deviation ===
Standard deviation is a measure of dispersion of a set of observations.

Let X be a random variable.

Then the standard deviation of X, written Ïƒ_X or Ïƒ, is defined as the principal square root of the variance of X:

:Ïƒ_X := âˆš(ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ))

title: Definition:Dispersion Point
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a connected set in T and let p âˆˆ H.

Let p âˆˆ H such that H âˆ–{ p } is totally disconnected, where âˆ– denotes set difference.


Then p is a dispersion point of H.

title: Definition:Distance/Points/Complex Numbers
definition:
Let x, y âˆˆâ„‚ be complex numbers.

Let | x - y | be the complex modulus of x - y.


Then the function d: â„‚^2 â†’â„:
:d (   )x, y = | x - y |
is called the distance between x and y.

title: Definition:Metric Space/Distance Function
definition:
Let ( A, d ) be a metric space.

The mapping d: A Ã— A â†’â„ is referred to as a distance function on A.


Here, d: A Ã— A â†’â„ is a real-valued function satisfying the metric space axioms:

title: Definition:Distance/Sets/Metric Spaces
definition:
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let x âˆˆ A.

Let S, T be subsets of A.


The distance between x and S is defined and annotated d (   )x, S = inf_y âˆˆ S( d (   )x, y).

The distance between S and T is defined and annotated d (   )S, T = inf_x âˆˆ S 
 y âˆˆ T( d (   )x, y).

title: Definition:Distance between Points
definition: The distance between two points A and B in space is defined as the length of a straight line segment that would be drawn from A to B.

title: Definition:Distance between Lines
definition:
Let L_1 and L_2 be straight lines in space.

The distance between L_1 and L_2 is defined as the length of the shortest line segment joining L_1 and L_2.

title: Definition:Distance between Parallel Lines
definition:
Let L_1 and L_2 be parallel lines.

The distance between L_1 and L_2 is defined as the length of a line segment joining L_1 and L_2 that is perpendicular to both.

title: Definition:Distributive Operation
definition:
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, which we will denote as âˆ˜ and *.


The operation âˆ˜ is distributive over *, or distributes over *,  if and only if :
:âˆ˜ is right distributive over *
and:
:âˆ˜ is left distributive over *.


=== Left Distributive ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, denoted here as âˆ˜ and *.

The operation âˆ˜ is left distributive over the operation *  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜( b * c ) = ( a âˆ˜ b ) * ( a âˆ˜ c )

=== Right Distributive ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, denoted here as âˆ˜ and *.

The operation âˆ˜ is right distributive over the operation *  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: ( a * b ) âˆ˜ c = ( a âˆ˜ c ) * ( b âˆ˜ c )

So as to streamline what may turn into cumbersome language, some further definitions:

=== Distributand ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, which we will denote as âˆ˜ and *.

Let âˆ˜ be distributive over *.

Then * is a distributand of âˆ˜.


=== Linguistic Note ===


Category:Definitions/Distributive Operations

=== Distributor ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, which we will denote as âˆ˜ and *.

Let âˆ˜ be distributive over *.

Then âˆ˜ is a distributor of *.


Category:Definitions/Distributive Operations

title: Definition:Distributive Lattice
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.


Then ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is distributive  if and only if  ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) satisfies one of the distributive lattice axioms:
 

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.


Then ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is distributive  if and only if  ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) satisfies all of the distributive lattice axioms:

title: Definition:Divergent Product/Divergence to Zero
definition:
Let ( ğ•‚, â€– Â· â€–) be a valued field.

Let âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© be a sequence of elements of ğ•‚.

:there exist infinitely many n âˆˆâ„• with a_n = 0

the product diverges to 0, and we assign the value:
:âˆ_n  = 1^âˆ a_n = 0

title: Definition:Divergence Operator
definition:
=== Physical Interpretation ===
Let ğ• be a vector field acting over a region of space R.

The divergence of ğ• at a point P is the total flux away from P per unit volume.

It is a scalar field.

=== Geometrical Representation ===
Let R be a region of space embedded in a Cartesian coordinate frame.

Let ğ• be a vector field acting over R.


The divergence of ğ• at a point A in R is defined as:

 
 
 
 

where:
:âˆ‡ denotes the Del operator

:V_x, V_y and V_z denote the magnitudes of the components of ğ• at A in the directions of the coordinate axes x, y and z respectively.

=== Real Cartesian Space ===
Let â„^n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n denote the real Cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let ( ğ_1, ğ_2, â€¦, ğ_n ) be the standard ordered basis on â„^n.

Let ğŸ = ( f_1 (   )ğ±, f_2 (   )ğ±, â€¦, f_n (   )ğ±): â„^n â†’â„^n be a vector-valued function on â„^n.


Let the partial derivative of ğŸ with respect to x_k exist for all f_k.


The divergence of ğŸ is defined as:

 
 
 
 
 


=== Cartesian 3-Space ===

In 3 dimensions with the standard ordered basis ( ğ¢, ğ£, ğ¤), this is usually rendered:

Let R be a region of Cartesian 3-space â„^3.

Let ğ•(   )x, y, z be a vector field acting over R.


The divergence of ğ• is defined as:

 
 
 
 

=== Riemannian Manifold ===
Let ( M, g ) be a Riemannian manifold equipped with a metric g.

Let ğ— : ğ’^âˆ(   )M â†’ğ’^âˆ(   )M be a smooth vector field.


The divergence of ğ— is defined as:

 
 
 
 

where:
:â‹†_g is the Hodge star operator of ( M, g )
:d_d R is de Rham differential.

=== Integral Form ===
Let R be a region of space embedded in a Cartesian coordinate frame.

Let ğ• be a vector field acting over R.


The divergence of ğ• at a point A in R is defined as:

:divğ• := lim_Î´Ï„â†’ 0âˆ«_S ğ•Â·d SÎ´Ï„

where:
:S is the surface of a volume element Î´Ï„ containing A
:Â· denotes the dot product
:âˆ«_S denotes the surface integral over S.

title: Definition:Divergent Sequence
definition:
A sequence which is not convergent is divergent.

 

=== Divergent Real Sequence ===
A real sequence which is not convergent is divergent.

title: Definition:Divergent Series
definition: A series which is not convergent is divergent.

title: Definition:Divergent Function
definition: A function which is not convergent is divergent.

title: Definition:Divergent Improper Integral
definition:
An improper integral of a real function f is said to diverge if any of the following hold:

:(1):    f is continuous on [ a  . . )â†’ and the limit lim_b â†’ +âˆâˆ«_a^b f (   )x  d x does not exist

:(2):    f is continuous on (  . . ]b and the limit lim_a â†’ -âˆâˆ«_a^b f (   )x  d x does not exist

:(3):    f is continuous on [ a  . . )b, has an infinite discontinuity at b, and the limit lim_c â†’ b^-âˆ«_a^c f (   )x  d x does not exist

:(4):    f is continuous on ( a  . . ]b, has an infinite discontinuity at a, and the limit lim_c â†’ a^+âˆ«_c^b f (   )x  d x does not exist.

title: Definition:Divergent Product
definition:
An infinite product which is not convergent is divergent.

 


=== Divergence to zero ===
Let ( ğ•‚, â€– Â· â€–) be a valued field.

Let âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© be a sequence of elements of ğ•‚.


If either:

:there exist infinitely many n âˆˆâ„• with a_n = 0

:there exists n_0 âˆˆâ„• with a_n  0 for all n > n_0 and the sequence of partial products of âˆ_n  = n_0 + 1^âˆ a_n converges to 0

the product diverges to 0, and we assign the value:
:âˆ_n  = 1^âˆ a_n = 0
