Category:Definitions/Infinite Products

title: Definition:Divisor (Algebra)/Integer
definition:
Let ( â„¤, +, Ã—) be the ring of integers.

Let x, y âˆˆâ„¤.


Then x divides y is defined as:
:x \ y âˆƒ t âˆˆâ„¤: y = t Ã— x


=== Aliquot Part ===
An aliquot part of an integer n is a divisor of n which is strictly less than n.

=== Aliquant Part ===
An aliquant part of an integer n is a positive integer which is less than n but is not a divisor of n.

title: Definition:Prime Factor
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

Then p is a prime factor of n  if and only if :
: (1):    p is a prime number
: (2):    p is a divisor (that is, factor) of n.

title: Definition:Divisor (Algebra)/Ring with Unity
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be an ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.

Let x, y âˆˆ D.

We define the term x divides y in R as follows:
:x \_R y âˆƒ t âˆˆ R: y = t âˆ˜ x


When no ambiguity results, the subscript is usually dropped, and x divides y in R is just written x \ y.

title: Definition:Divisor of Polynomial
definition:
Let D be an integral domain.

Let D [ x ] be the polynomial ring in one variable over D.

Let f, g âˆˆ D [ x ] be polynomials.


Then:
:f divides g
:f is a divisor of g
:g is divisible by f
 if and only if :
:âˆƒ h âˆˆ D [ x ] : g = f h


This is denoted:
:f \ g


=== Notation ===
The conventional notation for x is a divisor of y is "x | y", but there is a growing trend to follow the notation "x \ y", as espoused by   etc.

From  :
:The notation 'm | n' is actually much more common than 'm \ n' in current mathematics literature. But vertical lines are overused â€“ for absolute values, set delimiters, conditional probabilities, etc. â€“ and backward slashes are underused. Moreover, 'm \ n' gives an impression that m is the denominator of an implied ratio. So we shall boldly let our divisibility symbol lean leftward.


An unfortunate unwelcome side-effect of this notational convention is that to indicate non-divisibility, the conventional technique of implementing / through the notation looks awkward with \, so \ is eschewed in favour of âˆ¤.


Some sources use | -10mu  3pt - or similar to denote non-divisibility.


Category:Definitions/Divisors

title: Definition:Division/Divisor
definition:
Let c = a / b denote the division operation on two elements a and b of a field or a Euclidean domain.

The element b is the divisor of a.

title: Definition:Domain (Relation Theory)
definition:
=== Relation ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.

The domain of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Dom( â„›) := { s âˆˆ S: âˆƒ t âˆˆ T: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›}


That is, it is the same as what is defined here as the preimage of â„›.


=== General Definition ===
Let âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i be the cartesian product of sets S_1 to S_n.

Let â„›âŠ†âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i be an n-ary relation on âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i.

The domain of â„› is the set defined as:
:Dom( â„›) := {( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆâˆ_i  = 1^n - 1 S_i: âˆƒ s_n âˆˆ S_n: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}


The concept is usually encountered when â„› is an endorelation on S:
:Dom( â„›) := {( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆ S^n - 1: âˆƒ s_n âˆˆ S_n: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}

=== Class Theory ===
 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let â„›âŠ† V Ã— V be a relation in V.

The domain of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Dom( â„›) := { x âˆˆ V: âˆƒ y âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the class of all x such that ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„› for at least one y.

=== Mapping ===

The term domain is usually seen when the relation in question is actually a mapping.

Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.

The domain of f is S, and can be denoted Dom( f ).

=== Binary Operation ===
Let âˆ˜: S Ã— S â†’ T be a binary operation.

The domain of âˆ˜ is the set S and can be denoted Dom( âˆ˜).


This definition can be considered as the same as that for the domain of a mapping, where the domain would be defined as S Ã— S.

Category:Definitions/Abstract Algebra

title: Definition:Variable/Domain
definition:
The collection of all possible objects that a variable may refer to has to be specified.

This collection is the domain of the variable.

title: Definition:Domain (Category Theory)
definition:
Let f: X â†’ Y be a morphism.

Then the domain of f is defined to be the object X.

This is usually denoted X = Dom( f ) or X = D (   )f.

title: Definition:Integral Domain
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
An integral domain ( D, +, âˆ˜) is:

:a commutative ring which is non-null
:with a unity
:in which there are no (proper) zero divisors, that is:
::: âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ D: x âˆ˜ y = 0_D  x = 0_D  or  y = 0_D

that is, in which all non-zero elements are cancellable.

=== Definition 2 ===
An integral domain ( D, +, âˆ˜) is a commutative ring such that ( D^*, âˆ˜) is a monoid, all of whose elements are cancellable.

In this context, D^* denotes the ring D without zero: D âˆ–{ 0_D }.

=== Integral Domain Axioms ===

title: Definition:Dominate (Set Theory)
definition:
Let S and T be sets.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let S and T be sets.


Then S is dominated by T  if and only if  there exists an injection from S to T.


The notation S â‰¼ T is used to indicate that S dominates T.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let S and T be sets.


Then S is dominated by T  if and only if  S is equivalent to some subset of T.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a bijection f: S â†’ T' for some T' âŠ† T.

The notation S â‰¼ T is used to indicate that S dominates T.

=== Strictly Dominated ===
Let S, T be sets.


S is strictly dominated by set T  if and only if  S â‰¼ T but T â‰¼ S.

This can be written S â‰º T or S < T.


Category:Definitions/Set Theory

title: Definition:Dominate (Analysis)
definition:
Let âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© be a sequence in â„.

Let âŸ¨ z_n âŸ© be a sequence in â„‚.


Then âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© dominates âŸ¨ z_n âŸ©  if and only if :
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„•: | z_n |â‰¤ a_n

Category:Definitions/Analysis
Category:Definitions/Complex Analysis

title: Definition:Avoirdupois/Dram
definition:
The dram is an avoirdupois unit of mass.

=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Apothecaries' Weights and Measures/Mass/Drachm
definition:
The drachm is an apothecaries' unit of mass.

=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Dual Relation
definition:
=== Inverse of Complement ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a binary relation.


Then the dual of â„› is denoted â„›^d and is defined as:

:â„›^d := ( R )^-1

where:
:R denotes the complement of â„›
:( R )^-1 denotes the inverse of the complement of â„›.

=== Complement of Inverse ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a binary relation.


Then the dual of â„› is denoted â„›^d and is defined as:

:â„›^d := ( â„›^-1)

where:
:â„›^-1 denotes the inverse of â„›
:( â„›^-1) denotes the complement of the inverse of â„›.


Category:Definitions/Relation Theory

title: Definition:Dual Ordering
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let â‰½ be the inverse relation to â‰¼.

That is, for all a, b âˆˆ S:

:a â‰½ b  if and only if  b â‰¼ a


Then â‰½ is called the dual ordering of â‰¼.


=== Dual Ordered Set ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let â‰½ be the dual ordering of â‰¼.


The ordered set ( S, â‰½) is called the dual ordered set (or just dual) of ( S, â‰¼).


That it indeed is an ordered set is a consequence of Dual Ordering is Ordering.

=== Notation for Dual Ordering ===
To denote the dual of an ordering, the conventional technique is to reverse the symbol.

Thus:
:â‰½ denotes â‰¼^-1
:â‰½ denotes â‰¼^-1
:â‹Ÿ denotes â‹^-1

and so:
:a â‰¼ b  b â‰½ a
:a â‰¼ b  b â‰½ a
:a â‹ b  b â‹Ÿ a


Similarly for the standard symbols used to denote an ordering on numbers:
:â‰¥ denotes â‰¤^-1
:â©¾ denotes â©½^-1
:âª– denotes âª•^-1

and so on.

=== Notation for Dual Strict Ordering ===
To denote the dual of an strict ordering, the conventional technique is to reverse the symbol.

Thus:
:â‰» denotes â‰º^-1

and so:
:a â‰º b  b â‰» a


Similarly for the standard symbol used to denote a strict ordering on numbers:
:> denotes <^-1

and so on.

title: Definition:Dual Statement (Order Theory)
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let â‰½ be the dual ordering to â‰¼.

Let x3a3 be any statement pertaining to ( S, â‰¼) (be it in natural language or a formal language).


The dual statement of x3a3, denoted x3a3^*, is the statement obtained from replacing every reference to â‰¼ in x3a3 with a reference to its dual â‰½.

This dual statement may then be turned into a statement about â‰¼ again by applying the equivalences on Dual Pairs (Order Theory).

title: Definition:Dual Isomorphism (Order Theory)
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼_S ) and ( T, â‰¼_T ) be ordered sets.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a bijection.


Then Ï• is a dual isomorphism between ( S, â‰¼_S ) and ( T, â‰¼_T )  if and only if  Ï• and Ï•^-1 are decreasing mappings.


If there is a dual isomorphism between ( S, â‰¼_S ) and ( T, â‰¼_T ), then ( S, â‰¼_S ) is dual to ( T, â‰¼_T ).

Equivalently, ( S, â‰¼_S ) is dual to ( T, â‰¼_T )  if and only if  S with the dual ordering is isomorphic to T.

title: Definition:Dual Order Embedding
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be ordered sets.


A dual order embedding is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T such that:

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )y â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )x


That is:
:if Ï• is an order embedding of ( S, â‰¼_1 ) into ( T, â‰½_2 )
where â‰½_2 is the dual of â‰¼_2.

Category:Definitions/Order Embeddings

title: Definition:Self-Dual (Order Theory)
definition:
Let (S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

If S is dual to S, then S is self-dual.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Eccentricity
definition:
Let K be a conic section specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant e

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = e p


The constant e is known as the eccentricity of the conic section.

title: Definition:Eccentricity of Vertex
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Let v âˆˆ V be a vertex of G.


The eccentricity of v is the maximum distance from v to another vertex of G:


That is:
:E (   )v = max_u âˆˆ V D (   )v, u

where D (   )v, u denotes the distance from v to u.

title: Definition:Graph (Graph Theory)/Edge
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

The edges are the elements of E.


In the above, the edges are AB, AE, BE, CD, CE, CF, DE, DF, FG.


=== Join ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Let u and v be vertices of G.

Let e = u v be an edge of G.


Then e joins the vertices u and v.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Edge
definition: The edges of a polyhedron are the sides of the polygons which constitute its faces.

title: Definition:Polyhedral Angle/Edge
definition: Each of the half-lines that form a polyhedral angle is known as an edge of the polyhedral angle.

title: Definition:Half-Plane/Edge
definition:
Let ğ’« denote the plane.

Let â„’ denote an infinite straight line in ğ’«.

Let â„‹ denote one of the half-planes into which â„’ divides ğ’«.

Then â„’ is called the edge of â„‹.

title: Definition:Morphism
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.


A morphism of ğ‚ is an object f, together with:

* A domain dom f, which is an object of ğ‚
* A codomain cod f, also an object of ğ‚


The collection of all morphisms of ğ‚ is denoted ğ‚_1.


If A is the domain of f and B is its codomain, this is mostly represented by writing:

:f: A â†’ B or A  f âŸ¶ B

title: Definition:Elevation of Point
definition: The elevation of a point P is the height of P above some reference horizontal baseline or plane.

title: Definition:Angle of Elevation
definition:
Let A and B be points in space such that A is higher than B.

The angle of elevation of A from B is the angle between the line AB and the horizontal.

title: Definition:Embedding (Topology)
definition:
Let A, B be topological spaces.

Let f: A â†’ B be a mapping.

Let the image of f be given the subspace topology.

Let the restriction f _A Ã— f[ A ] of f to its image be a homeomorphism.


Then f is an embedding (of A into B).

title: Definition:Embedding (Model Theory)
definition:
Let â„³ and ğ’© be â„’-structures with universes M and N respectively.


j: â„³â†’ğ’© is an â„’-embedding  if and only if  it is an injective map M â†’ N which preserves interpretations of all symbols in â„’; that is, such that:
:j (   )f^â„³(   )a_1, â€¦, a_n_f = f^ğ’©(   )j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_f for all function symbols f in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_f in M
:( a_1, â€¦, a_n_R) âˆˆ R^â„³( j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_R) âˆˆ R^ğ’© for all relation symbols R in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_R in M
:j (   )c^â„³ = c^ğ’© for all constant symbols c in â„’.


=== Partial Embedding ===

A common method of constructing isomorphisms and elementary embeddings in proofs is to recursively define them a finite number of elements at a time.  For this  purpose, it is useful to have a definition of embeddings using functions which are only defined on a subset of M:


Let A âŠ† M be a subset of M.


j: A â†’ğ’© is a partial â„’-embedding  if and only if  it is an injective map A â†’ N which preserves interpretations of all symbols in â„’ applied to elements of A; that is, such that:
:j (   )f^â„³(   )a_1, â€¦, a_n_f = f^ğ’©(   )j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_f for  all function symbols f in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_f in A
:( a_1, â€¦, a_n_R) âˆˆ R^â„³( j (   )a_1, â€¦, j (   )a_n_R) âˆˆ R^ğ’© for all relation symbols R in â„’ and a_1, â€¦, a_n_R in A
:j (   )c^â„³ = c^ğ’© for all constant symbols c in â„’.


=== Isomorphism ===

j: â„³â†’ğ’© is an â„’-isomorphism  if and only if  it is a bijective â„’-embedding.


=== Automorphism ===

j: â„³â†’ğ’© is an â„’-automorphism  if and only if  it is an â„’-isomorphism and â„³ = ğ’©.


It is often useful to talk about automorphisms which are constant on subsets of M.  So, there is a definition and a notation for doing so:

Let A âŠ† M be a subset of M, and let b âˆˆ M.


An â„’-automorphism j is an A-automorphism  if and only if  j (   )a = a for all aâˆˆ A.

An â„’-automorphism j is an A, b-automorphism  if and only if  it is an ( A âˆª{ b })-automorphism; that is: j (   )a = a for all a âˆˆ A and also j (   )b = b.

title: Definition:Embedding (Galois Theory)
definition:
Let K and L be fields.

A (field) monomorphism Ï•: K â†’ L is called an embedding of K in L.

title: Definition:Ring Monomorphism
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) and ( S, âŠ•, * ) be rings.

Let Ï•: R â†’ S be a (ring) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a ring monomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is an injection.

title: Definition:Embedding of Categories
definition:
Let C and D be categories.

Let F : C â†’ D be a functor.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let C and D be categories.

Let F : C â†’ D be a functor.


The functor F is an embedding  if and only if  it is:
* injective on objects
* faithful

=== Definition 2 ===
Let C and D be categories.

Let F : C â†’ D be a functor.


The functor F is an embedding  if and only if  it is injective on morphisms.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let C and D be categories.

Let F : C â†’ D be a functor.


The functor F is an embedding  if and only if  it is a monomorphisms in the category of categories.

title: Definition:Empty Set
definition:
The empty set is a set which has no elements.

That is, x âˆˆâˆ… is false, whatever x is.


It is usually denoted by some variant of a zero with a line through it, for example âˆ… or âˆ…, and can always be represented as {}.

title: Definition:Empty Class (Class Theory)
definition:
A class is defined as being empty  if and only if  it has no elements.

That is:
:âˆ€ x: x âˆ‰ A
or:
:âˆƒ x: x âˆˆ A


The empty class is usually denoted âˆ… or âˆ….

On   the preferred symbol is âˆ….

title: Definition:Empty Mapping
definition:
Let T be a set.


Then the mapping e: âˆ…â†’ T whose domain is the empty set and whose codomain is T is called the empty mapping:
:e âŠ†âˆ…Ã— T = âˆ…

title: Definition:Null Relation
definition:
The null relation is a relation â„› in S to T such that â„› is the empty set:
:â„›âŠ† S Ã— T: â„› = âˆ…


That is, no element of S relates to any element in T:
:â„›: S Ã— T: âˆ€( s, t ) âˆˆ S Ã— T:  s â„› t

title: Definition:Edgeless Graph
definition:
An edgeless graph is a graph with no edges.

That is, an edgeless graph is a graph of size zero.

Equivalently, an edgeless graph is a graph whose vertices are all isolated.


The edgeless graph of order n is denoted N_n and can be referred to as the n-edgeless graph.

title: Definition:Summation/Vacuous Summation
definition:
Take the summation:
:âˆ‘_Î¦(   )j a_j
where Î¦(   )j is a propositional function of j.

Suppose that there are no values of j for which Î¦(   )j is true.

Then âˆ‘_Î¦(   )j a_j is defined as being 0.

This summation is called a vacuous summation.


This is because:
:âˆ€ a: a + 0 = a
where a is a number.

Hence for all j for which Î¦(   )j is false, the sum is unaffected.


This is most frequently seen in the form:
:âˆ‘_j  = m^n a_j = 0
where m > n.

In this case, j can not at the same time be both greater than or equal to m and less than or equal to n.


Some sources consider such a treatment as abuse of notation.

title: Definition:Class Interval/Empty
definition: A class interval is empty  if and only if  it is of frequency zero.

title: Definition:Zero (Category)
definition:
The category 0, zero, is the empty category:


:


with:
:no objects
and consequently:
:no morphisms.

title: Definition:Empty Class (Class Theory)
definition:
A class is defined as being empty  if and only if  it has no elements.

That is:
:âˆ€ x: x âˆ‰ A
or:
:âˆƒ x: x âˆˆ A


The empty class is usually denoted âˆ… or âˆ….

On   the preferred symbol is âˆ….

title: Definition:Class Interval/Empty
definition: A class interval is empty  if and only if  it is of frequency zero.

title: Definition:Uncertainty
definition:
Let X be a discrete random variable.

Let X take a finite number of values with probabilities p_1, p_2, â€¦, p_n.


The uncertainty of X is defined as:

:H (   )X =  -âˆ‘_k p_k  p_k

where:
: denotes logarithm base 2
:the summation is over those k where p_k > 0.


=== Units ===
The unit of measurement used to quantify uncertainty is the bit.


Category:Definitions/Uncertainty

title: Definition:Differential Entropy
definition:
Differential entropy extends the concept of entropy to continuous random variables.

Let X be a continuous random variable.

Let X have probability density function f_X. 

Then the differential entropy of X, h (   )X measured in nats, is given by: 

:h (   )X = -âˆ«_-âˆ^âˆ f_X (   )x ln f_X (   )x  d x


Where f_X (   )x = 0, we take f_X (   )x ln f_X (   )x = 0 by convention.

title: Definition:Entropy (Physics)
definition:
Entropy is a property of a thermodynamic system.

It quantifies the number Î© of microstates that are consistent with the macroscopic quantities that characterize the system.


The entropy of a system is equal to the expectation of the value:
:k ln P
where:
:k is a constant which relates the mean kinetic energy and absolute temperature of the system
:P is the coefficient of probability of the system.

title: Definition:Epicycle (Ptolemaic Astronomy)
definition:
An epicycle is the orbit described by a body moving in a uniform circular motion around a point which is itself moving in a uniform circular motion around another point.

:

That point may itself also be moving in a uniform circular motion around yet another point.

title: Definition:Epicycloid/Generator/Epicycle
definition:
Let an epicycloid be generated by rolling a circle C_1 around the outside of another circle C_2.


:


The circle C_1 can be referred to as the epicycle of the epicycloid.

title: Definition:Hypocycloid/Generator/Epicycle
definition:
Let a hypocycloid be generated by rolling circle C_1 around the inside of another (larger) circle C_2.


:


The circle C_1 can be referred to as the epicycle of the hypocycloid.

title: Definition:Epimorphism (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
A homomorphism which is a surjection is an epimorphism.


=== Semigroup Epimorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) and ( T, * ) be semigroups.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a (semigroup) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a semigroup epimorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a surjection.

=== Monoid Epimorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) and ( T, * ) be monoids.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a (monoid) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a monoid epimorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a surjection.

=== Group Epimorphism ===
Let ( G, âˆ˜) and ( H, * ) be groups.

Let Ï•: G â†’ H be a (group) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a group epimorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a surjection.

=== Ring Epimorphism ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) and ( S, âŠ•, * ) be rings.

Let Ï•: R â†’ S be a (ring) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a ring epimorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a surjection.

=== Field Epimorphism ===
Let ( F, +, âˆ˜) and ( K, âŠ•, * ) be fields.

Let Ï•: R â†’ S be a (field) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a field epimorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a surjection.

=== R-Algebraic Structure Epimorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ—_1, âˆ—_2, â€¦, âˆ—_n, âˆ˜)_R and ( T, âŠ™_1, âŠ™_2, â€¦, âŠ™_n, âŠ—)_R be R-algebraic structures.


Then Ï•: S â†’ T is an R-algebraic structure epimorphism  if and only if :

:(1):   Ï• is a surjection
:(2):   âˆ€ k: k âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]n: âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: Ï•(   )x âˆ—_k y = Ï•(   )x âŠ™_k Ï•(   )y
:(3):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: âˆ€Î»âˆˆ R: Ï•(   )Î»âˆ˜ x = Î»âŠ—Ï•(   )x


This definition also applies to modules, and also to vector spaces.

title: Definition:Epimorphism (Category Theory)
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.

An epimorphism is a morphism f âˆˆğ‚_1 such that:

: g âˆ˜ f = h âˆ˜ f  g = h

for all morphisms g, h âˆˆğ‚_1 for which these compositions are defined.


That is, an epimorphism is a morphism which is right cancellable. 



One writes f: C â†  D to denote that f is an epimorphism.

title: Definition:Geographical Equator
definition:
The (geographical) equator is the great circle described on the surface of Earth whose plane is perpendicular to Earth's axis of rotation.


:

title: Definition:Celestial Equator
definition:
Consider the celestial sphere with observer O.

Let P be the north celestial pole.


The great circle whose plane is perpendicular to OP is known as the celestial equator.


:

title: Definition:Galactic Equator
definition:
The galactic equator is the great circle that is the intersection of the plane of the Milky Way with the celestial sphere.


=== Galactic Poles ===
The galactic poles are the two poles of the great circle that is the galactic equator.

=== Galactic Axis ===
The galactic axis is the axis of the great circle that is the galactic equator.

title: Definition:Statistical Equilibrium
definition:
Let S be a stochastic process.

Suppose that the observations of the time series to which S gives rise have a constant mean level.

Then S is said to be in (statistical) equilibrium.

title: Definition:Equilibrium (Mechanics)/Stable
definition:
Let B be a particle, a system of particles, or a body which is in equilibrium.

Let B be such that if a sufficiently small displacement is applied, then it returns to its original position.


B is then said to be in stable equilibrium.

title: Definition:Equilibrium (Mechanics)/Unstable
definition:
Let B be a particle, a system of particles, or a body which is in equilibrium.

Let B be such that if a displacement is applied, however small, B moves to a position different from both its original position and its displaced position.


B is then said to be in unstable equilibrium.

title: Definition:Equilibrium (Mechanics)/Neutral
definition:
Let B be a particle, a system of particles, or a body which is in equilibrium.

Let B be such that if a small displacement is applied, B remains in its new position.


B is then said to be in neutral equilibrium.

title: Definition:Spring/Equilibrium Position
definition:
The equilibrium position of a body B attached to a spring S is the position it occupies when S is exerting no force upon B.

For an ideal spring obeying Hooke's Law ğ… = -k ğ±, the equilibrium position is set to be the point ğ± =  0.

title: Definition:Equilibrium Point
definition: An equilibrium point is a stable outcome of a game associated with a particular set of strategies.

title: Definition:Equilibrium Strategy
definition:
A system of strategies, one for each player, is in equilibrium  if and only if  they result in an equilibrium point.

Such strategies are known as equilibrium strategies.


In the singular, an equilibrium strategy is one that contributes to an equilibrium point.

title: Definition:Nash Equilibrium
definition:
Let a strategic game G be modelled by:
:G = âŸ¨ N, âŸ¨âŸ©, âŸ¨ A_i âŸ©âŸ©â‰¿_i


A Nash equilibrium of G is a profile a^* âˆˆ A of moves which has the property that:
:âˆ€ i âˆˆ N: âˆ€ a_i âˆˆ A_i: ( a^*_-i, a^*_i ) â‰¿_i ( a^*_-i, a_i )


Thus, for a^* to be a Nash equilibrium, no player i has a move yielding a preferable outcome to that when a^*_i is chosen, given that every other player j has chosen his own equilibrium move.

That is, no player can profitably deviate, if no other player also deviates.

title: Definition:Semantic Equivalence
definition:
Let â„³ be a formal semantics for a formal language â„’.

Let Ï•, Ïˆ be â„’-WFFs.


Then Ï• and Ïˆ are â„³-semantically equivalent  if and only if :

:Ï•_â„³Ïˆ and Ïˆ_â„³Ï•

that is,  if and only if  they are â„³-semantic consequences of one another.


Equivalently, Ï• and Ïˆ are â„³-semantically equivalent  if and only if , for each â„³-structure â„³:

:â„³_â„³Ï•  if and only if  â„³_â„³Ïˆ

title: Definition:Provable Equivalence
definition:
Let ğ’« be a proof system for a formal language â„’.

Let Ï•, Ïˆ be â„’-WFFs.


Then Ï• and Ïˆ are ğ’«-provably equivalent  if and only if :

:Ï•âŠ¢_ğ’«Ïˆ and ÏˆâŠ¢_ğ’«Ï•

that is,  if and only if  they are ğ’«-provable consequences of one another.


The provable equivalence of Ï• and Ïˆ can be denoted by:

:Ï•âŠ£âŠ¢_ğ’«Ïˆ

title: Definition:Set Equivalence
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Then S and T are equivalent  if and only if :
:there exists a bijection f: S â†’ T between the elements of S and those of T.

That is,  if and only if  they have the same cardinality.


This can be written S âˆ¼ T.


If S and T are not equivalent we write S  T.

title: Definition:Row Equivalence
definition:
Two matrices ğ€ = [ a ]_m n, ğ = [ b ]_m n are row equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of elementary row operations.

This relationship can be denoted ğ€âˆ¼ğ.

title: Definition:Column Equivalence
definition:
Two matrices ğ€ = [ a ]_m n, ğ = [ b ]_m n are column equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of elementary column operations.

This relationship can be denoted ğ€âˆ¼ğ.

title: Definition:Topological Equivalence
definition:
=== Homeomorphism: Topological Spaces ===

Let T_Î± = ( S_Î±, Ï„_Î±) and T_Î² = ( S_Î², Ï„_Î²) be topological spaces.

Let f: T_Î±â†’ T_Î² be a bijection.

Let T_Î± = ( S_Î±, Ï„_Î±) and T_Î² = ( S_Î², Ï„_Î²) be topological spaces.

Let f: T_Î±â†’ T_Î² be a bijection.


f is a homeomorphism  if and only if  both f and f^-1 are continuous.


=== Homeomorphism: Metric Spaces ===
Let M_1 = ( A_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A_2, d_2 ) be metric spaces.

Let f: A_1 â†’ A_2 be a bijection such that:
:f is continuous from M_1 to M_2
:f^-1 is continuous from M_2 to M_1.


Then:
:f is a homeomorphism
:M_1 and M_2 are homeomorphic.

=== Topologically equivalent metrics ===

Let M_1 = ( A, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A, d_2 ) be metric spaces on the same underlying set A.

Let M_1 = ( A, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A, d_2 ) be metric spaces on the same underlying set A.


d_1 and d_2 are topologically equivalent  if and only if :

:For all metric spaces ( B, d ) and ( C, d' ):
:For all mappings f: B â†’ A and g: A â†’ C:

::(1):    f is ( d, d_1 )-continuous  if and only if  f is ( d, d_2 )-continuous
::(2):    g is ( d_1, d' )-continuous  if and only if  g is ( d_2, d' )-continuous.

Such mappings f and g can be referred to as homeomorphisms.

title: Definition:Equivalence Relation
definition:
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


Let â„› be:

:(1): reflexive
:(2): symmetric
:(3): transitive

Then â„› is an equivalence relation on S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation on a set S.


â„› is an equivalence relation  if and only if :

:Î”_S âˆªâ„›^-1âˆªâ„›âˆ˜â„›âŠ†â„›

where:
:Î”_S denotes the diagonal relation on S
:â„›^-1 denotes the inverse relation
:âˆ˜ denotes composition of relations

title: Definition:Euclidean Geometry
definition:
Euclidean geometry is the branch of geometry in which the parallel postulate applies.

An assumption which is currently under question is whether or not ordinary space is itself Euclidean.


Euclidean geometry adheres to Euclid's postulates.

title: Definition:Euclidean Space
definition:
Let S be one of the standard number fields â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let S^n be a cartesian space for n âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 1.

Let d: S^n Ã— S^n â†’â„ be the usual (Euclidean) metric on S^n.

Then ( S^n, d ) is a Euclidean space.

title: Definition:Euclidean Space/Euclidean Topology
definition:
Let S be one of the standard number fields â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let S^n be a cartesian space for n âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 1.

Let M = ( S^n, d ) be a Euclidean space.


The topology Ï„_d induced by the Euclidean metric d is called the Euclidean topology.

title: Definition:Euclidean Metric
definition:
Let M_1' = ( A_1', d_1') and M_2' = ( A_2', d_2') be metric spaces.

Let A_1'Ã— A_2' be the cartesian product of A_1' and A_2'.


The Euclidean metric on A_1'Ã— A_2' is defined as:

:d_2 (   )x, y := ( ( d_1'(   )x_1, y_1)^2 + ( d_2'(   )x_2, y_2)^2 )^1/2

where x = ( x_1, x_2 ), y = ( y_1, y_2 ) âˆˆ A_1'Ã— A_2'.


=== General Definition ===
Let M_1' = ( A_1', d_1'), M_2' = ( A_2', d_2'), â€¦, M_n' = ( A_n', d_n') be metric spaces.

Let ğ’œ = âˆ_i  = 1^n A_i' be the cartesian product of A_1', A_2', â€¦, A_n'.


The Euclidean metric on ğ’œ = âˆ_i  = 1^n A_i' is defined as:

:d_2 (   )x, y := ( âˆ‘_i  = 1^n ( d_i'(   )x_i, y_i)^2 )^1/2

where x = ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ), y = ( y_1, y_2, â€¦, y_n ) âˆˆğ’œ.

=== Riemannian Manifold ===
Let x âˆˆâ„^n be a point.

Let ( x_1, â€¦, x_n ) be the standard coordinates.

Let T_x â„^n be the tangent space of â„^n at x.

Let T_x â„^n be identified with â„^n:

:T_x â„^n â‰…â„^n
 

Let v, w âˆˆ T_x â„^n be vectors such that:

:v = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n v^i . âˆ‚_i |_x

:w = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n w^i . âˆ‚_i |_x

Let g be a Riemannian metric such that:

:g_x = âŸ¨ v,   âŸ© w_x = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n v^i w^i


Then g is called the Euclidean metric.

title: Definition:Euclidean Norm
definition:
Let ğ¯ = ( v_1, v_2, â€¦, v_n ) be a vector in the real Euclidean n-space â„^n.


The Euclidean norm of ğ¯ is defined as:

title: Definition:Euclidean Domain
definition:
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain.

Let there exist a Euclidean valuation on D.

Then D is called a Euclidean domain.


=== Euclidean Valuation ===
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain with zero 0_D.

Let there exist a mapping Î½: D âˆ–{ 0_D }â†’â„• such that for all a âˆˆ D, b âˆˆ D_ 0_D:

 
 
 
 

Then Î½ is a Euclidean valuation on D.

title: Definition:Euclidean Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


=== Left-Euclidean ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is left-Euclidean  if and only if :

:( x, z ) âˆˆâ„›( y, z ) âˆˆâ„›( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›

=== Right-Euclidean ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is right-Euclidean  if and only if :

:( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›( x, z ) âˆˆâ„›( y, z ) âˆˆâ„›

=== Euclidean ===

â„› is Euclidean  if and only if  it is both left-Euclidean and right-Euclidean.

title: Definition:Expansion of Topology
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let Ï„_1 and Ï„_2 be topologies on S such that Ï„_1 âŠ†Ï„_2.


Then Ï„_2 is an expansion of Ï„_1.

title: Definition:Decimal Expansion
definition:
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

The decimal expansion of x is the expansion of x in base 10.


x = âŒŠ x âŒ‹ + âˆ‘_j â‰¥ 1d_j/10^j:
:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_10
where:
:s = âŒŠ x âŒ‹, the floor of x
:it is not the case that there exists m âˆˆâ„• such that d_M = 9 for all M â‰¥ m.
(That is, the sequence of digits does not end with an infinite sequence of 9s.)


=== Decimal Point ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ have a decimal expansion:
:n. d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦


The dot that separates the integer part from the fractional part of x is called the decimal point.

That is, it is the radix point when used specifically for a base 10 representation.

=== Size Less than 1 ===
A number x such that | x | < 1 has a units digit which is zero.

Such a number may be expressed either with or without the zero, for example:
:0  568
or:
:568

While both are commonplace, the form with the zero is less prone to the mistake where decimal point is missed when reading it.

=== Decimal Place ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let the decimal expansion of x be:

:x = [ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_10

Then d_k is defined as being the digit in the kth decimal place.

title: Definition:Basis Expansion
definition:
=== Positive Real Numbers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number such that x â‰¥ 0.

Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.


Let us define the recursive sequence:
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„•: n â‰¥ 1: âŸ¨ f_n âŸ© = 
b ( x - âŒŠ x âŒ‹)     : n = 1 

b ( f_n - 1 - âŒŠ f_n - 1âŒ‹)     : n > 1

Then we define:
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„•: n â‰¥ 1: âŸ¨ d_n âŸ© = âŒŠ f_n âŒ‹


It follows from the method of construction and the definition of the floor function that:

:âˆ€ n: 0 â‰¤ f_n < b and hence âˆ€ n: 0 â‰¤ d_n â‰¤ b - 1
:âˆ€ n: f_n = 0  f_n + 1 = 0 and hence d_n + 1 = 0.


Hence we can express x = âŒŠ x âŒ‹ + âˆ‘_j â‰¥ 1d_j/b^j as:
:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b
where:
:s = âŒŠ x âŒ‹
:it is not the case that there exists m âˆˆâ„• such that d_M = b - 1 for all M â‰¥ m.
(That is, the sequence of digits does not end with an infinite sequence of b - 1.)


This is called the expansion of x in base b.

The generic term for such an expression is a basis expansion.


It follows from the Division Theorem that for a given b and x this basis expansion is unique.


=== Termination ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b


Let it be the case that:
:âˆƒ m âˆˆâ„•: âˆ€ k â‰¥ m: d_k = 0

That is, every digit of x in base b after a certain point is zero.

Then x is said to terminate.

=== Recurrence ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a real number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b

Let there be a finite sequence of p digits of x:
:( d_r + 1 d_r + 1â€¦ d_r + p)
such that for all k âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 and for all j âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, p }:
:d_r + j + k p = d_r + j

where p is the smallest p to have this property.

That is, let x be of the form:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1â€¦]_b


That is, ( d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p) repeats from then on, or recurs.

Then x is said to recur.


=== Non-Recurring Part ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a real number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be recurring:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p  d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1â€¦]_b


The non-recurring part of x  is:
:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r ]

=== Recurring Part ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a real number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be recurring:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p  d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1â€¦]_b


The recurring part of x  is:
:[ d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p]


=== Period ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a rational number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b

From Basis Expansion of Rational Number, x either terminates or recurs.


The period of recurrence is the number of digits in the recurring part after which it repeats itself.


Category:Definitions/Basis Expansions

=== Period ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a rational number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b

From Basis Expansion of Rational Number, x either terminates or recurs.


The period of recurrence is the number of digits in the recurring part after which it repeats itself.


Category:Definitions/Basis Expansions

=== Negative Real Numbers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„: x < 0.

We take the absolute value y of x, that is:
:y = | x |

Then we take the expansion of y in base b:
:| s . d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦|_b
where s = âŒŠ y âŒ‹.

Finally, the expansion of x in base b is defined as:
:-[ s . d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b


=== Termination ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b


Let it be the case that:
:âˆƒ m âˆˆâ„•: âˆ€ k â‰¥ m: d_k = 0

That is, every digit of x in base b after a certain point is zero.

Then x is said to terminate.

=== Recurrence ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a real number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b

Let there be a finite sequence of p digits of x:
:( d_r + 1 d_r + 1â€¦ d_r + p)
such that for all k âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 and for all j âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, p }:
:d_r + j + k p = d_r + j

where p is the smallest p to have this property.

That is, let x be of the form:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1â€¦]_b


That is, ( d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p) repeats from then on, or recurs.

Then x is said to recur.


=== Non-Recurring Part ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a real number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be recurring:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p  d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1â€¦]_b


The non-recurring part of x  is:
:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r ]

=== Recurring Part ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a real number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be recurring:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦ d_r d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p  d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p d_r + 1â€¦]_b


The recurring part of x  is:
:[ d_r + 1 d_r + 2â€¦ d_r + p]


=== Period ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a rational number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b

From Basis Expansion of Rational Number, x either terminates or recurs.


The period of recurrence is the number of digits in the recurring part after which it repeats itself.


Category:Definitions/Basis Expansions

=== Period ===
Let b âˆˆâ„•: b â‰¥ 2.

Let x be a rational number.

Let the basis expansion of x in base b be:

:[ s  d_1 d_2 d_3 â€¦]_b

From Basis Expansion of Rational Number, x either terminates or recurs.


The period of recurrence is the number of digits in the recurring part after which it repeats itself.


Category:Definitions/Basis Expansions

title: Definition:Algebraic Expansion
definition:
An (algebraic) expansion is a algebraic expression written as the sum of terms.

The word is also used for the actual process of converting the power of a multinomial, in order to obtain such an expression.

title: Definition:Set Partition/Finite Expansion
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let S = { S_1, S_2, â€¦, S_n } form a partition of S.


Then the representation by such a partition â‹ƒ_k  = 1^n S_k = S is also called a finite expansion of S.


The notations:
:S = S_1 | S_2 |â‹¯| S_n
or:
:S = { S_1 | S_2 |â‹¯| S_n }
are sometimes seen.


Category:Definitions/Set Partitions

title: Definition:Propositional Expansion
definition:
Suppose our universe of discourse consists of the objects ğ—_1, ğ—_2, ğ—_3, â€¦ and so on.


(There may be an infinite number of objects in this universe.)


=== Universal Quantifier ===
Suppose our universe of discourse consists of the objects ğ—_1, ğ—_2, ğ—_3, â€¦ and so on.

Let âˆ€ be the universal quantifier.

What âˆ€ x: P (   )x means is:

:ğ—_1 has property P, and ğ—_2 has property P, and ğ—_3 has property P, and ...

This translates into propositional logic as:

:P (   )ğ—_1 P (   )ğ—_2 P (   )ğ—_3â€¦


This expression of âˆ€ x as a conjunction is known as the propositional expansion of âˆ€ x. 


The propositional expansion for the universal quantifier can exist in actuality only when the number of objects in the universe is finite.

If the universe is infinite, then the propositional expansion can exist only conceptually, and the universal quantifier cannot be eliminated.


Category:Definitions/Propositional Expansions
Category:Definitions/Universal Quantifier

=== Existential Quantifier ===
Suppose our universe of discourse consists of the objects ğ—_1, ğ—_2, ğ—_3, â€¦ and so on.

Let âˆƒ be the existential quantifier.

What âˆƒ x: P (   )x means is:

:At least one of ğ—_1, ğ—_2, ğ—_3, â€¦ has property P.

This means:

:Either ğ—_1 has property P, or ğ—_2 has property P, or ğ—_3 has property P, or ...

This translates into propositional logic as:

:P (   )ğ—_1 P (   )ğ—_2 P (   )ğ—_3â€¦


This expression of âˆƒ x as a disjunction is known as the propositional expansion of âˆƒ x.


The propositional expansion for the existential quantifier can exist in actuality only when the number of objects in the universe is finite.

If the universe is infinite, then the propositional expansion can exist only conceptually, and the existential quantifier cannot be eliminated.


Category:Definitions/Propositional Expansions
Category:Definitions/Existential Quantifier

title: Definition:Extension of Relation
definition:
Let:

:â„›_1 âŠ† X Ã— Y be a relation on X Ã— Y
:â„›_2 âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation on S Ã— T
:X âŠ† S
:Y âŠ† T
:â„›_2 _X Ã— Y be the restriction of â„›_2 to X Ã— Y.


Let â„›_2 _X Ã— Y = â„›_1.


Then â„›_2 extends or is an extension of â„›_1.

title: Definition:Extension of Mapping
definition:
As a mapping is, by definition, also a relation, the definition of an extension of a mapping is the same as that for an extension of a relation:

Let:

:f_1 âŠ† X Ã— Y be a mapping on X Ã— Y
:f_2 âŠ† S Ã— T be a mapping on S Ã— T
:X âŠ† S
:Y âŠ† T
:f_2 _X Ã— Y be the restriction of f_2 to X Ã— Y.


Let f_2 _X Ã— Y = f_1.

That is, let f_1 be a subset of f_2.


Then f_2 extends or is an extension of f_1.

title: Definition:Extension of Operation
definition:
Let (S, âˆ˜) be a magma.

Let (T, âˆ˜_T) be a submagma of (S, âˆ˜), where âˆ˜_T denotes the restriction of âˆ˜ to T.


Then:
: (S, âˆ˜) is an extension of (T, âˆ˜_T)
or
: (S, âˆ˜) extends (T, âˆ˜_T)


We can use the term directly to the operation itself and say:
: âˆ˜ is an extension of âˆ˜_T
or:
: âˆ˜ extends âˆ˜_T

title: Definition:Extension of Sequence
definition:
As a sequence is, by definition, also a mapping, the definition of an extension of a sequence is the same as that for an extension of a mapping:

Let:

:âŸ¨ a_k âŸ©_k âˆˆ A be a sequence on A, where A âŠ†â„•
:âŸ¨ b_k âŸ©_k âˆˆ B be a sequence on B, where B âŠ†â„•
:A âŠ† B
:âˆ€ k âˆˆ A: b_k = a_k

Then âŸ¨ b_k âŸ©_k âˆˆ B extends or is an extension of âŸ¨ a_k âŸ©_k âˆˆ A.


=== Negative Integers ===
A sequence on â„• can be extended to the negative integers.

Let âŸ¨ a_k âŸ©_k âˆˆâ„• and âŸ¨ b_k âŸ©_k âˆˆâ„• be sequences on â„•.

Let a_0 = b_0.


Let c_k be defined as:

:âˆ€ k âˆˆâ„¤: c_k =  a_k     : k â‰¥ 0 
 b_-k :     k â‰¤ 0


Then âŸ¨ c_k âŸ©_k âˆˆâ„¤ extends (or is an extension of) âŸ¨ a_k âŸ©_k âˆˆâ„• to the negative integers.

title: Definition:Extension of Class/Immediate
definition:
Let A and B be classes.

Let B be an extension of A.

B is an immediate extension of A  if and only if  B contains exactly one more element than A.

title: Definition:Field Extension
definition:
Let F be a field.


A field extension over F is a field E where F âŠ† E.

That is, such that F is a subfield of E.


This can be expressed:
:E is a field extension over a field F
or:
:E over F is a field extension 
as:
:E / F is a field extension.  


E / F can be voiced as E over F.

title: Definition:Exterior (Topology)
definition:
Let T be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† T.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† T.


The exterior of H is the complement of the closure of H in T.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† T.


The exterior of H is the interior of the complement of H in T.

title: Definition:Exterior Derivative
definition:
Let an exact n-form Ï‰ be given on an m-manifold, with local coordinates x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_m.

Let a local coordinate expression for Ï‰ be given:

:Ï‰ = f (   )x_1, â€¦, x_m d x_Ï•(   )1âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )2âˆ§â‹¯âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )n

where:
:Ï•: { 1, â€¦, n }â†’{ 1, â€¦, m } is an injection which determines which coordinate vectors Ï‰ acts on.
:âˆ§ denotes the wedge product.


The exterior derivative dÏ‰ is the ( n + 1 )-form defined as:

:dÏ‰ = ( âˆ‘_k  = 1^m âˆ‚ f/âˆ‚ x_k d x_k ) âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )1âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )2âˆ§â€¦âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )n


For inexact forms:
:d(   )a + b = d a + d b

title: Definition:Polygon/External Angle
definition:
Contrary to intuition, the external angle of a vertex of a polygon is not the size of the angle between the sides forming that vertex, as measured outside the polygon.

An external angle is in fact an angle formed by one side of a polygon and a line produced from an adjacent side.

:

While âˆ  AFE is the internal angle of vertex F, the external angle of this vertex is âˆ  EFG.

title: Definition:Transversal (Geometry)/Exterior Angle
definition:
:


An exterior angle of a transversal is an angle which is not between the two lines cut by a transversal.

In the above figure, the exterior angles with respect to the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHE
:âˆ  CJF
:âˆ  BHE
:âˆ  DJF

title: Definition:Exterior Point (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z_0 âˆˆâ„‚.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z_0 âˆˆâ„‚.


z_0 is an exterior point of S  if and only if  z_0 has an Ïµ-neighborhood which is disjoint from S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z_0 âˆˆâ„‚.


z_0 is an exterior point of S  if and only if :
:z_0 is not an interior point of S
and:
:z_0 is not a boundary point of S.

title: Definition:Jordan Curve/Exterior
definition:
Let f: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’â„^2 be a Jordan curve.


It follows from the Jordan Curve Theorem that â„^2 âˆ–Img( f ) is a union of two disjoint connected components, one of which is unbounded.

This unbounded component is called the exterior of f, and is denoted as Ext( f ).

title: Definition:Polygon/External Angle
definition:
Contrary to intuition, the external angle of a vertex of a polygon is not the size of the angle between the sides forming that vertex, as measured outside the polygon.

An external angle is in fact an angle formed by one side of a polygon and a line produced from an adjacent side.

:

While âˆ  AFE is the internal angle of vertex F, the external angle of this vertex is âˆ  EFG.

title: Definition:Transversal (Geometry)/Exterior Angle
definition:
:


An exterior angle of a transversal is an angle which is not between the two lines cut by a transversal.

In the above figure, the exterior angles with respect to the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHE
:âˆ  CJF
:âˆ  BHE
:âˆ  DJF

title: Definition:Root of Number/Extraction
definition: The process of evaluating roots of a given real number is referred to as extraction.

title: Definition:Root of Equation/Extraction
definition: The process of finding roots of a given equation is referred to as extraction.

title: Definition:Planar Graph/Face
definition:
:

The faces of a planar graph are the areas which are surrounded by edges.

In the above, the faces are BCEF, ABF, CFG, AFG and ABCDCEG.


=== Incident ===
:


Let G = ( V, E ) be a planar graph:

Then a face of G is incident to an edge e of G if e is one of those which surrounds the face.

Similarly, a face of G is incident to a vertex v of G if v is at the end of one of those incident edges.


In the above graph, for example, the face BCEF is incident to:
:the edges BC, CE, EF, FB
:the vertices B, C, E, F.

=== Adjacent ===
:

Let G = ( V, E ) be a planar graph.

Two faces of G are adjacent  if and only if  they are both incident to the same edge (or edges).

In the above diagram, BCEF and ABF are adjacent, but BCEF and AFG are not adjacent.


Note that faces which are both incident to the same vertex are not considered adjacent unless they are also both incident to the same edge.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Face
definition: The faces of a polyhedron are the polygons which contain it.

title: Definition:Geometric Figure/Three-Dimensional Figure/Face
definition: The faces of a three-dimensional figure are the surfaces which form its extremities.

title: Definition:Surface (Geometry)
definition:
and:
: 
:An extremity of a solid is a surface.
 â€
 

=== Plane Surface ===
 


=== Side ===
From the definition of surface, it follows that a plane locally separates space into two sides.

Thus the sides of a plane are the parts of that space into which the plane separates it.


Category:Definitions/Surfaces

=== The Plane ===
The plane is the term used for the general plane surface which is infinite in all directions.

=== Regular Surface ===
A subset S âŠ†â„^3 is a regular surface  if and only if  for each p âˆˆ S there exist:
:a neighborhood V âŠ†â„^3 of p
:an open set U âŠ†â„^2
:a surjective mapping ğ± : U â†’ V âˆ© S, written as:
::ğ±(   )u, v := ( x (   )u, v, y (   )u, v, z (   )u, v)

such that:
:(1):    x (   )u, v, y (   )u, v, z (   )u, v are smooth
:(2):   ğ±: U â†’ V âˆ© S is a homeomorphism
:(3): For each q âˆˆ U, the differential d_q ğ±: â„^2 â†’â„^3 of ğ± at q is one-to-one

title: Definition:Polyhedral Angle/Face
definition: Each of the planes bounded by the defining half-lines is known as a face of the polyhedral angle.

title: Definition:Divisor (Algebra)/Integer
definition:
Let ( â„¤, +, Ã—) be the ring of integers.

Let x, y âˆˆâ„¤.


Then x divides y is defined as:
:x \ y âˆƒ t âˆˆâ„¤: y = t Ã— x


=== Aliquot Part ===
An aliquot part of an integer n is a divisor of n which is strictly less than n.

=== Aliquant Part ===
An aliquant part of an integer n is a positive integer which is less than n but is not a divisor of n.

title: Definition:Cartesian Product/Factors
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Let S Ã— T be the cartesian product of S and T.


Then the sets S and T are called the factors of S Ã— T.

title: Definition:Product Topology/Factor Space
definition:
Let âŸ¨( X_i, Ï„_i )  âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of topological spaces where I is an arbitrary index set.

Let ( ğ’³, Ï„) be the product space of âŸ¨( x_i, Ï„_i )  âŸ©_i âˆˆ I.


Each of the topological spaces ( X_i, Ï„_i ) are called the factors of ( ğ’³, Ï„), and can be referred to as factor spaces.

title: Definition:Indexing Set/Family
definition:
Let I and S be sets.

Let x: I â†’ S be an indexing function for S.

Let x_i denote the image of an element i âˆˆ I of the domain I of x.

Let âŸ¨ x_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I denote the set of the images of all the elements i âˆˆ I under x.


The image Img( x ), consisting of the terms âŸ¨ x_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I, along with the indexing function x itself, is called a family of elements of S indexed by I.

title: Definition:Indexing Set/Family of Sets
definition:
Let ğ’® be a set of sets.

Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of elements of ğ’® indexed by I.


Then âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I is referred to as an indexed family of sets.

title: Definition:Indexing Set/Family of Subsets
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let I be an indexing set.

For each i âˆˆ I, let S_i be a corresponding subset of S.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of subsets of S indexed by I.


Then âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I is referred to as an indexed family of subsets (of S by I).

title: Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


( F, +, Ã—) is a field  if and only if :
:(1): the algebraic structure ( F, + ) is an abelian group
:(2): the algebraic structure ( F^*, Ã—) is an abelian group where F^* = F âˆ–{ 0_F }
:(3): the operation Ã— distributes over +.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an integral domain such that every non-zero element a of F has a multiplicative inverse a^-1 such that:
:a Ã— a^-1 = 1_F = a^-1Ã— a
where 1_F denotes the unity of ( F, +, Ã—).


Then ( F, +, Ã—) is a field.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a commutative ring with unity ( F, +, Ã—) such that every non-zero element a of F has a multiplicative inverse:
:a^-1 such that a Ã— a^-1 = 1_F = a^-1Ã— a
where 1_F denotes the unity of ( F, +, Ã—).


Then ( F, +, Ã—) is a field.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a non-trivial division ring whose ring product is commutative.


Then ( F, +, Ã—) is a field.

=== Definition 5 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


( F, +, Ã—) is a field  if and only if  it fulfils the conditions of the field axioms, as follows:
 

=== Addition ===
The distributand + of a field ( F, +, Ã—) is referred to as field addition, or just addition.


=== Additive Group ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field.


The group ( F, + ) is known as the additive group of F.

=== Additive Inverse ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field whose addition operation is +.

Let a âˆˆ R be any arbitrary element of F.


The additive inverse of a is its inverse under addition, denoted -a:

:a + ( -a ) = 0_F

where 0_F is the zero of R.


=== Additive Inverse of Number ===

The concept is often encountered in the context of numbers:
Let F be one of the standard number systems: â„•, â„¤, â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let a âˆˆ F be any arbitrary number.


The additive inverse of a is its inverse under addition, denoted -a:

:a + ( -a ) = 0

=== Product ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field.


The distributive operation Ã— in ( F, +, Ã—) is known as the (field) product.

title: Definition:Field of Relation
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.


The field of â„› is defined as:
:Field( â„›) := { x âˆˆ S: âˆƒ t âˆˆ T: ( x, t ) âˆˆâ„›}âˆª{ x âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: ( s, x ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the union of the domain of â„› with its image.


=== Class Theory ===
 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let â„›âŠ† V Ã— V be a relation in V.


The field of â„› is defined as:
:Field( â„›) := { x âˆˆ V: âˆƒ y âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}âˆª{ y âˆˆ V: âˆƒ x âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the union of the domain of â„› with its image.

title: Definition:Vector Field
definition:
Let F be a field which acts on a region of space S.

Let the point-function giving rise to F be a vector quantity.


Then F is a vector field.


=== Vector Field on Smooth Manifold ===
Let M be a smooth manifold.

Let TM be the tangent bundle of M.

Let T_p M be the tangent space at p âˆˆ M.


Then by the vector field on M we mean the continuous map X : M â†’ TM such that:

:âˆ€ p âˆˆ M : X_p âˆˆ T_p M

title: Definition:Operation/Arity/Finitary
definition:
A finitary operation is an operation which takes a finite number of operands.


Category:Definitions/Operations

title: Definition:Logical Argument/Finitary
definition: A finitary argument is a logical argument which starts with a finite number of axioms, and can be translated into a finite number of statements.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Module
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be a module over R.


Then M is finitely generated  if and only if  there is a generator for M which is finite.

title: Definition:Morphism of Schemes of Finite Type
definition:
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) and ( Y, ğ’ª_Y ) be schemes.

Let f : ( X, ğ’ª_X ) â†’( Y, ğ’ª_Y ) be a morphism of schemes.


f is of finite type  if and only if  f is locally of finite type and quasi-compact.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Algebraic Structure
definition:
Let ( A, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

Let ( A, âˆ˜) have a generator which is finite.


Then ( A, âˆ˜) is finitely generated.

title: Definition:Generator of Monoid
definition:
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid.

Let S âŠ† M.

Let H be the smallest submonoid of M such that S âŠ† H.


Then:
:S is a generator of ( H, âˆ˜)
:S generates ( H, âˆ˜)
:( H, âˆ˜) is the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.


This is written H = âŸ¨ S âŸ©.


If S is a singleton, for example S = { x }, then we can (and usually do) write H = âŸ¨ x âŸ© for H = âŸ¨{ x }âŸ©.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Group
definition:
Let G be a group.


G is finitely generated  if and only if  G has a generator which is finite.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Module
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be a module over R.


Then M is finitely generated  if and only if  there is a generator for M which is finite.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Field Extension
definition:
Let E / F be a field extension.


Then E is said to be finitely generated over F  if and only if , for some Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n âˆˆ E:

:E = F (Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n) 

where F (Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n) is the field in E generated by F âˆª{Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n}.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Algebra
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring.

Let B be an A-algebra.


Then B is finitely generated  if and only if  B has a generator which is finite.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Focus
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a conic section specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant Ïµ

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = Ïµ  p


The point F is known as the focus of ğ’¦.

title: Definition:Ellipse/Focus
definition:
Let K be an ellipse specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant Ïµ such that 0 < Ïµ < 1

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = Ïµ  p


The point F is known as the focus of the ellipse.

title: Definition:Parabola/Focus
definition:
:


Let K be a parabola specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D equals the distance q from P to F:
:p = q


The point F is known as the focus of the parabola.

title: Definition:Hyperbola/Focus
definition:
:


Let K be a hyperbola specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant Ïµ such that Ïµ > 1

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = Ïµ  p


The point F_1 is known as a focus of the hyperbola.

The symmetrically-positioned point F_2 is also a focus of the hyperbola.

title: Definition:FPS/Length/Foot
definition:
The foot is the FPS base unit and an imperial unit of length.


=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Altitude of Triangle/Foot
definition:
Let ABC be a triangle.

Let h_a be the altitude of A:

:


The point at which h_a meets BC (or its production) is the foot of the altitude h_a.


Category:Definitions/Triangles

title: Definition:Right Angle/Perpendicular/Foot
definition:
:


The foot of a perpendicular is the point where it intersects the line to which it is at right angles.

In the above diagram, the point C is the foot of the perpendicular CD.

title: Definition:Free Monoid
definition:
Let S be a set.


A free monoid over S is a monoid M together with a mapping i: S â†’ M, subject to:

:For all monoids N, for all mappings f: S â†’ N, there is a unique monoid homomorphism fÌ…: M â†’ N, such that:

::fÌ…âˆ˜ i = f

This condition is called the universal (mapping) property or UMP of the free monoid over S.


=== Category-Theoretic Formulation ===

Let ğŒğ¨ğ§ be the category of monoids, and let ğ’ğğ­ be the category of sets.

Let |Â·| be the underlying set functor on ğŒğ¨ğ§.


Let M âˆˆğŒğ¨ğ§_0 be a monoid, and let i: S â†’|M| be a mapping.

Then (M, i) is said to be a free monoid over S  if and only if :

:For all N âˆˆğŒğ¨ğ§_0 and f: S â†’|N|âˆˆğ’ğğ­_1, a unique fÌ…âˆˆğŒğ¨ğ§_1 makes the following diagram commute:

::<0em,4em>*ğŒğ¨ğ§ :,
<0em,1em>*ğ’ğğ­ :,

<4em,4em>*+M = "M",
<8em,4em>*+N = "N",
"M";"N" **@. ?>*@> ?*!/_1em/fÌ…,

<4em,1em>*+|M| = "MM",
<8em,1em>*+|N| = "NN",
<4em,-3em>*+S = "S",

"MM";"NN" **@- ?>*@> ?*!/_1em/|fÌ…|,
"S";"MM" **@- ?>*@> ?*!/_1em/i,
"S";"NN" **@- ?>*@> ?*!/^1em/f

This condition is called the universal (mapping) property or UMP of the free monoid over S.

title: Definition:Free Commutative Monoid
definition:
The free commutative monoid on an indexed set X = âŸ¨ X_j: j âˆˆ J âŸ© is the set M of all monomials under the standard multiplication.

 
That is, it is the set M of all finite sequences of X.

title: Definition:Free Group
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A group G is a free group  if and only if  it is isomorphic to the free group on some set.

=== Definition 2 ===
A group G is a free group  if and only if  it has a presentation of the form âŸ¨ S âŸ©, where S is a set.

That is, it has a presentation without relators.

title: Definition:Free Group on Set
definition:
Let X be a set.


A free group on X is a certain X-pointed group, that is, a pair ( F, Î¹) where:
:F is a group
:Î¹ : X â†’ F is a mapping
that can be defined as follows:


=== Definition 1 ===
Let X be a set.


A free group on X is an X-pointed group ( F, Î¹) that satisfies the following universal property:
:For every X-pointed group ( G, Îº) there exists a unique group homomorphism Ï• : F â†’ G such that:
::Ï•âˆ˜Î¹ = Îº
:that is, a morphism of pointed groups F â†’ G.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let X be a set.


The free group on X is the pair ( F, Î¹) such that:
:F is the group of reduced group words on X
:Î¹ : X â†’ F is the canonical injection.

title: Definition:Free Abelian Group
definition:
Let G be an abelian group.


G is a free abelian group  if and only if  the â„¤-module associated with G is a free â„¤-module.

That is, G is a free abelian group  if and only if  it has a basis over â„¤.

title: Definition:Free Abelian Group on Set
definition:
Let â„¤ be the additive group of integers.

Let S be a set.


The free abelian group on S is the pair ( â„¤^( S ), Î¹) where:
* â„¤^( S ) is the direct sum of S copies of â„¤. That is, of the indexed family S â†’{â„¤}
* Î¹ : S â†’â„¤^( S ) is the canonical mapping, which sends s to the mapping Î´_stâˆˆâ„¤^( S ), where Î´ denotes Kronecker delta.

title: Definition:Frequency Curve (Statistics)
definition: A frequency curve is a smooth curve approximating a frequency polygon for a large data set.

title: Definition:Frequency Curve (Probability Theory)
definition: A frequency curve is a curve representing a frequency function.

title: Definition:FrÃ©chet Space (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a FrÃ©chet space or T_1 space  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S such that x  y, both:
::âˆƒ U âˆˆÏ„: x âˆˆ U, y âˆ‰ U
:and:
::âˆƒ V âˆˆÏ„: y âˆˆ V, x âˆ‰ V

That is:
:for any two distinct elements x, y âˆˆ S there exist open sets U, V âˆˆÏ„ such that x is in U but not in V, and y is in V but not in U.


That is:
:( S, Ï„) is T_1  if and only if  every two elements of S are separated.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a FrÃ©chet space or T_1 space  if and only if  all points of S are closed in T.

title: Definition:FrÃ©chet Space (Functional Analysis)
definition:
Let â„^Ï‰ denote the countable-dimensional real Cartesian space.

Let:
:x := âŸ¨ x_i âŸ©_i âˆˆâ„• = ( x_0, x_1, x_2, â€¦)
and:
:y := âŸ¨ y_i âŸ©_i âˆˆâ„• = ( y_0, y_1, y_2, â€¦)
denote arbitrary elements of â„^Ï‰.


Let the distance function d: â„^Ï‰Ã—â„^Ï‰â†’â„ be applied to â„^Ï‰ as:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆâ„^Ï‰: d (   )x, y = âˆ‘_i âˆˆâ„•2^-i| x_i - y_i |1 + | x_i - y_i |


The distance function d is referred to as the FrÃ©chet (product) metric.


The resulting metric space ( â„^Ï‰, d ) is then referred to as the FrÃ©chet (metric) space.

title: Definition:Galois Group of Field Extension
definition:
Let L / K be a field extension.


The Galois group of L / K is the subgroup of the automorphism group of L consisting of field automorphisms that fix K point-wise:
:Gal( L / K ) = {ÏƒâˆˆAut( L ): âˆ€ k âˆˆ K: Ïƒ(   )k = k }


=== Topological Group ===
The notation Gal( L / K ) is also a shorthand for the topological group:
:( Gal( L / K ), Ï„)
where Ï„ is the Krull topology.

title: Definition:Galois Group of Polynomial
definition:
Let P be a polynomial.

The Galois group of P is the symmetry group of the roots of P.

title: Definition:Generated Algebraic Substructure
definition:
Let ( A, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

Let G âŠ† A be any subset of A.


The algebraic substructure generated by G is the smallest substructure of ( A, âˆ˜) which contains G.


It is written âŸ¨ G âŸ©.

title: Definition:Generated Submonoid
definition:
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid whose identity is e_M.

Let S âŠ† M

Let H be the smallest (with respect to set inclusion) submonoid of M such that ( S âˆª{ e_M }) âŠ† H.


Then ( H, âˆ˜) is the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.


This is written H = âŸ¨ S âŸ©.


If S is a singleton, for example S = { x }, then we can (and usually do) write H = âŸ¨ x âŸ© for H = âŸ¨{ x }âŸ©.


=== Generator ===
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid

Let S âŠ† M.

Let ( H, âˆ˜) be the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.

Then S is known as a generator of ( H, âˆ˜).

title: Definition:Generated Subgroup
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.


The subgroup generated by S is the smallest subgroup containing S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.


The subgroup generated by S is the intersection of all subgroups of G containing S.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.

Let S^-1 be the set of inverses of S.


The subgroup generated by S is the set of words on the union S âˆª S^-1.

title: Definition:Generated Normal Subgroup
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ† G be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let G be a group. 

Let S âŠ† G be a subset.


The normal subgroup generated by S, denoted âŸ¨ S^G âŸ©,  is the intersection of all normal subgroups of G containing S.

=== Definition 2 ===
 

Let G be a group. 

Let S âŠ† G be a subset.


The normal subgroup generated by S, denoted âŸ¨ S^G âŸ©,  is the smallest normal subgroup of G containing S:
:âŸ¨ S^G âŸ© = âŸ¨ x S x^-1: x âˆˆ G âŸ©

title: Definition:Generated Submodule
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be an R-module.

Let SâŠ‚ M be a subset of M.


=== R-module ===
Let R be a ring.

Let M = ( G, +, âˆ˜)_R be an R-module.

Let S âŠ‚ M be a subset of M.


The submodule generated by S is the intersection of all submodules of M containing S.

=== Unitary R-Module ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let M be a unitary R-module.

Let SâŠ‚ M be a subset.


The submodule generated by S is the set of all linear combinations of elements of S.

title: Definition:Generated Ideal of Ring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let S âŠ† R be a subset of R.


The ideal generated by S is the smallest ideal of R containing S, that is, the intersection of all ideals containing S.


=== Unitary Rings ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let S âŠ† R be a subset of R.


The ideal generated by S is the set of all two-sided linear combinations of elements of S.

=== Commutative and Unitary Rings ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a commutative ring with unity.

Let S âŠ† R be a subset of R.


The ideal generated by S is the set of all linear combinations of elements of S.

title: Definition:Generator of Algebraic Structure
definition:
Let ( A, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

Let G âŠ‚ A be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===

The subset G is a generator of A  if and only if  A is the algebraic substructure generated by G.


=== Definition 2 ===

The subset G is a generator of A  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ G: x âˆ˜ y âˆˆ A;
:âˆ€ z âˆˆ A: âˆƒ x, y âˆˆ W (   )G: z = x âˆ˜ y
where W (   )G is the set of words of G.

That is, every element in A can be formed as the product of a finite number of elements of G.


If G is such a set, then we can write A = âŸ¨ G âŸ©.

title: Definition:Generator of Subsemigroup
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a semigroup.

:( T, âˆ˜) is the subsemigroup of ( S, âˆ˜) generated by X.

:T = âŸ¨ X âŸ©

title: Definition:Generator of Monoid
definition:
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid.

Let S âŠ† M.

:S is a generator of ( H, âˆ˜)

title: Definition:Generator of Group
definition:
Let ( G, âˆ˜) be a group.

Let S âŠ† G.


Then S is a generator of G, denoted G = âŸ¨ S âŸ©,  if and only if  G is the subgroup generated by S.

title: Definition:Generated Submonoid/Generator
definition:
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid

Let S âŠ† M.

Let ( H, âˆ˜) be the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.

Then S is known as a generator of ( H, âˆ˜).

title: Definition:Generator of Subgroup
definition:
Let ( G, âˆ˜) be a group.

Let S âŠ† G.

Let H be the subgroup generated by S.


Then S is a generator of H, denoted H = âŸ¨ S âŸ©,  if and only if  H is the subgroup generated by S.


=== Definition by Predicate ===
A generator of a subgroup can be defined by a predicate.

For example:

:âŸ¨ x âˆˆ G: x^2 = e âŸ©

defines the subgroup of G generated by the elements of G of order 2.

title: Definition:Genus of Surface
definition:
Let S be a surface.

Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph which is embedded in S.

Let G be such that each of its faces is a simple closed curve.

Let Ï‡(   )G = v - e + f = 2 - 2 p be the Euler characteristic of G where:
:v = | V | is the number of vertices
:e = | E | is the number of edges
:f is the number of faces.

Then p is known as the genus of S.

title: Definition:Genus of Manifold
definition: The genus of a compact topological manifold is the number of handles it has.

title: Definition:Genus of Riemann Surface
definition: The genus of a Riemann surface R is the number of linearly independent holomorphic 1-forms that are defined on R.

title: Definition:Genus of Plane Algebraic Curve
definition:
Let ğ’ be a plane algebraic curve with no singular points.

The genus of ğ’ is defined as:
:d - 1 2
where d denotes the degree of ğ’.


=== Singular Points ===
Let ğ’ be a plane algebraic curve which has 1 or more singular points.

The genus of ğ’ is defined as:
:d - 2 2 - âˆ‘Î´
where:
:d denotes the degree of ğ’
:each term of the summation corresponds to one of the singular points of ğ’
:Î´ is 1 for a double point, but for more complicated singular points is larger.

title: Definition:Grad
definition:
The grad is a measurement of plane angle.

It is defined as 1 100 of a right angle.

title: Definition:Slope
definition:
=== Straight Line ===
Let â„’ be a straight line embedded in a Cartesian plane.

The slope of â„’ is defined as the tangent of the angle that â„’ makes with the x-axis.


=== General Form ===
Let â„’ be a straight line embedded in a Cartesian plane.

Let â„’ be given by the equation:

:l x + m y + n = 0

The slope of â„’ is defined by means of the ordered pair ( -l, m ), where:
:for m  0, Ïˆ = arctan(   )- l m
:for m = 0, Ïˆ = Ï€ 2
where Ïˆ is the angle that â„’ makes with the x-axis.


Thus:
:when m = 0, the slope of â„’ is ( l, 0 ) and â„’ is parallel to the y-axis
:when l = 0, the slope of â„’ is ( 0, m ) and â„’ is parallel to the x-axis.

=== Curve ===
Let P be a point on a curve ğ’ embedded in a Cartesian plane.

The slope of ğ’ at P is defined as the slope of the tangent to ğ’ at P.

title: Definition:Graph Theory
definition:
Graph theory is the branch of mathematics concerned with the structure and properties of graphs.

As a (graph-theoretical) graph has the same conceptual definition as a relation, it follows that there is considerable overlap between the fields of graph theory and relation theory.

title: Definition:Graph (Graph Theory)
definition:
A graph is intuitively defined as a pair consisting of a set of vertices and a set of edges each with a vertex at each end.


=== Vertex ===
 

Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

The vertices (singular: vertex) are the elements of V.

Informally, the vertices are the points that are connected by the edges.


In the above, the vertices are the points A, B, C, D, E, F, G which are marked as dots.

=== Edge ===
 


Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

The edges are the elements of E.


In the above, the edges are AB, AE, BE, CD, CE, CF, DE, DF, FG.


=== Join ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Let u and v be vertices of G.

Let e = u v be an edge of G.


Then e joins the vertices u and v.

title: Definition:Graph (Category Theory)
definition:
A graph is an interpretation of a metagraph within set theory.


Let ğ”˜ be a class of sets.

A metagraph ğ’¢ is a graph  if and only if :

:(1): The objects form a subset vertğ’¢âŠ†ğ”˜

:(2): The morphisms form a subset edgeğ’¢âŠ†ğ”˜

 

If the class ğ”˜ is a set, then morphisms are functions, and the domain and codomain in the definition of a morphism are those familiar from set theory.

If ğ”˜ is a proper class this is not the case, for example the morphisms of ğ’ need not be functions.

title: Definition:Graph of Real Function
definition:
Let U âŠ†â„^n be an open subset of n-dimensional Euclidean space.

Let f : U â†’â„^k be a real function.


The graph Î“(   )f of the function f is the subset of â„^n Ã—â„^k such that:

:Î“(   )f = {( x, y ) âˆˆâ„^n Ã—â„^k: x âˆˆ U âŠ†â„^n : f (   )x = y }

where Ã— denotes the Cartesian product.

title: Definition:Relation/Graph
definition:
Let S Ã— T be the cartesian product of two sets S and T.

Let â„› be a relation on S Ã— T.


The graph of â„› is the set of all ordered pairs ( s, t ) of S Ã— T such that s â„› t:
:ğ’¯(   )â„› = {( s, t ): s â„› t }

title: Definition:Graph (Statistics)
definition:
In the context of statistics, a graph is a word that loosely means a pictorial or diagrammatic presentation of a set of data.


=== Bar Chart ===
A bar chart is a form of graph which consists of a finite set of (usually) vertical bars whose length determines the statistic being communicated.


:

=== Pie Chart ===
A pie chart is a form of graph which consists of a circle divided into sectors whose areas represent the proportion of the corresponding statistic relative to the whole.


:

=== Pictograph ===
A pictograph is a variant of a bar chart whose  bars consist of a number of icons or other pictorial symbols arranged in a (usually) line.

title: Definition:Homogeneous Expression
definition: A homogeneous expression is an algebraic expression in which the variables can be replaced throughout by the product of that variable with a given non-zero constant, and the constant can be extracted as a factor of the resulting expression.

title: Definition:Homogeneous Equation
definition: A homogeneous equation is formed when a homogeneous expression is equated to zero.

title: Definition:Homogeneous Quadratic Equation
definition:
A homogeneous quadratic equation is a quadratic equation in two variables such that each term is of degree 2:

:a x^2 + h x y + b y^2 = 0

title: Definition:Homogeneous (Analytic Geometry)
definition: A straight line or plane is homogeneous  if and only if  it contains the origin.

title: Definition:Homogeneous Cartesian Coordinates
definition:
Let ğ’ denote the Cartesian plane.

Let P = ( x, y ) be an arbitrary point in ğ’.


Let x and y be expressed in the forms:

 
 
 
 

where Z is an arbitrary real number.


P is then determined by the ordered triple ( X, Y, Z ), the terms of which are called its homogeneous Cartesian coordinates.

title: Definition:Homogeneous Polynomial
definition: A homogeneous polynomial is a polynomial whose monomials with nonzero coefficients all have the same total degree.

title: Definition:Group Homomorphism
definition:
Let ( G, âˆ˜) and ( H, * ) be groups.

Let Ï•: G â†’ H be a mapping such that âˆ˜ has the morphism property under Ï•.

:Ï•(   )a âˆ˜ b = Ï•(   )a * Ï•(   )b


Then Ï•: ( G, âˆ˜) â†’( H, * ) is a group homomorphism.

definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) and ( S, âŠ•, * ) be rings.

definition:
Let ( F, +, Ã—) and ( K, âŠ•, âŠ—) be fields.

That is, âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ F:

 
 
 
 


Then Ï•: ( F, +, Ã—) â†’( K, âŠ•, âŠ—) is a field homomorphism.

definition:
Let R, S be rings with unity.

Let F be a subfield of both R and S.


Then a ring homomorphism Ï†: R â†’ S is called an F-homomorphism if:
:âˆ€ a âˆˆ F: Ï•(   )a = a

:I_F is the identity mapping on F.
