title: Definition:Projection (Hilbert Spaces)
definition:
Let H be a Hilbert space.

Let P âˆˆ B (   )H be an idempotent operator.


Then P is said to be a projection  if and only if :

:P = ( Img( P ) )^âŠ¥

where:
:P denotes the kernel of P
:Img( P ) denotes the image of P
:âŠ¥ denotes orthocomplementation.

title: Definition:Orthogonal Projection
definition:
Let H be a Hilbert space.

Let K be a closed linear subspace of H.


Then the orthogonal projection on K is the mapping P_K: H â†’ H defined by

:k = P_K (   )h  k âˆˆ K and d (   )h, k = d (   )h, K

where the latter d signifies distance to a set.


That P_K is indeed a mapping is proved on Orthogonal Projection is Mapping.

 

 
 

The name orthogonal projection stems from the fact that ( h - P_K (   )h ) âŠ¥ K.

title: Definition:Subfield/Proper Subfield
definition:
Let ( K, +, âˆ˜) be a subfield of ( F, +, âˆ˜).


Then ( K, +, âˆ˜) is a proper subfield of ( F, +, âˆ˜)  if and only if  K  F.


That is, ( K, +, âˆ˜) is a proper subfield of ( F, +, âˆ˜)  if and only if :
:(1):   ( K, +, âˆ˜) is a subfield of ( F, +, âˆ˜)
:(2):    K is a proper subset of F.

title: Definition:Proper Subgroup
definition:
Let ( G, âˆ˜) be a group.


Then ( H, âˆ˜) is a proper subgroup of ( G, âˆ˜)  if and only if :

: (1):   ( H, âˆ˜) is a subgroup of ( G, âˆ˜)
: (2):    H  G, i.e. H âŠ‚ G.


The notation H < G, or G > H, means:
: H is a proper subgroup of G.


If H is a subgroup of G, but it is not specified whether H = G or not, then we write H â‰¤ G, or G â‰¥ H.


=== Non-Trivial Proper Subgroup ===
Let ( G, âˆ˜) be a group.

Let ( H, âˆ˜) be a subgroup of ( G, âˆ˜) such that { e }âŠ‚ H âŠ‚ G, that is:
:H { e }
:H  G

Then ( H, âˆ˜) is a non-trivial proper subgroup of ( G, âˆ˜).

title: Definition:Proper Subring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.


A subring S of R is a proper subring of R  if and only if  S is neither the null ring nor R itself.

title: Definition:Subcontinuum/Proper Subcontinuum
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a continuum in T.


Let K be a subcontinuum of H such that K  H.

That is, let K be a proper subset of H.


Then K is a proper subcontinuum of H.

title: Definition:Vector Subspace
definition:
Let K be a division ring.

Let ( S, +, âˆ˜)_K be a K-algebraic structure with one operation.


Let T be a closed subset of S.

Let ( T, +_T, âˆ˜_T )_K be a K-vector space where:
:+_T is the restriction of + to T Ã— T and
:âˆ˜_T is the restriction of âˆ˜ to K Ã— T.


Then ( T, +_T, âˆ˜_T )_K is a (vector) subspace of ( S, +, âˆ˜)_K.


=== Proper Subspace ===
Let K be a division ring.

Let ( S, +, âˆ˜)_K be a K-algebraic structure with one operation.

Let ( T, +_T, âˆ˜_T )_K be a vector subspace of ( S, +, âˆ˜)_K.


If T is a proper subset of S, then ( T, +_T, âˆ˜_T )_K is a proper (vector) subspace of ( S, +, âˆ˜)_K.

=== Hilbert Spaces ===
Let K be a division ring.

Let (S, +, âˆ˜)_K be a K-algebraic structure with one operation.


Let T be a closed subset of S.

Let (T, +_T, âˆ˜_T)_K be a K-vector space where:
: +_T is the restriction of + to T Ã— T and
: âˆ˜_T is the restriction of âˆ˜ to K Ã— T.


Then (T, +_T, âˆ˜_T)_K is a (vector) subspace of (S, +, âˆ˜)_K.


When considering Hilbert spaces, one wants to deal with projections onto subspaces.

These projections however require the linear subspace to be closed in topological sense in order to be well-defined.

Therefore, in treatises of Hilbert spaces, one encounters the terminology linear manifold for the concept of vector subspace defined above.

The adapted definition of linear subspace is then that it is a topologically closed linear manifold.

title: Definition:Submodule/Proper
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜_G )_R be an R-module.

Let ( H, +_H, âˆ˜_H )_R be a submodule of ( G, +_G, âˆ˜_G )_R.

Let H be a proper subset of G.


Then ( H, +_H, âˆ˜_H )_R is a proper submodule of ( G, +_G, âˆ˜_G )_R.

title: Definition:Pseudoprime (Number Theory)
definition:
A pseudoprime is a composite number which exhibit behaviour which in some way is more characteristic of a prime number.


=== Fermat Pseudoprime ===
Let q be a composite number such that âˆƒ n âˆˆ N: n^q â‰¡ n  q.

Then q is a Fermat pseudoprime to base n. 


=== Fermat Pseudoprimes to base 2 (Poulet Numbers) ===

Fermat pseudoprimes to base 2 are known as Poulet numbers:

Let q be a composite number such that 2^q â‰¡ 2  q.

Then q is a Poulet number. 


=== Sequence of Poulet Numbers ===


=== Fermat Pseudoprimes to base 3 ===
Let q be a composite number such that 3^q â‰¡ 3  q.

Then q is a Fermat pseudoprime to base 3. 


=== Sequence ===


=== Fermat Pseudoprimes to base 4 ===
Let q be a composite number such that 4^q â‰¡ 4  q.

Then q is a Fermat pseudoprime to base 4. 


=== Sequence ===


=== Fermat Pseudoprimes to base 5 ===
Let q be a composite number such that 5^q â‰¡ 5  q.

Then q is a Fermat pseudoprime to base 5. 


=== Sequence ===

title: Definition:Pseudoprime (Order Theory)
definition:
Let L = ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be an up-complete lattice.

Let p âˆˆ S.


Then p is pseudoprime  if and only if 
:there exists a prime ideal P in L: p = sup P

definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.

A pullback of f and g is a commutative diagram:

::P

In this situation, p_1 is called the pullback of f along g and may be denoted as g^* f.

Similarly, p_2 is called the pullback of g along f and may be denoted f^* g.

title: Definition:Pullback of Quotient Group Isomorphism
definition:
Let G, H be groups.

title: Definition:Compact Space/Topology
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is compact  if and only if  every open cover for S has a finite subcover.

=== Definition 2 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is compact  if and only if  it satisfies the Finite Intersection Axiom.

=== Definition 3 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is compact  if and only if  Ï„ has a sub-basis â„¬ such that:
:from every cover of S by elements of â„¬, a finite subcover of S can be selected.

=== Definition 4 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is compact  if and only if  every filter on S has a limit point in S.

=== Definition 5 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is compact  if and only if  every ultrafilter on S converges.

title: Definition:Quasi-Compact Scheme
definition:
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) be a scheme.


Then ( X, ğ’ª_X ) is quasi-compact  if and only if  X is compact.

title: Definition:Quasi-Compact Morphism of Schemes
definition:
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) and ( Y, ğ’ª_Y ) be schemes.

Let f : ( X, ğ’ª_X ) â†’( Y, ğ’ª_Y ) be a morphism of schemes.


f is quasi-compact  if and only if  for all quasi-compact open subsets U âŠ‚ Y, the set f^-1(   )U âŠ‚ X is quasi-compact.

title: Definition:Circle/Radius
definition:
:

A radius of a circle is a straight line segment whose endpoints are the center and the circumference of the circle.

In the above diagram, the line AB is a radius.

title: Definition:Sphere/Geometry/Radius
definition: A radius of a sphere is a straight line segment whose endpoints are the center and the surface of the sphere.

title: Definition:Polygon/Regular/Long Radius
definition:
The long radius of a regular polygon P is defined as the distance from the center of P to one of its vertices.

:

In the above, the length of OA is the long radius of the regular polygon.

title: Definition:Regular Polygon/Apothem
definition:
The apothem of a regular polygon P is defined as the perpendicular distance from the center of P to one of its sides.

:

In the above, the length of OM is the apothem of the regular polygon.

title: Definition:Radius of Curvature
definition:
The radius of curvature of a curve C at a point P is defined as the reciprocal of the absolute value of its curvature:

:Ï =  1 | k |


=== Cartesian Coordinates ===
Let C be a curve defined by a real function which is twice differentiable.

Let C be embedded in a cartesian plane.


The radius of curvature of C at a point P can be expressed in cartesian coordinates as:
:Ï = |( 1 + y'^2 )^3/2y' '|

where:
 
 
 
 

=== Parametric Cartesian Form ===
Let C be a curve defined by a real function which is twice differentiable.

Let C be embedded in a cartesian plane and defined by the parametric equations:
:x = x (   )t 
 y = y (   )t


The radius of curvature Ï of C at a point P = ( x, y ) is given by:

:Ï = ( x'^2 + y'^2 )^3/2| x' y' ' - y' x' ' |
where:
:x' = d xd t is the derivative of x   t at P
:y' = d yd t is the derivative of y   t at P
:x' ' and y' ' are the second derivatives of x and y   t at P.

title: Definition:Position Vector
definition:
Let P be a point in a given frame of reference whose origin is O.

The position vector ğ« of P is the displacement vector of P from O.


=== Notation ===

title: Definition:Range of Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation, or (usually) a mapping (which is, of course, itself a relation).


The range of â„›, denoted  is defined as one of two things, depending on the source.

On   it is denoted Rng( â„›), but this may be non-standard.


=== Range as Codomain ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation, or (usually) a mapping (which is, of course, itself a relation).


The range of â„› can be defined as T.

As such, it is the same thing as the term codomain of â„›.

=== Range as Image ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation, or (usually) a mapping (which is, of course, itself a relation).


The range of â„› can be defined as:
:Rng( â„›) = { t âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›}

Defined like this, it is the same as what is defined as the image of â„›.

title: Definition:Real Function/Range
definition:
Let S âŠ†â„.

Let f: S â†’â„ be a real function.

The range of f is the set of values that the dependent variable can take.


That is, it is the image set of f.

title: Definition:Range (Statistics)
definition:
Range is a measure of dispersion of a set of observations.


Let S be a set of observations of a quantitative variable.

The range of S is defined as:
:R (   )S := max(   )S - min(   )S

where max(   )S and min(   )S are the greatest value of S and the least value of S respectively.


=== Infinite Range ===
For certain random variables, it is possible that the range may be infinite, in the sense that it is technically unbounded.

title: Definition:Rank (Set Theory)
definition:
Let A be a set.

Let V denote the von Neumann hierarchy.


Then the rank of A is the smallest ordinal x such that A âˆˆ V (   )x + 1, given that x exists.

title: Definition:Rank/Matrix
definition:
Let K be a field.

Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix over K.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let K be a field.

Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix over K.


The rank of ğ€, denoted Ï(   )ğ€, is the dimension of the subspace of K^m generated by the columns of ğ€.


That is, it is the dimension of the column space of ğ€.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let K be a field.

Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix over K.


Let ğ€ be converted to echelon form ğ.

Let ğ have exactly k non-zero rows.

Then the rank of ğ€, denoted Ï(   )ğ€, is k.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let K be a field.

Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix over K.


The rank of ğ€, denoted Ï(   )ğ€, is the largest number of elements in a linearly independent set of rows of ğ€.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let K be a field.

Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix over K.


The rank of ğ€, denoted Ï(   )ğ€, is the largest number of elements in a linearly independent set of columns of ğ€.

=== Definition 5 ===
Let K be a field.

Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix over K.


The rank of ğ€, denoted Ï(   )ğ€, is the order of the largest non-zero determinant that can be extracted from ğ€ by selecting rows and columns.

title: Definition:Rank/Linear Transformation
definition:
Let Ï• be a linear transformation from one vector space to another.

Let the image of Ï• be finite-dimensional.


Then its dimension is called the rank of Ï• and is denoted Ï(   )Ï•.

title: Definition:Rank of Entire Function
definition:
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be an entire function.

Let âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© be the sequence of non-zero zeroes of f, repeated according to multiplicity.


The rank of f is:
:the smallest positive integer p â‰¥ 0 for which the series âˆ‘_n  = 1^âˆ| a_n |^-p - 1 converges
or:
:âˆ if there is no such integer.


If f has finitely many zeroes, its rank is 0.

title: Definition:Rank of Free Group
definition:
Let F be a free group.


The rank of F is the dimension of its abelianization as a module over â„¤.

title: Definition:Rank (Statistics)
definition:
Let S be a set of sample data which has been assigned a ranking â„›.

The index of a given x âˆˆ S according to â„› is known as its rank.

title: Definition:Rank Correlation Coefficient
definition:
A rank correlation coefficient is a statistical coefficient which measures the degree of agreement of a set of subjective rankings.


=== Spearman's Rank Correlation Coefficient ===
Let X and Y be two rankings assigned to the same set of entities.

The Spearman's rank correlation coefficient is the Pearson correlation coefficient between X and Y.

=== Kendall's Rank Correlation Coefficient ===
Kendall's rank correlation coefficient is a test for consistency of 2 sets of rankings âŸ¨ a âŸ©_n and âŸ¨ b âŸ©_n on a set S of n objects.


The set R of ordered pairs ( a_i, b_i ) is assembled:
:R = {( a_i, b_i ): i âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, n }}
and ordered according to âŸ¨ a âŸ©.

The number Q of elements of S out of ranking order from âŸ¨ b âŸ© is counted.

Kendall's rank correlation coefficient is then formed:
:K = 1 - 4 Qn ( n + 1 )
which takes values between -1 (complete disagreement) and +1 (complete agreement).

Complete disagreement happens when âŸ¨ a âŸ©_n is in reverse order to âŸ¨ b âŸ©_n.

=== Kendall's Coefficient of Concordance ===
Kendall's coefficient of concordance is a test for consistency of more than 2 sets of rankings.

Let m judges independently award ranks 1 to n to a set of n competitors.

Let s_i be the sum of the rankings awarded to competitor i.

The mean M of the values of s_i is 1 2 m ( n + 1 ).

The sum of the squares of the deviations from M is given by:
:S = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n ( s_i - M )^2

and Kendall's coefficient of concordance is given by:
:W = 12 Sm^2 n ( n^2 - 1 )


=== Kendall's Coefficient of Concordance is between 0 and 1 ===

title: Definition:Line/Infinite Half-Line
definition:
An infinite half-line is a line which terminates at an endpoint at one end, but has no such endpoint at the other.


=== Start Point ===
The endpoint of an infinite half-line is a known as its start point.


Category:Definitions/Lines

title: Definition:Ray (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


A ray in T is an embedding R_>0â†’ S.

Category:Definitions/Topology

title: Definition:Ray (Order Theory)
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.

Let â‰º be the reflexive reduction of â‰¼.

Let a âˆˆ S be any point in S.


=== Open Ray ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.

Let â‰º be the reflexive reduction of â‰¼.

Let a âˆˆ S be any point in S.


The following sets are called open rays or open half-lines:

:{ x âˆˆ S: a â‰º x } (the strict upper closure of a), denoted a^â‰»
:{ x âˆˆ S: x â‰º a } (the strict lower closure of a), denoted a^â‰º.

=== Closed Ray ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.

Let a âˆˆ S be any point in S.


The following sets are called closed rays or closed half-lines:

:{ x âˆˆ S: a â‰¼ x } (the upper closure of a), denoted a^â‰½
:{ x âˆˆ S: x â‰¼ a } (the lower closure of a), denoted a^â‰¼.

=== Upward-Pointing Ray ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.

Let â‰º be the reflexive reduction of â‰¼.

Let a âˆˆ S be any point in S.


An upward-pointing ray is a ray which is bounded below:

:an open ray a^â‰»:= { x âˆˆ S: a â‰º x }
:a closed ray a^â‰½: { x âˆˆ S: a â‰¼ x }

=== Downward-Pointing Ray ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.

Let â‰º be the reflexive reduction of â‰¼.

Let a âˆˆ S be any point in S.


A downward-pointing ray is a ray which is bounded above:

:an open ray a^â‰º := { x âˆˆ S: x â‰º a }
:a closed ray a^â‰¼ : { x âˆˆ S: x â‰¼ a }

title: Definition:Realization of Stochastic Process
definition:
Let S be a stochastic process.

Let T be a time series of observations of S which has been acquired as S evolves, according to the underlying probability distribution of S.


Then T is referred to as a realization of S.


Thus we can regard the observation z_t at some timestamp t, for example t = 25, as the realization of a random variable with probability mass function p (   )z_t.

Similarly the observations z_t_1 and z_t_2 at times t_1 and t_2 can be regarded as the realizations of two random variables with joint probability mass function p (   )z_t_1 and p (   )z_t_2.


Similarly, the observations making an equispaced time series can be described by an N-dimensional random variable ( z_1, z_2, â€¦, z_N ) with associated probability mass function p (   )z_1, z_2, â€¦, z_N.

title: Definition:Type
definition:
Let â„³ be an â„’-structure.

Let A be a subset of the universe of â„³.

Let â„’_A be the language consisting of â„’ along with constant symbols for each element of A.

Viewing â„³ as an â„’_A-structure by interpreting each new constant as the element for which it is named, let Th_A (   )â„³ be the set of â„’_A-sentences satisfied by â„³.


An n-type over A is a set p of â„’_A-formulas in n free variables such that p âˆªTh_A (   )â„³ is satisfiable by some â„’_A-structure.

 


=== Complete Type ===

We say that an n-type p is complete (over A)  if and only if :
:for every â„’_A-formula Ï• in n free variables, either Ï•âˆˆ p or Ï•âˆ‰ p.


The set of complete n-types over A is often denoted by S_n^â„³(   )A.


Given an n-tuple bÌ… of elements from â„³, the type of bÌ… over A is the complete n-type consisting of those â„’_A-formulas Ï•(   )x_1, â€¦, x_n such that â„³Ï•(   )bÌ….

It is often denoted by tp^â„³(   )bÌ… / A.


=== Realization ===

Given an â„’_A-structure ğ’©, a type p is realized by an element bÌ… of ğ’©  if and only if :
:âˆ€Ï•âˆˆ p: ğ’©Ï•(   )bÌ….

Such an element bÌ… of ğ’© is a realization of p.


=== Omission ===

We say that ğ’© omits p  if and only if  p is not realized in ğ’©.

Then p is an omission from ğ’©.

title: Definition:Reducible Fraction
definition:
Let q =  a b be a vulgar fraction.

Then q is defined as being reducible  if and only if  q is not in canonical form.

That is,  if and only if  there exists r âˆˆâ„¤: r  1 such that r is a divisor of both a and b.

Such a fraction can therefore be reduced by dividing both a and b by r.

title: Definition:Reducible Polynomial
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let K be a field.


A reducible polynomial over K is a nonconstant polynomial over K that can be expressed as the product of two polynomials over K of smaller degree.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let K be a field.


A reducible polynomial over K is a polynomial over K that can be expressed as the product of two nonconstant polynomials.

title: Definition:Reducible Linear Representation
definition:
Let Ï: G â†’GL( V ) be a linear representation.


Ï is reducible  if and only if  there exists a non-trivial proper vector subspace W of V such that:
:âˆ€ g âˆˆ G: Ï(   )g (   )W âŠ† W


That is, such that W is invariant for every linear operator in the set {Ï(   )g: g âˆˆ G }.

title: Definition:Reducible G-Module
definition:
Let M be a G-module.

Then M is reducible  if and only if  the corresponding linear representation is reducible.

title: Definition:Mapping Reduction
definition:
Let x3a3, x3a3' be finite sets.

Let:

 
 
 
 

be sets of finite strings over x3a3 and x3a3' respectively, where:
:x3a3^* denotes the set of all finite strings over the alphabet x3a3.

Let f : x3a3^* â†’x3a3'^* be a computable function such that, for all w âˆˆx3a3^*:
:w âˆˆ L  f (   )w âˆˆ L'

Then, f is a mapping reduction from L to L'.


If any such f exists, then L is mapping reducible to L', which is denoted as:
:L â‰¤_m L'

title: Definition:Reduction Formula (Calculus)
definition:
Let f: â„Ã—â„¤_â‰¥ 0: â„ be a Darboux integrable real-valued function on â„Ã—â„•.

Let:
:I_n = âˆ« f (   )x, n d x
for some n âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0.


A reduction formula is a recurrence relation of the form:
:I_k = g (   )I_n
such that k < n.


That is, it is a technique to reduce the integer parameter in the integrand in order to allow evaluation of the integral at, usually, n = 0 or n = 1.

This technique relies upon the supposition that f (   )x, 0 or f (   )x, 1 can be integrated directly.

title: Definition:Reduction Formula (Trigonometry)
definition: A reduction formula in the context of trigonometry is a formula that gives a trigonometric function of an angle plus or minus one or more right angles.

title: Definition:Residue (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be a complex function.

Let z_0 âˆˆ U âŠ‚â„‚ such that f is analytic in U âˆ–{ z_0 }.


Then by Existence of Laurent Series, there is a Laurent series:
:âˆ‘_j  = -âˆ^âˆ a_j ( z - z_0 )^j
such that the sum converges to f in U - { z_0 }.  


The residue at a point z = z_0 of f is defined as a_-1 in that Laurent series.

It is denoted Res( f,   )z_0 or just Res(   )z_0 when f is understood.

title: Definition:Residue (Number Theory)
definition:
Let m, n âˆˆâ„• be natural numbers.

Let a âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer such that a is not divisible by m.

Then a is a residue of m of order n  if and only if :
:âˆƒ x âˆˆâ„¤: x^n â‰¡ a  m
where â‰¡ denotes modulo congruence.


=== Nonresidue ===
Let m, n âˆˆâ„• be natural numbers.

Let a âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer such that a is not divisible by m.


a is a nonresidue of m of order n  if and only if  there does not exist x âˆˆâ„¤ such that:
:x^n â‰¡ a  m

where â‰¡ denotes modulo congruence.

title: Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)/Residue
definition:
Let m âˆˆâ„¤_ 0 be a non-zero integer.

Let a, b âˆˆâ„¤.

Let a â‰¡ b  m.


Then b is a residue of a modulo m.

Residue is another word for remainder, and is any integer congruent to a modulo m.

title: Definition:Residue Field of Local Ring
definition:
Let R be a commutative local ring.

Let m be its maximal ideal.


The residue field of R is the quotient ring R / m.

title: Definition:Vector Sum
definition:
Let ğ® and ğ¯ be vector quantities of the same physical property.


=== Component Definition ===
Let ğ® and ğ¯ be vector quantities of the same physical property.


Let ğ® and ğ¯ be represented by their components considered to be embedded in a real n-space:

 
 
 
 


Then the (vector) sum of ğ® and ğ¯ is defined as:
:ğ® + ğ¯ := ( u_1 + v_1, u_2 + v_2, â€¦, u_n + v_n )


Note that the + on the   is conventional addition of numbers, while the + on the   takes on a different meaning.

The distinction is implied by which operands are involved.

=== Triangle Law ===
Let ğ® and ğ¯ be vector quantities of the same physical property.

Let ğ® and ğ¯ be represented by arrows embedded in the plane such that:

:ğ® is represented by Aâƒ—Bâƒ—
:ğ¯ is represented by Bâƒ—Câƒ—

that is, so that the initial point of ğ¯ is identified with the terminal point of ğ®.

:

Then their (vector) sum ğ® + ğ¯ is represented by the arrow Aâƒ—Câƒ—.

title: Definition:Eliminant
definition:
Let S be a system of simultaneous linear equations.

The eliminant of S is the determinant formed by removing the variables between the equations.

title: Definition:Retraction (Category Theory)
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.

Let f: C â†’ D be a morphism of ğ‚.


A retraction of f is a morphism g: D â†’ C such that:

:g âˆ˜ f = id_C

where id_C denotes the identity morphism on C.


=== Retract ===
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.

Let f: C â†’ D be a morphism.

Let g: D â†’ C be a retraction of f.


Then D is said to be a retract of C.

title: Definition:Retraction (Topology)
definition:
Let T_1 = ( S_1, Ï„_1 ) be a topological space.

Let T_2 = ( S_2, Ï„_2 ) be a topological subspace of T_1.

That is:
:S_2 âŠ† S_1

Let f: S_1 â†’ S_2 be a mapping.


Then f is a retraction of T_1  if and only if :
:âˆ€ s âˆˆ S_2: f (   )s = s

title: Definition:Right (Direction)
definition:
The direction right is that way:
:â†’

title: Definition:Right Angle
definition:
A right angle is an angle that is equal to one quarter of a full angle.

That is, equal to one half of a straight angle.


=== Measurement of Right Angle ===

title: Definition:Right Hand Side
definition:
In an equation:
:Expression 1 = Expression 2
the term Expression 2 is the right hand side.

title: Definition:Right-Total Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.


Then â„› is right-total  if and only if :
:âˆ€ t âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›


That is,  if and only if  every element of T is related to by some element of S.


That is,  if and only if :
:Img( â„›) = T
where Img( â„›) denotes the image of â„›.

title: Definition:Right Quasi-Reflexive Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is right quasi-reflexive  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›( y, y ) âˆˆâ„›

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is right quasi-reflexive  if and only if :

:âˆ€ y âˆˆImg( â„›): ( y, y ) âˆˆâ„›

where Img( â„›) denotes the image set of â„›.

title: Definition:Euclidean Relation/Right-Euclidean
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is right-Euclidean  if and only if :

:( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›( x, z ) âˆˆâ„›( y, z ) âˆˆâ„›

title: Definition:Right Inverse Mapping
definition:
Let S, T be sets where S âˆ…, that is, S is not empty.

Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.


Let g: T â†’ S be a mapping such that:
:f âˆ˜ g = I_T
where:
:f âˆ˜ g denotes the composite mapping g followed by f
:I_T is the identity mapping on T.


Then g: T â†’ S is called a right inverse (mapping) of f.

title: Definition:Inverse (Abstract Algebra)/Right Inverse
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a monoid whose identity is e_S.

An element x_R âˆˆ S is called a right inverse of x  if and only if :
:x âˆ˜ x_R = e_S

title: Definition:Inverse Matrix/Right
definition:
Let m, n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a (strictly) positive integer.


Let ğ€ = [ a ]_m n be a matrix of order m Ã— n.

Let ğ = [ b ]_n m be a matrix of order n Ã— m such that:
:ğ€ğ = ğˆ_m

where ğˆ_m denotes the unit matrix of order m.


Then ğ is known as a right inverse (matrix) of ğ€.

title: Definition:Root of Number
definition:
Let x, y âˆˆâ„_â‰¥ 0 be positive real numbers.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer such that n  0.


Then y is the positive nth root of x  if and only if :
:y^n = x

and we write:
:y = âˆš(x)


Using the power notation, this can also be written:
:y = x^1/n


When n = 2, we write y = âˆš(x) and call y the positive square root of x.

When n = 3, we write y = âˆš(x) and call y the cube root of x.


Note the special case where x = 0 = y:
:0 = âˆš(0)


=== Index ===
Let âˆš(x) denote the nth root of x.

The number n is known as the index of the root.


If n is not specified, that is âˆš(x) is presented, this means the square root.

=== Extraction of Root ===
The process of evaluating roots of a given real number is referred to as extraction.

title: Definition:Root of Equation
definition:
Let E (   )x be a mathematical expression representing an equation which is dependent upon a variable x.

A root of E (   )x is a constant which, when substituted for x in E (   )x, makes E (   )x a true statement.


=== Extraction of Root ===
The process of finding roots of a given equation is referred to as extraction.

title: Definition:Root of Mapping
definition:
Let f: R â†’ R be a mapping on a ring R.

Let x âˆˆ R.


Then the values of x for which f (   )x = 0_R are known as the roots of the mapping f.

title: Definition:Root of Polynomial
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let f âˆˆ R [ x ] be a polynomial over R.


A root in R of f is an element x âˆˆ R for which f (   )x = 0, where f (   )x denotes the image of f under the evaluation homomorphism at x.

title: Definition:Rooted Tree/Root Node
definition:
Let T be a rooted tree.

The root node of T is the node of T which is distinguished from the others by being the ancestor node of every node of T.

title: Definition:Labeled Tree for Propositional Logic/Hypothesis Set
definition:
Let ( T, ğ‡, Î¦) be a labeled tree for propositional logic.


The countable set ğ‡ of WFFs of propositional logic is called the hypothesis set.

The elements of ğ‡ are known as hypothesis WFFs.


The hypothesis set ğ‡ is considered to be attached to the root node of T.

title: Definition:Rotation (Geometry)
definition:
A rotation in the context of Euclidean geometry is an isometry on a Euclidean space â„^n as follows.

A rotation is defined usually for either:
:n = 2, representing the plane
or:
:n = 3, representing ordinary space.


=== Rotation in the Plane ===
A rotation r_Î± in the plane is an isometry on the Euclidean Space Î“ = â„^2 as follows.


Let O be a distinguished point in Î“, which has the property that:
:r_Î±(   )O = O

That is, O maps to itself.


Let P âˆˆÎ“ such that P  O.

Let OP be joined by a straight line.

Let a straight line OP' be constructed such that:
:(1):    OP' = OP
:(2): âˆ  POP' = Î± such that OP â†’ OP' is in the anticlockwise direction:

:


Then:
:r_Î±(   )P = P'

Thus r_Î± is a rotation (in the plane) of (angle) Î± about (the axis) O.

=== Rotation in Space ===
A rotation r_Î¸ in space is an isometry on the Euclidean Space Î“ = â„^3 as follows.


Let AB be a distinguished straight line in Î“, which has the property that:
:âˆ€ P âˆˆ AB: r_Î¸(   )P = P

That is, all points on AB map to themselves.


Let P âˆˆÎ“ such that P âˆ‰ AB.

Let a straight line be constructed from P to O on AB such that OP is perpendicular to AB.

Let a straight line OP' be constructed perpendicular to AB such that:
:(1):    OP' = OP
:(2):   âˆ  POP' = Î¸ such that OP â†’ OP' is in the anticlockwise direction:


:


Then:
:r_Î¸(   )P = P'

Thus r_Î¸ is a rotation (in space) of (angle) Î¸ about (the axis) O.


 

=== Axis of Rotation ===
Let r_Î¸ be a rotation in the Euclidean Space Î“ = â„^n.


The set A of points in Î“ such that:
:âˆ€ P âˆˆ A: r_Î¸(   )P = P

is called the axis of rotation of r_Î¸.

=== Vector Form ===
A space rotation r_Î¸ can be expressed as an axial vector ğ«_Î¸ such that:
:the direction of ğ«_Î¸ is defined to be its axis of rotation
:the length of ğ«_Î¸ specifies its angle of rotation of ğ«_Î¸ to an appropriate scale.

:

=== Right-Hand Rule ===
Let ğ• be an axial vector acting with respect to an axis of rotation R.

Consider a right hand with its fingers curled round R so that the fingers are pointed in the direction of rotation of ğ• around R.


The right-hand rule is the convention that the direction of ğ• is the direction in which the thumb is pointing:


:

title: Definition:Rotation (Permutation Theory)
definition:
Let ( a_1, â€¦, a_n ) be a string over an alphabet A.

A rotation is a mapping r: A^n â†’ A^n given by:

:( a_1, â€¦, a_n ) â†¦( a_Ï•(   )1, â‹¯, a_Ï•(   )n)

where Ï• is a permutation on n letters.

Category:Definitions/Permutations on n Letters

title: Definition:Truth Table/Row
definition:
A row of a truth table is one of the horizontal lines that consists of instances of the symbols T and F.

Each row contains the truth values of each of the boolean interpretations of the statement forms according to the propositional variables that comprise them.

There are as many rows in a truth table as there are combinations of T and F for all the propositional variables that constitute the statement forms.

title: Definition:Matrix/Row
definition:
Let ğ€ be an m Ã— n matrix.

For each i âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]m, the rows of ğ€ are the ordered n-tuples:
:r_i = ( a_i 1, a_i 2, â€¦, a_i n)

where r_i is called the ith row of ğ€.


A row of an m Ã— n matrix can also be treated as a 1 Ã— n row matrix in its own right:
:r_i = [ a_i 1 a_i 2     â‹¯ a_i n ]
for i = 1, 2, â€¦, m.

title: Definition:Latin Square/Row
definition:
Let ğ‹ be a Latin square.

The rows of ğ‹ are the lines of elements reading across the page.

title: Definition:Run (Statistics)
definition: A run is a sequence of observations which follows some specified pattern.

title: Definition:Run (Analytic Geometry)
definition:
Let P_1 = ( x_1, y_1 ) and P_2 = ( x_2, y_2 ) be points in the Cartesian plane.


The run from P_1 to P_2 is the difference between their abscissae:
:x_2 - x_1

title: Definition:Saddle Point (Game Theory)
definition:
Let G be a two-player zero-sum game.

Let G be defined by a payoff table T.


Let E be an entry in T such that:
:E is the smallest entry in its row
:E is the largest entry in its column.


Then E is a saddle point of G.

title: Definition:Saddle Point (Geometry)
definition:
Let ğ’® be a surface defined by the Cartesian equation z = f (   )x, y.

Let P be a point on ğ’® such that:
:the partial derivatives âˆ‚ zâˆ‚ x and âˆ‚ zâˆ‚ y are both zero
but:
:there is no local maximum or local minimum at P.


Then P is a saddle point of ğ’®.

title: Definition:Scalar Field (Linear Algebra)
definition:
Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_K be a vector space, where:

:( K, +_K, Ã—_K ) is a field

:( G, +_G ) is an abelian group ( G, +_G )

:âˆ˜: K Ã— G â†’ G is a binary operation.


Then the field ( K, +_K, Ã—_K ) is called the scalar field of ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_K.


If the scalar field is understood, then ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_K can be rendered ( G, +_G, âˆ˜).

title: Definition:Scalar Field (Physics)
definition:
Let F be a field which acts on a region of space S.

Let the point-function giving rise to F be a scalar quantity.


Then F is a scalar field.

title: Definition:Screw (Machine)
definition:
A screw is a simple machine consisting of:
:a cylindrical or conical body
:a helical groove cut into its surface

Thus it can be considered as a wedge wound in the form of a helix.


When the end of the screw S is placed against a substance, a rotation of S about its axis causes a translation of S along this axis, and into the substance.


=== Thread ===
The helical groove cut into the surface of a screw is called its thread.

title: Definition:Screw (Geometry)
definition:
A screw is an isometry on the real Euclidean space â„^3 defined as a combination of:
:a rotation about an axis
:a translation along that same axis of rotation.

title: Definition:Secant Function
definition:
=== Definition from Triangle ===
:

In the above right triangle, we are concerned about the angle Î¸.

The secant of âˆ Î¸ is defined as being HypotenuseAdjacent.

=== Definition from Circle ===
=== First Quadrant ===
Consider a unit circle C whose center is at the origin of a cartesian plane.


:


Let P be the point on C in the first quadrant such that Î¸ is the angle made by OP with the x-axis.

Let a tangent line be drawn to touch C at A = ( 1, 0 ).

Let OP be produced to meet this tangent line at B.


Then the secant of Î¸ is defined as the length of OB.

Hence in the first quadrant, the secant is positive.

=== Second Quadrant ===
Consider a unit circle C whose center is at the origin of a cartesian plane.


:


Let P be the point on C in the second quadrant such that Î¸ is the angle made by OP with the x-axis.

Let a tangent line be drawn to touch C at A = ( 1, 0 ).

Let OP be produced to meet this tangent line at B.


Then the secant of Î¸ is defined as the length of OB.

As OP needs to be produced in the opposite direction to P, the secant is therefore a negative function in the second quadrant.

=== Third Quadrant ===
Consider a unit circle C whose center is at the origin of a cartesian plane.


:


Let P be the point on C in the third quadrant such that Î¸ is the angle made by OP with the x-axis.

Let a tangent line be drawn to touch C at A = ( 1, 0 ).

Let OP be produced to meet this tangent line at B.


Then the secant of Î¸ is defined as the length of OB.


As OP needs to be produced in the opposite direction to P, the secant is therefore a negative function in the third quadrant.

=== Fourth Quadrant ===
Consider a unit circle C whose center is at the origin of a cartesian plane.


:


Let P be the point on C in the fourth quadrant such that Î¸ is the angle made by OP with the x-axis.

Let a tangent line be drawn to touch C at A = ( 1, 0 ).

Let OP be produced to meet this tangent line at B.


Then the secant of Î¸ is defined as the length of OB.

Hence in the fourth quadrant, the secant is positive.

=== Real Function ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

The real function x is defined as:

:x =  1 cos x

where cos x is the cosine of x.


The definition is valid for all x âˆˆâ„ such that cos x  0.


Category:Definitions/Secant Function

=== Complex Function ===
Let z âˆˆâ„‚ be a complex number.

The complex function z is defined as:

:z =  1 cos z

where cos z is the cosine of z.


The definition is valid for all z âˆˆâ„‚ such that cos z  0.


Category:Definitions/Secant Function

title: Definition:Secant Line
definition:
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function.

Let the graph of f be depicted on a Cartesian plane.


:


A secant to f is a straight line which intersects the graph of f in (at least) two points.


In the above diagram, the secant is the line AB in  .

title: Definition:Upper Section
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let U âŠ† S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let U âŠ† S.


U is an upper section in S  if and only if :

:âˆ€ u âˆˆ U: âˆ€ s âˆˆ S: u â‰¼ s  s âˆˆ U

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let U âŠ† S.


U is an upper section in S  if and only if :

:U^â‰½âŠ† U

where U^â‰½ is the upper closure of U.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let U âŠ† S.


U is an upper section in S  if and only if :

:U^â‰½ = U

where U^â‰½ is the upper closure of U.

title: Definition:Lower Section
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let L âŠ† S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let L âŠ† S.


L is a lower section in S  if and only if :
:âˆ€ l âˆˆ L, s âˆˆ S: s â‰¼ l  s âˆˆ L

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let L âŠ† S.


L is a lower section in S  if and only if :
:L^â‰¼âŠ† L

where L^â‰¼ is the lower closure of L.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let L âŠ† S.


L is a lower section in S  if and only if :
:L^â‰¼ = L

where L^â‰¼ is the lower closure of L.

=== Class Theory ===
 
Let A be a class under a total ordering â‰¼.

Let L be a subclass of A such that:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆ€ a âˆˆ A âˆ– L: x â‰¼ a
where A âˆ– L is the difference between A and L.

Then L is known as a lower section of A.

title: Definition:Golden Mean
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let a line segment AB be divided at C such that:
:AB : AC = AC : BC

Then the golden mean Ï• is defined as:
:Ï• := ABAC

=== Definition 2 ===
The golden mean is the unique positive real number Ï• satisfying:
:Ï• = 1 + âˆš(5) 2

=== Definition 3 ===
The golden mean is the unique positive real number Ï• satisfying:
:Ï• =  1 Ï• - 1

title: Definition:Dedekind Cut
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.


A Dedekind cut of ( S, â‰¼) is a non-empty proper subset L âŠŠ S such that:
:(1):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆ€ y âˆˆ S: y â‰º x  y âˆˆ L (L is a lower section in S)
:(2):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆƒ y âˆˆ L: x â‰º y

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a totally ordered set.


A Dedekind cut of ( S, â‰¼) is an ordered pair ( L, R ) such that:
:(1):   { L, R } is a partition of S.
:(2):    L does not have a greatest element.
:(3):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ L: âˆ€ y âˆˆ R: x â‰º y.

title: Definition:Section of Line by Line
definition:
Let a geometrical line A cross over (or intersect) another line B.

The point where they cross is called the section of the B by A (or equivalently, of A by B).


Category:Definitions/Geometry

title: Definition:Intersection (Geometry)
definition:
The intersection of two lines AB and CD is denoted by AB âˆ© CD.

The intersection of two geometric figures is the set of points shared by both figures.


Note that this use of âˆ© is consistent with that of its more usual context of set intersection.


When two lines intersect, they are said to cut each other.

title: Definition:Sector of Circle
definition:
A sector of a circle is the region bounded by two radii and an arc.

 
: 
:A sector of a circle is the figure which, when an angle is constructed at the center of the circle, is contained by the straight lines containing the angle and the circumference cut off by them.
 â€
 

In the diagram below, BAC is a sector. 

:


In fact there are two sectors, together making up the whole of the circle.

When describing a sectors by means of its three defining points (as in BAC above), the convention is to report them in the following order:

:(1): The point on the circumference at the end of the clockwise radius
:(2): The point at the center of the circle
:(3): The point on the circumference at the end of the anticlockwise radius

Thus in the sector above, BAC describes the sector indicated by Î¸, while the sector comprising the rest of the circle is described by CAB.


=== Angle of Sector ===
:

The angle of a sector of a circle is the angle between the two radii which delimit the sector.

In the above diagram, the angle of the sector BAC is Î¸.


The conjugate angle of Î¸ also forms a sector, denoted CAB (see above).

title: Definition:Spherical Sector
definition:
A spherical sector is a surface of revolution of a sector of a circle C rotated 360 ^âˆ˜ around a diameter of C.

The surfaces of the spherical sector are:
:the zone of S, formed by the arc of the sector
:one or two conical surfaces formed by the radius or radii of the sector
where S is the sphere formed as the surface of revolution of C as it rotates 360 ^âˆ˜ around the same diameter of C.


=== Spherical Cone ===
A spherical cone is a spherical sector S whose axis of revolution passes through the sector of the circle which is the generating curve of S.

title: Definition:Segment of Circle
definition:
:

 
: 
:A segment of a circle is the figure contained by a straight line and a circumference of a circle.
 â€
 

=== Base ===
:

The base of a segment of a circle is the straight line forming one of the boundaries of the seqment.

In the above diagram, AB is the base of the highlighted segment.

=== Angle of a Segment ===
 
: 
:An angle of a segment is that contained by a straight line and a circumference of a circle.
 â€
 
That is, it is the angle the base makes with the circumference where they meet.


It can also be defined as the angle between the base and the tangent to the circle at the end of the base:

:


Category:Definitions/Segments of Circles

=== Angle in a Segment ===
 
: 
:An angle in a segment is the angle which, when a point is taken on the circumference of the segment and straight lines are joined from it to the extremities of the straight line which is the base of the segment, is contained by the straight lines so joined.
 â€
 
: 
:And, when the straight lines containing the angle cut off a circumference, the angle is said to stand upon that circumference.
 â€
 

:

Such a segment is said to admit the angle specified.


Category:Definitions/Segments of Circles

=== Similar Segments ===
 
: 
:Similar segments of circles are those which admit equal angles, or in which the angles are equal to one another.
 â€
 


Category:Definitions/Segments of Circles

=== Major Segment ===
Let AB be a chord of a circle ğ’ defined by the points A and B on the circumference of ğ’.

The major segment of ğ’   AB is the segment between AB and the major arc of ğ’ between A and B.

=== Minor Segment ===
Let AB be a chord of a circle ğ’ defined by the points A and B on the circumference of ğ’.

The minor segment of ğ’   AB is the segment between AB and the minor arc of ğ’ between A and B.

title: Definition:Line/Segment
definition:
A line segment is any line (straight or not) which terminates at two points.


=== Straight Line Segment ===
A straight line segment is a line segment which is straight.


 
:A straight line segment can be drawn joining any two points.
 


Thus a definition for straight line which is frequently encountered is:
:A straight line is the shortest distance between two points.
This is all very well but it assumes that the line in question terminates at two particular endpoints.

=== Endpoint ===
Each of the points at either end of a line segment is called an endpoint of that line segment.

Similarly, the point at which an infinite half-line terminates is called the endpoint of that line.


 
: 
:The extremities of a line are points.
 â€
 

=== Midpoint ===
Let L = AB be a line segment whose endpoints are A and B.

Let M be a point on L such that the line segment AM is equal to the line segment MB.

That is, let M be the bisector of L.


Then M is the midpoint of L.

title: Definition:Initial Segment
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be a well-ordered set.

Let a âˆˆ S.


The initial segment (of S) determined by a is defined as:

:S_a := { b âˆˆ S: b â‰¼ a  b  a }

which can also be rendered as:

:S_a := { b âˆˆ S: b â‰º a }


That is, S_a is the set of all elements of S that strictly precede a.

That is, S_a is the strict lower closure of a (in S).


By extension, S_a is described as an initial segment (of S).


=== Class Theoretical Definition ===
 
Let A be a class.

Let â‰¼ be a well-ordering on A.

Let a âˆˆ A.


The initial segment (of A) determined by a is defined as:

:A_a := { b âˆˆ S: b â‰¼ a  b  a }

which can also be rendered as:

:A_a := { b âˆˆ S: b â‰º a }

title: Definition:Lower Closure/Element
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let a âˆˆ S.


The lower closure of a (in S) is defined as:

:a^â‰¼ := { b âˆˆ S: b â‰¼ a }


That is, a^â‰¼ is the set of all elements of S that precede a.


=== Class Theory ===
 
Let A be a class under an ordering â‰¼.

Let a âˆˆ A.


The lower closure of a (in A) is defined as:

:a^â‰¼ := { b âˆˆ A: b â‰¼ a }

title: Definition:Submatrix
definition:
Let ğ€ be a matrix with m rows and n columns.


A submatrix of ğ€ is a matrix formed by selecting from ğ€:
:a subset of the rows
and:
:a subset of the columns
and forming a new matrix by using those entries, in the same relative positions, that appear in both the rows and columns of those selected.

title: Definition:Ellipse/Major Axis/Semi-Major Axis
definition:
:

Consider an ellipse K.


A semi-major axis of K is either half of the major axis of K from its midpoint to its endpoint.


In the above diagram, O V_1 and O V_2 are the semi-major axes of K.

title: Definition:Semimajor Axis of Ellipsoid
definition:
Let â„° be an ellipsoid.

A semimajor axis of â„° is one of the two halves of the major axis of â„° divided by its midpoint.

title: Definition:Ellipse/Minor Axis/Semi-Minor Axis
definition:
:

Consider an ellipse K.


A semi-minor axis of K is either half of the minor axis of K from its midpoint to its endpoint.


In the above diagram, O C_1 and O C_2 are the semi-minor axes of K.

title: Definition:Semiminor Axis of Ellipsoid
definition:
Let â„° be an ellipsoid.

A semiminor axis of â„° is one of the two halves of the minor axis of â„° divided by its midpoint.

title: Definition:Separable Space
definition:
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is separable  if and only if  there exists a countable subset of S which is everywhere dense in T.


=== Normed Vector Space ===
Let M = ( X, â€– Â· â€–) be a normed vector space.

Let Y âŠ† X be a subset of X.

Let Y be countable set and (everywhere) dense in X.

In other words, suppose Y = { y_i : i âˆˆâ„•} such that:

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ X : âˆ€Ïµâˆˆâ„_> 0 : Ïµ > 0 : âˆƒ y_n âˆˆâ„•âˆˆ Y : â€– y_n - x â€– < Ïµ


Then X is separable.

title: Definition:Second-Countable Space
definition: A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is second-countable or satisfies the Second Axiom of Countability  if and only if  its topology has a countable basis.

title: Definition:Separable Element
definition:
Let L/K be a field extension.

Let Î±âˆˆ L.


Then Î± is separable over K  if and only if  its minimal polynomial over K is separable.

title: Definition:Separable Extension
definition:
Let K be a field.

Let L/K be an algebraic field extension.


Then L/K is a separable extension  if and only if  every Î±âˆˆ L is separable over K.

That is:
:For every Î±âˆˆ L, its minimal polynomial over K is separable.

title: Definition:Separable Polynomial
definition:
Let K be a field.

Let P (   )X âˆˆ K [ X ] be a polynomial of degree n.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let K be a field.

Let P (   )X âˆˆ K [ X ] be a polynomial of degree n.


P is separable  if and only if  its roots are distinct in an algebraic closure of K.


Category:Definitions/Separable Polynomials

=== Definition 2 ===
Let K be a field.

Let P (   )X âˆˆ K [ X ] be a polynomial of degree n.


P is separable  if and only if  it has no double roots in every field extension of K.


Category:Definitions/Separable Polynomials

=== Definition 3 ===
Let K be a field.

Let P (   )X âˆˆ K [ X ] be a polynomial of degree n.


P is separable  if and only if  it has n distinct roots in every field extension where P splits.


Category:Definitions/Separable Polynomials

title: Definition:Separable Differential Equation
definition:
A first order ordinary differential equation which can be expressed in the form:
:d yd x = g (   )x h (   )y
is known as a separable differential equation.


Its general solution is found by solving the integration:
:âˆ«d y/h (   )y = âˆ« g (   )x  d x + C


=== General Form ===
A first order ordinary differential equation which can be expressed in the form:
:g_1 (   )x h_1 (   )y + g_2 (   )x h_2 (   )y d yd x = 0
is known as a separable differential equation.


Its general solution is found by solving the integration:
:âˆ«g_1 (   )x/g_2 (   )x d x + âˆ«h_2 (   )y/h_1 (   )y d y = C

title: Definition:Separated Points
definition:
Let ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let x, y âˆˆ S such that both of the following hold:

:âˆƒ U âˆˆÏ„: x âˆˆ U, y âˆ‰ U
:âˆƒ V âˆˆÏ„: y âˆˆ V, x âˆ‰ V


Then x and y are separated points.

title: Definition:Separated Sets
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let A, B âŠ† S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let A, B âŠ† S.


A and B are separated (in T)  if and only if :
:A^- âˆ© B = A âˆ© B^- = âˆ…
where:
:A^- denotes the closure of A in T
:âˆ… denotes the empty set.


A and B are said to be separated sets (of T).

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let A, B âŠ† S.


A and B are separated (in T)  if and only if  there exist U,VâˆˆÏ„ with:
:A âŠ‚ U and U âˆ© B = âˆ…
:B âŠ‚ V and V âˆ© A = âˆ…
where âˆ… denotes the empty set.


A and B are said to be separated sets (of T).

Category:Definitions/Topology

A and B are said to be separated sets (of T).

title: Definition:Points Separated by Neighborhoods/Neighborhoods
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


Let x, y âˆˆ S such that:

:âˆƒ N_x, N_y âŠ† S: âˆƒ U, V âˆˆÏ„: x âˆˆ U âŠ† N_x, y âˆˆ V âŠ† N_y: N_x âˆ© N_y = âˆ…


That is, that x and y both have neighborhoods in T which are disjoint.


Then x and y are described as separated by neighborhoods.


Thus two points are separated by neighborhoods x and y  if and only if  the two singleton sets { x } and { y } are separated by neighborhoods as sets.

Category:Definitions/Separated by Neighborhoods

title: Definition:Sets Separated by Neighborhoods/Neighborhoods
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


Let A, B âŠ† S such that:
:âˆƒ N_A, N_B âŠ† S: âˆƒ U, V âˆˆÏ„: A âŠ† U âŠ† N_A, B âŠ† V âŠ† N_B: N_A âˆ© N_B = âˆ…


That is, that A and B both have neighborhoods in T which are disjoint.


Then A and B are described as separated by neighborhoods.


Category:Definitions/Separated by Neighborhoods

title: Definition:Separated by Closed Neighborhoods/Points
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


Let x, y âˆˆ S such that:

:âˆƒ N_x, N_y âŠ† S: âˆƒ U, V âˆˆÏ„: x âŠ† U âŠ† N_x, y âŠ† V âŠ† N_y: N_x^- âˆ© N_y^- = âˆ…

where N_x^- and N_y^- are the closures in T of N_x and N_y respectively.


That is, that x and y both have neighborhoods in T whose closures are disjoint.


Then x and y are described as separated by closed neighborhoods.


Thus two points are separated by closed neighborhoods x and y  if and only if  the two singleton sets { x } and { y } are separated (as sets) by closed neighborhoods.

title: Definition:Separated by Closed Neighborhoods/Sets
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


Let A, B âŠ† S such that:
:âˆƒ N_A, N_B âŠ† S: âˆƒ U, V âˆˆÏ„: A âŠ† U âŠ† N_A, B âŠ† V âŠ† N_B: N_A^- âˆ© N_B^- = âˆ…
where N_A^- and N_B^- are the closures in T of N_A and N_B respectively.

That is, that A and B both have neighborhoods in T whose closures are disjoint.


Then A and B are described as separated by closed neighborhoods.


Category:Definitions/Separated by Closed Neighborhoods

title: Definition:Hausdorff Space
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a Hausdorff space or T_2 space  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S, x  y: âˆƒ U, V âˆˆÏ„: x âˆˆ U, y âˆˆ V: U âˆ© V = âˆ… 

That is:
:for any two distinct elements x, y âˆˆ S there exist disjoint open sets U, V âˆˆÏ„ containing x and y respectively.


That is:
:( S, Ï„) is a T_2 space  if and only if  every two elements in S are separated by open sets.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a Hausdorff space or T_2 space  if and only if  each point of S is the intersection of all its closed neighborhoods.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a Hausdorff space or T_2 space  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S, x  y: âˆƒ N_x, N_y âŠ† S: âˆƒ U, V âˆˆÏ„: x âˆˆ U âŠ† N_x, y âˆˆ V âŠ† N_y: N_x âˆ© N_y = âˆ…

That is:
:for any two distinct elements x, y âˆˆ S there exist disjoint neighborhoods N_x, N_y âŠ† S containing x and y respectively.


That is:
:( S, Ï„) is a T_2 space  if and only if  every two elements in S are separated by neighborhoods.

title: Definition:Polygon/Side
definition:
:

The line segments which make up a polygon are known as its sides.

Thus, in the polygon above, the sides are identified as a, b, c, d and e.

title: Definition:Plane Surface/Side
definition:
From the definition of surface, it follows that a plane locally separates space into two sides.

Thus the sides of a plane are the parts of that space into which the plane separates it.


Category:Definitions/Surfaces

title: Definition:Side of Surface
definition:
Let S be a surface.

By definition, S locally separates space into two sides.

Thus the sides of S are the parts of that space into which S separates it.


Category:Definitions/Surfaces

title: Definition:Plane Number/Side
definition:
The side of a plane number is one of the (natural) numbers which are its divisors.


=== Example ===


Category:Definitions/Euclidean Number Theory

title: Definition:Solid Number/Side
definition:
The side of a solid number is one of the (natural) numbers which are its divisors.


=== Example ===


Category:Definitions/Euclidean Number Theory

title: Definition:Formal Language/Alphabet/Sign
definition:
A sign of a formal language â„’ is a symbol whose primary purpose is to structure â„’.

In building a formal language, signs form the hooks allowing the formal grammar to define the well-formed formulae of the formal language.


Common examples of signs are parentheses, "(" and ")", and the comma, ",".

The logical connectives are also signs.


Signs form part of the alphabet of â„’.

Unlike the letters, they must be the same for each signature for â„’.

title: Definition:Sign of Permutation
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let â„•_n denote the set of natural numbers { 1, 2, â€¦, n }.

Let ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ) be an ordered n-tuple of real numbers.

Let Ï€ be a permutation of â„•_n.

Let Î”_n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n be the product of differences of ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ).

Let Ï€Â·Î”_n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n be defined as:

:Ï€Â·Î”_n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n := Î”_n (   )x_Ï€(   )1, x_Ï€(   )2, â€¦, x_Ï€(   )n


The sign of Ï€âˆˆ S_n is defined as:

:sgn(   )Ï€ = Î”_nÏ€Â·Î”_n    : Î”_n  0 
 0     : Î”_n = 0

title: Definition:Sign (Arithmetic)
definition:
In the context of arithmetic and algebra, the term sign is used to mean one of the operators:

* Addition: +
* Subtraction: -
* Multiplication: Ã—
* Division: Ã·

It can also be used to describe a general operator in the context of abstract algebra: âˆ˜ and so on.

title: Definition:Sign of Number
definition:
The sign of a number is the symbol indicating whether it is:
: positive, denoted by the symbol +
or:
: negative, denoted by the symbol -.


Hence a number's sign has evolved to define the fact of the number being positive or negative independently of the symbol itself.


Thus:
:the sign of 3.14159 is positive
and
:the sign of -75 is negative.

title: Definition:Signum Function
definition:
Let X âŠ†â„ be a subset of the real numbers.


The signum function sgn: X â†’{ -1, 0, 1 } is defined as:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ X: sgn(   )x := [ x > 0 ] - [ x < 0 ]
where [ x > 0 ] etc. denotes Iverson's convention.


That is:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ X: sgn(   )x :=  -1     : x < 0 
 0     : x = 0 
 1     : x > 0


=== Graph of Signum Function ===
The graph of the signum function is illustrated below:


:

=== Natural Numbers ===
The signum function sgn: â„•â†’{ 0, 1 } is the restriction of the signum function to the natural numbers, defined as:
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„•: sgn(   )n :=  0     : n = 0 
 1     : n > 0


=== Signum Complement ===
Let sgn: â„•â†’{ 0, 1 } be the signum function on the natural numbers.

The signum complement function sgn: â„•â†’{ 0, 1 } is defined as:
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„•: sgn(   )n :=  1     : n = 0 
 0     : n > 0

title: Definition:Signature (Logic)
definition:
Let â„’ be a formal language.

A choice of vocabulary for â„’ is called a signature for â„’.


=== Signature for Predicate Logic ===
Let â„’_1 be the language of predicate logic.


Then a signature for â„’_1 is an explicit choice of the alphabet of â„’_1.

That is to say, it amounts to choosing, for each n âˆˆâ„•:

:A collection â„±_n of n-ary function symbols
:A collection ğ’«_n of n-ary relation symbols

It is often conceptually enlightening to explicitly address the 0-ary function symbols separately, as constant symbols.

title: Definition:Signature of Quadratic Form
definition: The signature of a quadratic form Q is the number of positive terms of Q minus the number of negative terms of Q.

title: Definition:Signature of Hermitian Matrix
definition: The signature of a Hermitian matrix ğ‡ is the number of positive eigenvalues of ğ‡ minus the number of negative eigenvalues of ğ‡.

title: Definition:Sign of Permutation
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let â„•_n denote the set of natural numbers { 1, 2, â€¦, n }.

Let ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ) be an ordered n-tuple of real numbers.

Let Ï€ be a permutation of â„•_n.

Let Î”_n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n be the product of differences of ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ).

Let Ï€Â·Î”_n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n be defined as:

:Ï€Â·Î”_n (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n := Î”_n (   )x_Ï€(   )1, x_Ï€(   )2, â€¦, x_Ï€(   )n


The sign of Ï€âˆˆ S_n is defined as:

:sgn(   )Ï€ = Î”_nÏ€Â·Î”_n    : Î”_n  0 
 0     : Î”_n = 0

title: Definition:Similar Figures
definition:
Two rectilineal figures are similar  if and only if :
:They have corresponding angles, all of which are equal
:They have corresponding sides, all of which are proportional.


=== Informal Definition ===
Two geometric figures are similar if they have the same shape but not necessarily the same size.

It is intuitively understood what it means for two figures to have the same shape.


=== Euclid's Definition ===

 
: 
:Similar rectilineal figures are such as have their angles severally equal and the sides about the equal angles proportional.
 â€
 

=== Algebraic Definition ===
Two geometric figures are similar if one can be transformed into the other by means of a similarity mapping.


=== Euclid's Definition ===

 
: 
:Similar rectilineal figures are such as have their angles severally equal and the sides about the equal angles proportional.
 â€
 

=== Euclid's Definition ===

 
: 
:Similar rectilineal figures are such as have their angles severally equal and the sides about the equal angles proportional.
 â€

title: Definition:Similar Triangles
definition:
Similar triangles are triangles whose corresponding angles are the same, but whose corresponding sides may be of different lengths.

:

Thus ABC is similar to DEF:
:âˆ  ABC = âˆ  EFD
:âˆ  BCA = âˆ  EDF
:âˆ  CAB = âˆ  DEF

title: Definition:Segment of Circle/Similar
definition:
: 
:Similar segments of circles are those which admit equal angles, or in which the angles are equal to one another.
 â€
 


Category:Definitions/Segments of Circles

title: Definition:Similar Solid Figures
definition: Category:Definitions/Solid Geometry

title: Definition:Right Circular Cone/Similar Cones
definition:
Let h_1 and h_2 be the lengths of the axes of two right circular cones.

Let d_1 and d_2 be the lengths of the diameters of the bases of the two right circular cones.

Then the two right circular cones are similar  if and only if :

:h_1h_2 = d_1d_2


 
: 
:Similar cones and cylinders are those in which the axes and the diameters of the bases are proportional.
 â€
 


Category:Definitions/Right Circular Cones

title: Definition:Cylinder/Similar Cylinders
definition:
Let h_1 and h_2 be the heights of two cylinders.

Let d_1 and d_2 be the diameters of the bases of the two cylinders.

Then the two cylinders are similar  if and only if :

:h_1h_2 = d_1d_2


 
: 
:Similar cones and cylinders are those in which the axes and the diameters of the bases are proportional.
 â€
 


Category:Definitions/Cylinders

title: Definition:Similarity Mapping
definition:
Let G be a vector space over a field K.

Let Î²âˆˆ K.

Let s_Î²: G â†’ G be the mapping on G defined as:
:âˆ€ğ±âˆˆ G: s_Î²(   )ğ± = Î²ğ±


s_Î² is called a similarity (mapping).


=== Scale Factor ===
Let G be a vector space over a field K.

Let Î²âˆˆ K.

Let s_Î²: G â†’ G be a similarity mapping on G:
:âˆ€ğ±âˆˆ G: s_Î²(   )ğ± = Î²ğ±


The coefficient Î² is called the scale factor of s_Î².

title: Definition:Self-Similarity
definition:
Let S be a geometric object.

S has the property of self-similarity  if and only if :
:every point of S is contained in a copy of S at a smaller scale.

title: Definition:Matrix Similarity
definition:
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„•_>0 be a natural number.

Let ğ€, ğ be square matrices of order n over R.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„•_>0 be a natural number.

Let ğ€, ğ be square matrices of order n over R.

Let there exist a nonsingular square matrix ğ of order n over R such that ğ = ğ^-1ğ€ğ.


Then ğ€ and ğ are similar.


We write:
:ğ€âˆ¼ğ

=== Definition 2 ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„•_>0 be a natural number.

Let ğ€, ğ be square matrices of order n over R.


ğ€ and ğ are similar  if and only if  they are the relative matrices, to (possibly) different ordered bases, of the same linear operator.


We write:
:ğ€âˆ¼ğ


We write:
:ğ€âˆ¼ğ

title: Definition:Set Equivalence
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Then S and T are equivalent  if and only if :
:there exists a bijection f: S â†’ T between the elements of S and those of T.

That is,  if and only if  they have the same cardinality.


This can be written S âˆ¼ T.


If S and T are not equivalent we write S  T.

title: Definition:Simple Group
definition:
A group G is simple  if and only if  it has only G and the trivial group as normal subgroups.

That is,  if and only if  the composition length of G is 1.

title: Definition:Simple Field Extension
definition:
Let E / F be a field extension.


Then E is a simple extension over F  if and only if :
:âˆƒÎ±âˆˆ E: E = F [ Î±]
where F [ Î±] is the field extension generated by Î±.

title: Definition:Continued Fraction/Simple/Finite
definition:
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

Let n â‰¥ 0 be a natural number.


A simple finite continued fraction of length n is a finite continued fraction in â„ of length n whose partial denominators are integers that are strictly positive, except perhaps the first.

That is, it is a finite sequence a: [ 0  . . ]n â†’â„¤ with a_n > 0 for n > 0.

title: Definition:Contour/Simple
definition:
Let â„^n be a real cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let C_1, â€¦, C_n be directed smooth curves in â„^n.

Let C_i be parameterized by the smooth path Ï_i: [ a_i  . . ]b_iâ†’â„^n for all i âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, n }.

Let C be the contour in â„^n defined by the finite sequence C_1, â€¦, C_n.


C is a simple contour  if and only if :

:(1): For all i, j âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n }, t_1 âˆˆ[ a_i  . . )b_i, t_2 âˆˆ[ a_j  . . )b_j with t_1  t_2, we have Ï_i (   )t_1Ï_j (   )t_2

:(2): For all k âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n }, t âˆˆ[ a_k  . . )b_k where either k  1 or t  a_1, we have Ï_k (   )t Ï_n (   )b_n.


Thus a simple contour is a contour that does not intersect itself.


=== Complex Plane ===

The definition carries over to the complex plane, in which context it is usually applied:

Let C_1, â€¦, C_n be directed smooth curves in the complex plane â„‚.

Let C_k be parameterized by the smooth path Î³_k: [ a_k  . . ]b_kâ†’â„‚ for all k âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n }.

Let C be the contour defined by the finite sequence C_1, â€¦, C_n.


C is a simple contour  if and only if :

:(1): For all j, k âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n }, t_1 âˆˆ[ a_j  . . )b_j, t_2 âˆˆ[ a_k  . . )b_k with t_1  t_2, we have Î³_j (   )t_1Î³_j (   )t_2.

:(2): For all k âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n }, t âˆˆ[ a_k  . . )b_k where either k  1 or t  a_1, we have Î³_k (   )t Î³_n (   )b_n.


Thus a simple contour is a contour that does not intersect itself.

title: Definition:Simple Graph
definition:
A simple graph is a graph which is:

:An undirected graph, that is, the edges are defined as doubleton sets of vertices and not ordered pairs

:Not a multigraph, that is, there is no more than one edge between each pair of vertices

:Not a loop-graph, that is, there are no loops, that is, edges which start and end at the same vertex

:Not a weighted graph, that is, the edges are not mapped to a number.


=== Formal Definition ===
Let V be a set.

Let â„› be an endorelation on V which is antireflexive and symmetric.

Let E be the set whose elements of the form:
:{( v_a, v_b ), ( v_b, v_a )  }.
where ( v_a, v_b ) and ( v_b, v_a ) are elements of â„› 


A simple graph is an ordered pair G = ( V, E ), where V and E are defined as above.


V is called the vertex set.

E is called the edge set.

title: Definition:Digraph/Simple Digraph
definition:
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

If the relation E in D is also specifically asymmetric, then D is called a simple digraph.

That is, in a simple digraph there are no pairs of arcs (like there are between v_1 and v_4 in the diagram above) which go in both directions between two vertices.

title: Definition:Multigraph/Simple Edge
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a multigraph.


A simple edge is an edge u v of G which is the only edge of G which is incident to both u and v.


Category:Definitions/Edges of Graphs
Category:Definitions/Multigraphs

title: Definition:Simple Function
definition:
Let ( X, x3a3) be a measurable space.

A real-valued function f: X â†’â„ is said to be a simple function  if and only if  it is a finite linear combination of characteristic functions:

:f = âˆ‘_k  = 1^n a_k Ï‡_S_k

where a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n are real numbers and each of the sets S_k is x3a3-measurable.


=== Positive Simple Function ===

When all of the a_i are positive, f is also said to be positive.

 

=== Banach Space ===
Let ğ”½âˆˆ{â„, â„‚}. 

Let I be a real interval.

Let X be a Banach space over ğ”½. 

Let f : I â†’ X be a function.


We say that f is simple  if and only if  there exists: 

:Lebesgue measurable subsets Î©_1, â€¦, Î©_r of I with finite Lebesgue measure
:x_1, â€¦, x_r âˆˆ X 

such that: 

:f (   )t = âˆ‘_r  = 1^n x_r Ï‡_Î©_r(   )t

for each t âˆˆ I.

title: Definition:Singular Statement
definition:
A singular statement is a statement whose subject is identified by means of a proper name.

More generally, it is a statement which contains no variables, either bound or free.


=== Individuating Description ===
An individuating description is a predicate whose purpose is to uniquely identify a particular object.

=== Designatory Function ===
A designatory function is a propositional function which, on replacement of the operand with a constant, becomes an individuating description.

title: Definition:Singular Matrix
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a (strictly) positive integer.

Let ğ€ be an element of the ring of square matrices ( â„³_R (   )n, +, Ã—).


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a (strictly) positive integer.

Let ğ€ be an element of the ring of square matrices ( â„³_R (   )n, +, Ã—).


Let ğ€ have no inverse.

Then ğ€ is referred to as singular.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a (strictly) positive integer.

Let ğ€ be an element of the ring of square matrices ( â„³_R (   )n, +, Ã—).


Let the determinant of ğ€ be equal to 0.

Then ğ€ is referred to as singular.

title: Definition:Singular Cardinal
definition:
Let Îº be an infinite cardinal.


Then Îº is a singular cardinal  if and only if  cf(   )Îº < Îº.

That is, the cofinality of Îº is less than itself.

title: Definition:Singular Point
definition:
=== Real Analysis ===

Let C be a locus.
Let C be a locus.

A point P âˆˆ C is called a singular point  if and only if  P does not have a unique tangent to C which is itself differentiable.

=== Complex Analysis ===
Let U âŠ†â„‚ be an open set.

Let f : U â†’â„‚ be a complex function.


A singular point of f is a point at which f is not analytic.

title: Definition:Skew Lines
definition:
Let L_1 and L_2 be two straight lines in 3-dimensional Euclidean space.


L_1 and L_2 are said to be skew  if and only if , when produced, they are neither intersecting nor parallel.

title: Definition:Skew Field
definition: A skew field is a division ring whose ring product is specifically not commutative.

title: Definition:Skewness
definition:
Skewness is a measure of the asymmetry of a probability distribution about its mean.


Let X be a random variable with mean Î¼ and standard deviation Ïƒ.

Then the skewness of X, usually denoted Î³_1, is defined as: 

:Î³_1 = ğ–¤( ( X - Î¼Ïƒ)^3 )

where ğ–¤( X ) denotes the expectation of X.


=== Coefficient of Skewness ===
Let X be a random variable with mean Î¼ and standard deviation Ïƒ.

The coefficient of skewness of X is the coefficient:

 
 
 
 

where:
:Î¼_i denotes the ith central moment of X
:Î¼ denotes the expectation of X, that is, its first central moment
:Ïƒ denotes the standard deviation of X, that is, the square root of its second central moment.


=== Notation ===


=== Notation ===


=== Positive Skewness ===
Let D be a probability distribution.

Let D have a coefficient of skewness Î³_1 such that:
:Î³_1 > 0

Then D is said to have positive skewness.

=== Negative Skewness ===
Let D be a probability distribution.

Let D have a coefficient of skewness Î³_1 such that:
:Î³_1 < 0

Then D is said to have negative skewness.

title: Definition:Small Class
definition:
Let A denote an arbitrary class.


Then A is said to be small  if and only if :

:âˆƒ x: x = A

where = denotes class equality and x is a set variable.


That is, a class is small  if and only if  it is equal to some set variable.


To denote that a class A is small, the notation â„³(   )A may be used.

Thus:
:â„³(   )A âˆƒ x: x = A

title: Definition:Small Category
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.


Then ğ‚ is said to be small  if and only if  both of the following hold:

:The collection of objects ğ‚_0 is a set;
:The collection of morphisms ğ‚_1 is a set.

title: Definition:Smooth Real Function
definition:
A real function is smooth  if and only if  it is of differentiability class C^âˆ.

That is,  if and only if  it admits of continuous derivatives of all orders.

title: Definition:Smooth Mapping
definition:
Let M, N be smooth manifolds. 

Denote m :=  M and n :=  N. 

Let Ï•: M â†’ N be a mapping. 


Then Ï• is a smooth mapping  if and only if :
:for every chart ( U, Îº) on M and every chart ( V, Î¾) on N such that V âˆ©Ï•(   )U âˆ…, the mapping:
::Î¾âˆ˜Ï•âˆ˜Îº^-1: Îº(   )U âŠ†â„^m â†’Î¾(   )V âˆ©Ï•(   )UâŠ†â„^n
:is smooth.

title: Definition:Topological Manifold/Smooth Manifold
definition:
Let M be a second-countable locally Euclidean space of dimension d. 

Let â„± be a smooth differentiable structure on M.


Then ( M, â„±) is called a smooth manifold of dimension d.

title: Definition:Smooth Homotopy
definition:
Let X and Y be topological spaces.

Let f: X â†’ Y, g: X â†’ Y be smooth mappings.


Then f and g are smoothly homotopic  if and only if  there exists a smooth mapping:
: H: X Ã—[0  . .  1] â†’ Y
such that:
: H (x, 0) = f (x)
and:
: H (x, 1) = g (x)


H is called a smooth homotopy between f and g.

title: Definition:Fiber of Truth/Solution
definition:
Let P: X â†’{T, F} be a propositional function defined on a domain X.

Let P be in the form of an equation in the context of algebra.

Let S = P^-1(   )T be the fiber of truth (under P).


Then an element of S is known as a solution of P.

title: Definition:Differential Equation/Solution/General Solution
definition:
Let Î¦ be a differential equation.

The general solution to Î¦ is the set of all functions Ï• that satisfy Î¦.

title: Definition:Differential Equation/Solution/Particular Solution
definition:
Let Î¦ be a differential equation.

Let S denote the solution set of Î¦.

A particular solution of Î¦ is the element of S, or subset of S, which satisfies a particular boundary condition of Î¦.

title: Definition:Simultaneous Equations/Solution
definition:
An ordered n-tuple ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ) which satisfies each of the equations in a system of m simultaneous equations in n variables is called a solution to, or of, the system.


=== Solution Set ===
Consider the system of m simultaneous equations in n variables:

:ğ•Š := âˆ€ i âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, m } : f_i (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦ x_n = Î²_i

Let ğ• be the set of ordered n-tuples:
:{âŸ¨ x_j âŸ©_j âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, n }: âˆ€ i âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, m }: f_i (   )âŸ¨ x_j âŸ© = Î²_i }

which satisfies each of the equations in ğ•Š.


Then ğ• is called the solution set of ğ•Š.


Thus to solve a system of simultaneous equations is to find all the elements of ğ•.

title: Definition:Solution of Game
definition:
Let G be a game.

A solution of G is a systematic description of the outcomes that may emerge in a family of games.

title: Definition:Polynomial Congruence/Solution
definition:
Let:
:P (   )x â‰¡ 0  n
be a polynomial congruence.


A solution of P (   )x â‰¡ 0  n is a residue class modulo n such that any element of that class satisfies the congruence.

title: Definition:Sound (Physics)
definition:
Sound is the vibration of an elastic medium whose frequency ranges between approximately 20  Hz and 20  kHz.

It is characterised by the ability of humans to detect it with their aural sensory systems.


Category:Definitions/Sound
Category:Definitions/Acoustics
Category:Definitions/Physics

title: Definition:Sound Logistic System
definition: A sound logistic system is a logistic system in which every theorem is a valid WFF.

title: Definition:Generator of Module
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be an R-module.

Let S âŠ† M be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let R be a ring.

Let M be an R-module.

Let S âŠ† M be a subset.


S is a generator of M  if and only if  M is the submodule generated by S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let R be a ring.

Let M be an R-module.

Let S âŠ† M be a subset.


S is a generator of M  if and only if  M has no proper submodule containing S.

title: Definition:Generator of Vector Space
definition:
Let K be a division ring.

Let ğ• be a vector space over K.

Let S âŠ†ğ• be a subset of ğ•.


S is a generator of ğ•  if and only if  every element of ğ• is a linear combination of elements of S.

title: Definition:State of Game
definition:
Let G be a game whose outcome is determined by the realization of a random variable X.

Each of the possible values that can be taken by X is known as a state of G.

title: Definition:State of Matter
definition:
Matter can be in one of the following states:

=== Solid ===
Solid is one of the fundamental states of matter.

A body is solid  if and only if  it retains its volume and has a well-definable shape without the need for a container.

The word can be used either as a noun or an adjective.

=== Liquid ===
Liquid is one of the fundamental states of matter.

A body is liquid  if and only if  it retains its volume, but in order to maintain a specific shape it needs a container.

The word can be used either as a noun or an adjective.

=== Gas ===
Gas is one of the fundamental states of matter.

A body is gas  if and only if  it can be contained only if it is fully surrounded by a solid, or in a bubble of liquid, or held together by gravitational pull.

=== Plasma ===
Plasma is one of the fundamental states of matter.

A body is plasma  if and only if  it consists of partially ionized gas and electrons.

title: Definition:Conditional/Language of Conditional/Strong
definition: In a conditional p  q, the statement p is stronger than q.

title: Definition:Strongly Locally Compact Space
definition:
Let T = (S, Ï„) be a topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


The space T is strongly locally compact  if and only if :
:every point of S is contained in an open set whose closure is compact.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = (S, Ï„) be a topological space.


The space T is strongly locally compact  if and only if :
:every point has a closed compact neighborhood.
That is:
:every point of S is contained in an open set which is contained in a closed compact subspace.

title: Definition:Structure for Predicate Logic
definition:
Let â„’_1 be the language of predicate logic.


A structure ğ’œ for â„’_1 comprises:

:(1): A non-empty set A;
:(2): For each function symbol f of arity n, a mapping f_ğ’œ: A^n â†’ A;
:(3): For each predicate symbol p of arity n, a mapping p_ğ’œ: A^n â†’ B

where B denotes the set of truth values.

A is called the underlying set of ğ’œ.

f_ğ’œ and p_ğ’œ are called the interpretations of f and p in ğ’œ, respectively.


We remark that function symbols of arity 0 are interpreted as constants in A.

To avoid pathological situations with the interpretation of arity-0 function symbols, it is essential that A be non-empty.

Also, the predicate symbols may be interpreted as relations via their characteristic functions.

title: Definition:Relational Structure
definition:
A relational structure is an ordered pair ( S, â„›), where:
:S is a set
:â„› is an endorelation on S.

title: Definition:Algebraic Structure
definition:
An algebraic structure with n operations is an ordered tuple:
:( S, âˆ˜_1, âˆ˜_2, â€¦, âˆ˜_n )
where:
:S is a set
:âˆ˜_1, âˆ˜_2, â€¦, âˆ˜_n are n binary operations which are defined on all the elements of S Ã— S.


=== One Operation ===
An algebraic structure with 1 operation is an ordered pair:
:( S, âˆ˜)
where:
:S is a set
:âˆ˜ is a binary operation defined on all the elements of S Ã— S.

=== Two Operations ===
An algebraic structure with 2 operations is an ordered triple:
:( S, âˆ˜, * )
where:
:S is a set
:âˆ˜ and * are binary operations defined on all the elements of S Ã— S.

title: Definition:Ringed Space
definition:
A ringed space is a pair ( X, ğ’ª_X ) where:
:X is a topological space
:ğ’ª_X is a sheaf of commutative rings with unity on X.



=== Structure Sheaf ===
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) be a ringed space.


The structure sheaf of ( X, ğ’ª_X ) is the term ğ’ª_X.
