title: Definition:Structure Sheaf of Spectrum of Ring
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let ( Spec( A ), Ï„) be its spectrum with Zariski topology Ï„


=== Definition 1 ===

Note that Principal Open Subsets form Basis of Zariski Topology on Prime Spectrum.

We define the structure sheaf of Spec( A ) to be the sheaf induced by a sheaf on this basis defined as follows:
:For f âˆˆ A, ğ’ª(   )X (   )f is the localization of A at f
:For f, g âˆˆ A with X (   )f âŠƒ X (   )g, the restriction is the induced homomorphism of A-algebras A_f â†’ A_g.


=== Definition 2 ===

 


=== Definition 3 ===

title: Definition:Subnormal Subgroup
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let H be a subgroup of G.


Then H is a k-subnormal subgroup of G  if and only if  there is a finite sequence of subgroups of G:
:H = H_0, H_1, H_2, â€¦, H_k = G
such that H_i is a normal subgroup of H_i + 1 for all i âˆˆ{ 0, 1, â€¦, k - 1 }.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a normal series:
:H = H_0  H_1  H_2 â‹¯ H_k = G
where  denotes the relation of normality.


Thus H is a subnormal subgroup of G  if and only if  there exists k âˆˆâ„¤_>0 such that H is a k-subnormal subgroup of G.


By this definition, a normal subgroup is a 1-subnormal subgroup.

title: Definition:Subnormal (Analytic Geometry)
definition:
:
Let ğ’ be a plane curve embedded in a Cartesian plane.

Let P be a point on ğ’.

Let ğ’© be the normal to ğ’ at P.

Let Q be the x-intercept of ğ’©.

Let AP be the line through P perpendicular to the x-axis meeting the x-axis at A.


The subnormal to ğ’ at P is the straight line segment AQ.


Thus the subnormal is the projection of the length of the normal onto the x-axis.

title: Definition:Compound Statement/Substatement
definition: A substatement of a compound statement is one of the statements that comprise it.

title: Definition:Statement Form/Substatement
definition: A substatement of a statement form ğ€ is another statement form which occurs as a part of ğ€.

title: Definition:Substitution
definition:
Substitution is a word that denotes the process of replacement of every occurrence of a term in an expression or equation with another.


 
* Set Theory:
** Definition:Substitution (Set Theory)


* Formal Systems:
** Definition:Substitution (Formal Systems)
*** Definition:Substitution for Well-Formed Part
*** Definition:Substitution for Letter
**** Definition:Alphabetic Substitution
*** Definition:Substitution of Term
*** Definition:Substitution for Metasymbol


* Mathematical Logic:
** Definition:Substitution (Mathematical Logic)

title: Definition:Substitution (Set Theory)
definition:
Let S and T be non-empty sets such that T is not a subset of S.

Let:
:s âˆˆ S
:t âˆˆ T âˆ– S
where âˆ– denotes set difference.

Let S' be the set defined as:
:S' = ( S âˆ–{ s }) âˆª{ t }

That is, S' is the set obtained by removing s and replacing it with t which is not in S.


The operation of replacing s with t is known as substitution.


Category:Definitions/Set Theory

title: Definition:Substitution (Formal Systems)/Well-Formed Part
definition:
Let â„± be a formal language with alphabet ğ’œ.

Let ğ be a well-formed formula of â„±.

Let ğ€ be a well-formed part of ğ.

Let ğ€' be another well-formed formula.


Then the substitution of ğ€' for ğ€ in ğ is the collation resulting from ğ by replacing all occurrences of ğ€ in ğ by ğ€'.

It is denoted as ğ(   )ğ€' //ğ€.


Note that it is not immediate that ğ(   )ğ€' //ğ€ is a well-formed formula of â„±.

This is either accepted as an axiom or proven as a theorem about the formal language â„±.


=== Example ===

title: Definition:Substitution (Formal Systems)/Letter
definition:
Let â„± be a formal language with alphabet ğ’œ.

Let ğ be a well-formed formula of â„±.

Let p be a letter of â„±.

Let ğ€ be another well-formed formula.

Then the substitution of ğ€ for p in ğ is the collation resulting from ğ by replacing all occurrences of p in ğ by ğ€.

It is denoted as ğ(   )ğ€// p.


Note that it is not immediate that ğ(   )ğ€// p is a well-formed formula of â„±.

This is either accepted as an axiom or proven as a theorem about the formal language â„±.

title: Definition:Alphabetic Substitution
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a WFF of the language of predicate logic â„’_1.

Consider the (abbreviated) WFF Q x: ğ‚ where Q is a quantifier.

Let y be another variable such that:

:y is freely substitutable for x in ğ‚
:y does not occur freely in ğ‚.


Let ğ‚' be the WFF resulting from substituting y for all free occurrences of x in ğ‚.

The change from Q x: ğ‚ to Q y: ğ‚' is called alphabetic substitution.

title: Definition:Substitution (Formal Systems)/Metasymbol
definition:
Let S_1 be a statement form.

Let p be a metasymbol which occurs one or more times in S_1.

Let T be a statement.

Let S_2 be the string formed by replacing every occurrence of p in S_1 with T.


Then S_2 results from the substitution of p by T in S_1.

S_2 is called a substitution instance of S_1.

title: Definition:Substitution (Mathematical Logic)
definition:
=== Mapping ===

Let S be a set.

Let f: S^t â†’ S be a mapping.

Let { g_1: S^k â†’ S, g_2: S^k â†’ S, â€¦, g_t: S^k â†’ S } be a set of mappings.

Let the mapping h: S^k â†’ S be defined as:
:h (   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_k = f (   )g_1 (   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_k, g_2 (   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_k, â€¦, g_t (   )s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_k


Then h is said to be obtained from f, g_1, g_2, â€¦, g_k by substitution.


The definition can be generalized in the following ways:
* It can apply to mappings which operate on variously different sets.
* Each of g_1, g_2, â€¦, g_t may have different arities. If g is a mapping of m variables where m > k, we can always consider it a mapping of k variables in which the additional variables play no part. So if g_i is a mapping of k_i variables, we can take k = max{ k_i: i = 1, 2, â€¦, t } and then each g_i is then a mapping of k variables.


=== Partial Function ===

Let f: â„•^t â†’â„• be a partial function.

Let { g_1: â„•^k â†’â„•, g_2: â„•^k â†’â„•, â€¦, g_t: â„•^k â†’â„•} be a set of partial functions.

Let the partial function h: â„•^k â†’â„• be defined as:
:h (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_kâ‰ˆ f (   )g_1 (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k, g_2 (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k, â€¦, g_t (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k
where â‰ˆ is as defined in Partial Function Equality.


Then h is said to be obtained from f, g_1, g_2, â€¦, g_k by substitution.


Note that h (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k is defined only when:
* All of g_1 (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k, g_2 (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k, â€¦, g_t (   )n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k are defined

title: Definition:Subtree (Graph Theory)
definition:
Let T = ( V, E ) be a tree.


A subtree of T is a subgraph of T that is also a tree.

title: Definition:Rooted Subtree
definition:
Let ( T, r_T ) be a rooted tree.


A rooted subtree of T is a rooted tree ( S, r_S ) such that:

:S is a subtree of T
:r_S = r_T

Note that the second condition implies that r_T âˆˆ S.

title: Definition:Tree (Set Theory)/Subtree
definition:
Let ( T, â‰¼) be a tree.

A subtree of ( T, â‰¼) is an ordered subset ( S, â‰¼) with the property that:
:for every âˆ€ s âˆˆ S: âˆ€ t âˆˆ T: t â‰¼ s  t âˆˆ S

That is, such that ( S, â‰¼) is a lower closure of ( T, â‰¼).


Category:Definitions/Set Theory

title: Definition:Addition/Sum
definition:
Let a + b denote the operation of addition on two objects a and b.

Then the result a + b is referred to as the sum of a and b.


Note that the nature of a and b has deliberately been left unspecified.

They could be, for example, numbers, matrices or more complex expressions constructed from such elements.

title: Definition:Summation
definition:
Let ( S, + ) be an algebraic structure where the operation + is an operation derived from, or arising from, the addition operation on the natural numbers.

Let ( a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ) âˆˆ S^n be an ordered n-tuple in S.


=== Definition by Index ===
Let ( S, + ) be an algebraic structure where the operation + is an operation derived from, or arising from, the addition operation on the natural numbers.

Let ( a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ) âˆˆ S^n be an ordered n-tuple in S.


The composite is called the summation of ( a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ), and is written:

:âˆ‘_j  = 1^n a_j = ( a_1 + a_2 + â‹¯ + a_n )


=== Summand ===
Let ( S, + ) be an algebraic structure where the operation + is an operation derived from, or arising from, the addition operation on the natural numbers.

Let { a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n }âŠ† S be a set of elements of S.

Let R (   )j be a propositional function of j.

Let:
:âˆ‘_R (   )j a_j
be an instance of a summation on { a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n }.


The set of elements { a_j âˆˆ S: 1 â‰¤ j â‰¤ n, R (   )j } is called the summand.

=== Definition by Inequality ===
Let ( S, + ) be an algebraic structure where the operation + is an operation derived from, or arising from, the addition operation on the natural numbers.

Let ( a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ) âˆˆ S^n be an ordered n-tuple in S.


The summation of ( a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ) can be written:
:âˆ‘_1 â‰¤ j â‰¤ n a_j = ( a_1 + a_2 + â‹¯ + a_n )


=== Multiple Indices ===
Let âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ j â‰¤ n a_j denote the summation of ( a_0, a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ).


Summands with multiple indices can be denoted by propositional functions in several variables, for example:

:âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n( âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ j â‰¤ n a_i j) = âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ i, j â‰¤ n a_i j


:âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n( âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ j â‰¤ i a_i j) = âˆ‘_0 â‰¤ j â‰¤ i â‰¤ n a_i j

=== Definition by Propositional Function ===
Let ( S, + ) be an algebraic structure where the operation + is an operation derived from, or arising from, the addition operation on the natural numbers.

Let ( a_1, a_2, â€¦, a_n ) âˆˆ S^n be an ordered n-tuple in S.


Let R (   )j be a propositional function of j.

Then we can write the summation as:

:âˆ‘_R (   )j a_j =  The sum of all a_j such that R (   )j holds.


If more than one propositional function is written under the summation sign, they must all hold.


Such an operation on an ordered tuple is known as a summation.


Note that the definition by inequality form 1 â‰¤ j â‰¤ n is a special case of such a propositional function.

Also note that the definition by index form âˆ‘_j  = 1^n is merely another way of writing âˆ‘_1 â‰¤ j â‰¤ n.

Hence all instances of a summation can be expressed in terms of a propositional function.


=== Iverson's Convention ===
Let âˆ‘_R (   )j a_j be the summation over all a_j such that j satisfies R.


This can also be expressed:
:âˆ‘_j âˆˆâ„¤ a_j [ R (   )j ]
where [ R (   )j ] is Iverson's convention.

=== Iverson's Convention ===
Let âˆ‘_R (   )j a_j be the summation over all a_j such that j satisfies R.


This can also be expressed:
:âˆ‘_j âˆˆâ„¤ a_j [ R (   )j ]
where [ R (   )j ] is Iverson's convention.

=== Summation over Finite Subset ===
Let ( G, + ) be a commutative monoid.


Let F âŠ† G be a finite subset of G.


Let { e_1, e_2, â€¦, e_n } be a finite enumeration of F.

Let ( e_1, e_2, â€¦, e_n ) be the ordered tuple formed from the bijection e: [ 1  . . ]n â†’ F.


The summation over F, denoted âˆ‘_g âˆˆ F g, is defined as the summation over ( e_1, e_2, â€¦, e_n ):
:âˆ‘_g âˆˆ F g = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n e_i

=== Summation over Finite Index ===
Let ( G, + ) be a commutative monoid.


Let âŸ¨ g_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed subset of G where the indexing set I is finite.


Let { e_1, e_2, â€¦, e_n } be a finite enumeration of I.

Let ( g_e_1, g_e_2, â€¦, g_e_n) be the ordered tuple formed from the composite mapping g âˆ˜ e: [ 1  . . ]n â†’ G.


The summation over I, denoted âˆ‘_i âˆˆ I g_i, is defined as the summation over ( g_e_1, g_e_2, â€¦, g_e_n):
:âˆ‘_i âˆˆ I g_i = âˆ‘_k  = 1^n g_e_k

title: Definition:Support of Mapping to Algebraic Structure/Real-Valued Function
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let f: S â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


The support of f is the set of elements x of S whose values under f are non-zero.

That is:
:supp(   )f := { x âˆˆ S: f (   )x  0 }


That is, the support of a function whose codomain is the set of real numbers is generally defined to be the subset of its domain which maps to anywhere that is not 0.

Category:Definitions/Real Analysis

title: Definition:Support of Module
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be a unitary A-module.


The support supp(   )M of M is the set of prime ideals P of A such that the localization of M at P is nonzero:
:supp(   )M = { P âˆˆSpec( A ) : M_P  0 }

where Spec( A ) is the spectrum of A.

Category:Definitions/Module Theory

title: Definition:Support of Element of Direct Product
definition:
Let âŸ¨( S_i, âˆ˜_i )  âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of algebraic structures with identity.

The support of m is defined as:
:supp{ i âˆˆ I: m_i  e_i }

 


=== Finite Support ===

The element is said to have finite support  if and only if  its support is a finite set.

title: Definition:Support of Continuous Mapping/Real-Valued
definition:
Let f: â„^n â†’â„ be a continuous real-valued function.

The support of f is the closure of the set of elements x of â„^n whose values under f are non-zero.

:supp(   )f = cl{ x âˆˆâ„^n: f (   )x  0 }

title: Definition:Support of Permutation
definition:
Let S be a set.

Let f be a permutation on S.


The support of f is the subset of moved elements:
:supp(   )f = { x âˆˆ S: f (   )x  x }

title: Definition:Characteristic Function (Set Theory)/Set/Support
definition:
Let S be a set

Let E âŠ† S be a subset.

Let Ï‡_E: S â†’{ 0, 1 } be the characteristic function of E.


The support of Ï‡_E, denoted supp(   )Ï‡_E, is the set E.

:supp(   )Ï‡_E = { x âˆˆ S: Ï‡_E (   )x = 1 }

title: Definition:Supremum of Set/Real Numbers
definition:
Let T âŠ†â„ be a subset of the real numbers.


A real number c âˆˆâ„ is the supremum of T in â„  if and only if :

:(1):    c is an upper bound of T in â„
:(2):    c â‰¤ d for all upper bounds d of T in â„.


If there exists a supremum of T (in â„), we say that:
:T admits a supremum (in â„) or
:T has a supremum (in â„).


The supremum of T is denoted sup T or sup(   )T.


=== Definition by Propositional Function ===
Let âŸ¨ a_j âŸ©_j âˆˆ I be a family of elements of the real numbers â„ indexed by I.

Let R (   )j be a propositional function of j âˆˆ I.


Then we can define the supremum of âŸ¨ a_j âŸ©_j âˆˆ I as:

:sup_R (   )j a_j :=  the supremum of all a_j such that R (   )j holds


If more than one propositional function is written under the supremum sign, they must all hold.


=== Finite Range ===
Let âŸ¨ a_j âŸ©_j âˆˆ I be a family of elements of the real numbers â„ indexed by I.

Let R (   )j be a propositional function of j âˆˆ I.


Let the fiber of truth of R (   )j be finite.

Then the supremum of âŸ¨ a_j âŸ©_j âˆˆ I can be expressed as:

:max_R (   )j a_j =  the maxmum of all a_j such that R (   )j holds

and can be referred to as the maximum of âŸ¨ a_j âŸ©_j âˆˆ I.


If more than one propositional function is written under the supremum sign, they must all hold.

=== Vacuous Supremum ===
Take the indexed supremum:
:sup _Î¦(   )j a_j
where Î¦(   )j is a propositional function of j.

Suppose that there are no values of j for which Î¦(   )j is true.

Then sup_Î¦(   )j a_j is defined as being -âˆ.

This supremum is called a vacuous supremum.


This is because:
:âˆ€ a âˆˆâ„: sup{ a, -âˆ} = a

Hence for all j for which Î¦(   )j is false, the supremum is unaffected.


In this context -âˆ is considered as minus infinity, the hypothetical quantity that has the property:

:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„¤: -âˆ < n

title: Definition:Symmetry
definition:
An object or an expression has (or exhibits) symmetry  if and only if  parts of it may be interchanged without changing the object as a whole.


 
* Algebra:
** Symmetric Expression


* Relation Theory:
** Symmetry (of a relation): whether a relation is symmetric, antisymmetric, asymmetric or non-symmetric.


* Mapping Theory:
** Symmetric Mapping: a mapping defined on a cartesian space whose values are preserved under permutation of its arguments:
:::f (   )x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n = f (   )x_Ï€(   )1, x_Ï€(   )2, â€¦ x_Ï€(   )n for all permuations Ï€ on { 1, 2, â€¦ n }


* Geometry:
** Symmetry: A movement of a geometric figure so that it looks the same after it has been moved.


* Group Theory:
** Symmetry group: The set of all symmetries of a geometric figure, the operation being composition of mappings.


* Linear Algebra:
** Symmetric mapping
** Symmetric matrix

title: Definition:Symmetry (Relation)
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.

â„› is symmetric  if and only if :

:( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›( y, x ) âˆˆâ„›

title: Definition:Symmetry (Geometry)
definition:
A symmetry of a geometric figure P is a bijection from P to itself which preserves the distance between points.

In other words, it is a self-congruence.


Intuitively and informally, a symmetry is a movement of the figure so that it looks exactly the same after it has been moved.

title: Definition:Symmetry Group
definition:
Let P be a geometric figure.

Let S_P be the set of all symmetries of P.

Let ( S_P, âˆ˜) be the algebraic structure such that âˆ˜ denotes the composition of mappings.


Then ( S_P, âˆ˜) is called the symmetry group of P.

title: Definition:System (Electronics)
definition: A system is a configuration of electrical devices designed for a specific utilitarian purpose.

title: Definition:Neighborhood System
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

A neighborhood system is a family âŸ¨ğ’©_x âŸ©_x âˆˆ S indexed by points of S, such that ğ’©_x is a local basis at x for x âˆˆ S.

title: Definition:Numeral System
definition:
A numeral system is:
:a set of symbols that is used to represent a specific subset of the set of numbers (usually natural numbers), referred to as numerals
:a set of rules which define how to combine the numerals so as to be able to express other numbers.

title: Definition:Babylonian Number System
definition:
The number system as used in the   was a positional number system where the number base was a combination of decimal (base 10) and sexagesimal (base 60).

The characters were written in   by a combination of:
:a thin vertical wedge shape, to indicate the digit 1
:a fat horizontal wedge shape, to indicate the digit 10
arranged in groups to indicate the digits 2 to 9 and 20 to 50.


:


At 59 the pattern stops, and the number 60 is represented by the digit 1 once again.

Thus these groupings were placed side by side:
:the rightmost grouping would indicate a number from 1 to 59
:the one to the left of that would indicate a number from 60 Ã— 1 to 60 Ã— 59
and so on, each grouping further to the left indicating another multiplication by 60


For fractional numbers there was no actual radix point. Instead, the distinction was inferred by context.


The fact that they had no symbol to indicate the zero digit means that this was not a true positional number system as such.


For informal everyday arithmetic, they used a decimal system which was the decimal part of the full sexagesimal system.

title: Definition:Number System
definition: A number system is a technique for representing numbers.

title: Definition:Positional Number System
definition:
A positional (number) system is a number system with the following properties:

:(1): It has a set of numerals which represent a subset of the numbers.

:(2): The number being represented is written as a string of these numerals, which represent a different value according to their position in the string.


The design of the positional number system is such that all numbers can be represented by such a string, which:
:may or may not be infinite in length
:may or may not be unique.

title: Definition:Tableau (Linear Programming)
definition: A tableau is a technique for presenting information obtained by an iterative process during the course of using the simplex method for solving a problem of linear programming.

title: Definition:Tableau Proof (Formal Systems)
definition:
A tableau proof for a proof system is a technique for presenting a logical argument in the form of a formal proof in a straightforward, standard form.

On  , the proof system is usually natural deduction.


A tableau proof is a sequence of lines specifying the order of premises, assumptions, inferences and conclusion in support of an argument.


Each line of a tableau proof has a particular format. It consists of the following parts:

* Line: The line number of the proof. This is a simple numbering from 1 upwards.
* Pool: The list of all the lines containing the pool of assumptions for the formula introduced on this line.
* Formula: The propositional formula introduced on this line.
* Rule: The justification for introducing this line. This should be the rule of inference being used to derive this line.
* Depends on: The lines (if any) upon which this line directly depends. For premises and assumptions, this field will be empty.


Optionally, a comment may be added to explicitly point out possible intricacies.

If any assumptions are discharged on a certain line, for the sake of clarity it is preferred that such be mentioned explicitly in a comment.


At the end of a tableau proof, the only lines upon which the proof depends may be those which contain the premises.


=== Length ===
The length of a tableau proof is the number of lines it has.


Category:Definitions/Proof Systems

	t has precisely one child s, and one grandchild r

:another child s' to t, with Î¦(s') = ğ

is a finite propositional tableau.
                                                                  	If (ğ€ğ) is an ancestor WFF of t, the labeled tree obtained from T by adding:
:a child s to t, with Î¦(s) = ğ€ 
:a child r to s, with Î¦(r) = ğ

is a finite propositional tableau.
                                                                           	If ğ€ğ is an ancestor WFF of t, the labeled tree obtained from T by adding:
:a child s to t, with Î¦(s) = ğ€ğ 
:another child s' to t, with Î¦(s') = ğ€ğ

is a finite propositional tableau.
                                                                      	If (ğ€ğ) is an ancestor WFF of t, the labeled tree obtained from T by adding:
:a child s to t, with Î¦(s) = ğ€ğ 
:another child s' to t, with Î¦(s') = ğ€ğ

is a finite propositional tableau.


Note how the boxes give an indication of the ancestor WFF mentioned in the clause.

These clauses together are called the tableau extension rules.

=== Infinite Propositional Tableau ===
An infinite labeled tree ( T, ğ‡, Î¦) is a propositional tableau  if and only if :

:There exists an exhausting sequence of sets âŸ¨ T_n âŸ©_n âˆˆâ„• of T such that for all n âˆˆâ„•:

::( T_n, ğ‡, Î¦_T_n)

:is a finite propositional tableau, where Î¦_T_n denotes the restriction of Î¦ to T_n.

title: Definition:Tableau Proof (Propositional Tableaux)
definition:
Let ğ‡ be a set of WFFs of propositional logic.

Let ğ€ be a WFF.


A tableau proof of ğ€ from ğ‡ is a tableau confutation of ğ‡âˆª{ğ€}.


This definition also applies when ğ‡ = âˆ….

Then a tableau proof of ğ€ is a tableau confutation of {ğ€}.


If there exists a tableau proof of ğ€ from ğ‡, one can write:
:ğ‡âŠ¢_PTğ€

Specifically, the notation:
:âŠ¢_PTğ€
means that there exists a tableau proof of ğ€.


=== Proof System ===

title: Definition:Tableau Confutation
definition:
Let ğ‡ be a set of WFFs of propositional logic.


A tableau confutation of ğ‡ is a propositional tableau T with root ğ‡ such that every branch of T is contradictory.

title: Definition:Tableau Proof (Formal Systems)
definition:
A tableau proof for a proof system is a technique for presenting a logical argument in the form of a formal proof in a straightforward, standard form.

On  , the proof system is usually natural deduction.


A tableau proof is a sequence of lines specifying the order of premises, assumptions, inferences and conclusion in support of an argument.


Each line of a tableau proof has a particular format. It consists of the following parts:

* Line: The line number of the proof. This is a simple numbering from 1 upwards.
* Pool: The list of all the lines containing the pool of assumptions for the formula introduced on this line.
* Formula: The propositional formula introduced on this line.
* Rule: The justification for introducing this line. This should be the rule of inference being used to derive this line.
* Depends on: The lines (if any) upon which this line directly depends. For premises and assumptions, this field will be empty.


Optionally, a comment may be added to explicitly point out possible intricacies.

If any assumptions are discharged on a certain line, for the sake of clarity it is preferred that such be mentioned explicitly in a comment.


At the end of a tableau proof, the only lines upon which the proof depends may be those which contain the premises.


=== Length ===
The length of a tableau proof is the number of lines it has.


Category:Definitions/Proof Systems

title: Definition:Tableau Proof (Propositional Tableaux)
definition:
Let ğ‡ be a set of WFFs of propositional logic.

:ğ‡âŠ¢_PTğ€

Specifically, the notation:
:âŠ¢_PTğ€
means that there exists a tableau proof of ğ€.


=== Proof System ===

title: Definition:Tangent Curve
definition: A set of curves is tangent to each other  if and only if  they have a point in common at which they have a tangent line in common.

title: Definition:Tangent Line
definition:
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function.

Let the graph of f be depicted on a Cartesian plane.


:


Let A = ( x, f (   )x ) be a point on G.


The tangent to f at A is defined as:
:lim_h â†’ 0f (   )x + h - f (   )x/h


Thus the tangent to f at x can be considered as the secant AB to G where:
:B = ( x + h, f (   )x + h)
as B gets closer and closer to A.

By taking h smaller and smaller, the secant approaches more and more closely the tangent to G at A.


Hence the tangent to f is a straight line which intersects the graph of f locally at a single point.


:


In the above diagram, the tangent is the straight line passing through A.

=== Limit of Secant ===
Let ğ’ be a space curve.

Let ğ’ be embedded in a Cartesian plane.

Let P be a point on ğ’.

Let ğ’® be a secant line to ğ’ passing through P and another point Q also on ğ’.


The tangent to ğ’ at P can be considered as the limit of ğ’® as Q approaches P.

=== Tangent to Circle ===
 
: 
:A straight line is said to touch a circle which, meeting the circle and being produced, does not cut the circle.

:

In the above diagram, the line is tangent to the circle at the point C.


=== Tangent Circles ===
 
: 
:Circles are said to touch one another which, meeting one another, do not cut one another.
 â€
 

:

In the above diagram, the two circles are tangent to each other at the point C.

=== Point of Contact ===
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function.

Let the graph of f be depicted on a Cartesian plane.


:


Let A = ( x, f (   )x ) be a point on G.

Let â„’ be tangent to f at A.

Then A is known as the point of contact of â„’ to f.

title: Definition:Tangent Function/Real
definition:
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

The real function tan x is defined as:

:tan x = sin xcos x

where:
: sin x is the sine of x
: cos x is the cosine of x.

The definition is valid for all x âˆˆâ„ such that cos x  0.

title: Definition:Tangent Function/Complex
definition:
Let z âˆˆâ„‚ be a complex number.

The complex function tan z is defined as:

:tan z = sin zcos z

where:
: sin z is the sine of z
: cos z is the cosine of z.

The definition is valid for all z âˆˆâ„‚ such that cos z  0.

title: Definition:Tensor Product of Abelian Groups
definition:
Let A and B be abelian groups.


=== Definition 1: by universal property ===

Their tensor product is a pair ( A âŠ— B, Î¸) where:
:A âŠ— B is an abelian group
:Î¸ : A Ã— B â†’ A âŠ— B is a biadditive mapping such that, for every ordered pair ( C, Ï‰) where:
:C is an abelian group
:Ï‰ : A Ã— B â†’ C is a biadditive mapping
there exists a unique group homomorphism g : A âŠ— B â†’ C such that Ï‰ = g âˆ˜Î¸.


=== Definition 2: construction ===

Their tensor product is the pair ( A âŠ— B, Î¸) where:
:A âŠ— B is the quotient of the free abelian group â„¤^( A Ã— B ) on the cartesian product A Ã— B by the subgroup generated by the elements of the form:
:::( a_1 + a_2, b ) - ( a_1, b ) - ( a_2, b )
:::( a, b_1 + b_2 ) - ( a, b_1 ) - ( a, b_2 )
::for a, a_1, a_2 âˆˆ A, b, b_1, b_2 âˆˆ B, where we denote ( a, b ) for its image under the canonical mapping A Ã— B â†’â„¤^( A Ã— B ).
:Î¸ : A Ã— B â†’ A âŠ— B is the composition of the canonical mapping A Ã— B â†’â„¤^( A Ã— B ) with the quotient group epimorphism â„¤^( A Ã— B ) â†’ A âŠ— B.

title: Definition:Tensor Product of Modules
definition:
=== Commutative ring ===

Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M and N be R-modules.


=== Definition 1 ===

Their tensor product is a pair ( M âŠ—_R N, Î¸) where:
:M âŠ—_R N is an R-module
:Î¸ : M Ã— N â†’ M âŠ—_R N is an R-bilinear mapping
satisfying the following universal property:
:For every pair ( P, Ï‰) of an R-module and an R-bilinear mapping Ï‰ : M Ã— N â†’ P, there exists a unique R-module homomorphism f: M âŠ—_R N â†’ P with Ï‰ = f âˆ˜Î¸.


=== Definition 2 ===

Their tensor product is the pair ( M âŠ—_R N, Î¸), where:
:M âŠ—_R N is the quotient of the free R-module R^( M Ã— N ) on the direct product M Ã— N, by the submodule generated by the set of elements of the form:
::( Î» m_1 + m_2, n ) - Î»( m_1, n ) - ( m_2, n )
::( m, Î» n_1 + n_2 ) - Î»( m, n_1 ) - ( m, n_2 )
::for m, m_1, m_2 âˆˆ M, n, n_1, n_2 âˆˆ N and Î»âˆˆ R, where we denote ( m, n ) for its image under the canonical mapping M Ã— N â†’ R^( M Ã— N ).
:Î¸ : M Ã— N â†’ M âŠ—_R N is the composition of the canonical mapping M Ã— N â†’ R^( M Ã— N ) with the quotient module homomorphism R^( M Ã— N ) â†’ M âŠ—_R N.


=== Noncommutative ring ===

Let R be a ring.

Let M be a R-right module.

Let N be a R-left module.


First construct a left module as a direct sum of all free left modules with a basis that is a single ordered pair in M Ã— N which is denoted R (   )m, n.

:T = âŠ•_s âˆˆ M Ã— N R s


That this is indeed a module is demonstrated in Tensor Product is Module.


Next for all m, m' âˆˆ M, n, n' âˆˆ N and r âˆˆ R we construct the following free left modules.

:L_m, m', n with a basis of ( m + m', n ), ( m, n ) and ( m', n )
:R_m, n, n' with a basis of ( m, n + n' ), ( m, n ) and ( m, n' )
:A_r, m, n with a basis of r ( m, n ) and ( m r, n )
:B_r, m, n with a basis of r ( m, n ) and ( m, r n )

Let:

:D = âŠ•_r âˆˆ R, n, n' âˆˆ N, m, m' âˆˆ M(   )L_m, m', nâŠ• R_m, n, n'âŠ• A_r, m, nâŠ• B_r, m, n

The tensor product M âŠ—_R N is then our quotient module T / D.

title: Definition:Language of Predicate Logic/Formal Grammar/Term
definition:
Part of specifying the language of predicate logic â„’_1 is the introduction of terms.


The terms of â„’_1 are identified by the following bottom-up grammar:

 
 
 
 


Colloquially, we can think of a term as an expression signifying an object.

title: Definition:Logical Term
definition:
Both the subject and the predicate of a simple statement are referred to as its (logical) terms.


Note that this use of the word term is a more specialized use of the word term as used in algebra.

title: Definition:Term of Expression
definition:
A term is either a variable or a constant.


Let a âˆ˜ b be an expression.

Then each of a and b are known as the terms of the expression.


The word term is usually used when the operation âˆ˜ is addition, that is +.

title: Definition:Polynomial/Term
definition:
Let P = a_n x^n + a_n - 1 x^n - 1 + â‹¯ + a_1 x + a_0 be a polynomial.

Each of the expressions a_i x^i, for 0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n, is referred to as a term of P.

title: Definition:Fraction/Term
definition:
The terms of a fraction are referred to as the numerator and the denominator:

=== Numerator ===
Let a b be a fraction.

The term a is known as the numerator of a b.

=== Denominator ===
Let a b be a fraction.

The term b is known as the denominator of a b.

A helpful mnemonic to remember which goes on top and which goes on the bottom is "Numerator Over Denominator", which deserves a "nod" for being correct.

title: Definition:Term of Sequence
definition:
The elements of a sequence are known as its terms.


Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a sequence.

Then the kth term of âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© is the ordered pair ( k, x_k ).


=== Index ===
Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a sequence.

Let x_k be the kth term of âŸ¨ x_n âŸ©.

Then the integer k is known as the index of x_k.

title: Definition:Order of Group Element/Finite/Also known as
definition:
Let G be a group.


An element of finite order of G is also known as a torsion element of G.

title: Definition:Torsion Subgroup
definition:
Let G be an abelian group.


Its torsion subgroup T (   )G is the subgroup of all torsion elements.

title: Definition:Torsion Group
definition:
Let G be a group.


Then G is a torsion group  if and only if  all its elements are torsion elements.

title: Definition:Torsion Element of Module
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be a unitary module over R.

Let m âˆˆ M.


Then m is a torsion element of M  if and only if  there exists a regular element a âˆˆ R with a m = 0.

title: Definition:Torsion Submodule
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be a unitary module over R.


The torsion submodule T (   )M of M is the submodule of all torsion elements of M.

title: Definition:Torsion Module
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be a unitary module over R.


Then M is a torsion module  if and only if  every element of M is of torsion, that is, M equals its torsion submodule T (   )M.

title: Definition:Transcendental (Abstract Algebra)/Field Extension
definition:
A field extension E / F is said to be transcendental  if and only if :
:âˆƒÎ±âˆˆ E: Î± is transcendental over F

That is, a field extension is transcendental  if and only if  it contains at least one transcendental element.


=== Transcendental Element ===
Let E / F be a field extension.

Let Î±âˆˆ E.


Then Î± is transcendental over F  if and only if :
: âˆ„ f (   )x âˆˆ F [ x ] âˆ–{ 0 }: f (   )Î± = 0
where f (   )x denotes a polynomial in x over F.

title: Definition:Transcendental (Abstract Algebra)/Ring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a commutative ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.

Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral subdomain of R.

Let x âˆˆ R.


Then x is transcendental over D  if and only if :
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0: âˆ‘_k  = 0^n a_k âˆ˜ x^k = 0_R âˆ€ k: 0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ n: a_k = 0_R


That is, x is transcendental over D  if and only if  the only way to express 0_R as a polynomial in x over D is by the null polynomial.

title: Definition:Transcendental Number
definition:
A number (either real or complex) is transcendental  if and only if  it is not algebraic.


=== Transcendental Number over Field ===

Some sources define a transcendental number over a more general field:

Let F be a field.

Let z be a complex number.

z is a transcendental number over F  if and only if  z cannot be expressed as a root of a polynomial with coefficients in F.

title: Definition:Entire Function/Transcendental
definition:
Let f be an entire function that has an essential singularity at âˆ.

Then f is a transcendental entire function.

title: Definition:Superfunction
definition:
Let C, D âŠ†â„‚ with z âˆˆ C  z + 1 âˆˆ C.

Let F: C â†’ D and H: D â†’ D be holomorphic functions.

Let H (   )F (   )z = F (   )z + 1 for all z âˆˆ C.

Then F is said to be a superfunction of H, and H is called a transfer function of F.

That is, superfunctions are iterations of transfer functions.

title: Definition:Transfer Function (Time Series Analysis)
definition: A transfer function, in the context of time series analysis, is a function of time which theoretically models the future output for each possible input.

title: Definition:Laplace Transform
definition:
Let f: â„_â‰¥ 0â†’ğ”½ be a function of a real variable t, where ğ”½âˆˆ{â„, â„‚}.

The Laplace transform of f, denoted â„’{ f } or F, is defined as:

:â„’{ f (   )t } = F (   )s = âˆ«_0^â†’ +âˆ e^-s t f (   )t  d t

whenever this improper integral converges.

If this improper integral does not converge, then â„’{ f (   )t } does not exist.


Here â„’{ f } is a complex function of the variable s.


=== Discontinuity at Zero ===
Let f: â„_> 0â†’ğ”½ be a function of a real variable t, where ğ”½âˆˆ{â„, â„‚}.

Let f be discontinuous or not defined at t = 0.

Then the Laplace transform of f  is defined as:

:â„’{ f (   )t } = F (   )s = âˆ«_0^+^â†’ +âˆ e^-s t f (   )t  d t = lim_Ïµâ†’ 0^+âˆ«_Ïµ^â†’ +âˆ e^-s t f (   )t  d t

whenever this improper integral converges.

If this improper integral does not converge, then â„’{ f (   )t } does not exist.


Here the integral is improper not only because of its upper limit but also because of its lower limit.

title: Definition:Hough Transform
definition:
The Hough transform is a general technique which is now used to identify the locations of features in digital images.

It is a development of the Radon transform suitable for numerical calculation.

title: Definition:Radon Transform
definition:
The Radon transform is a transform which reconstructs a function from the values of its integral over a set of lines in the plane.

It is used for measuring data from incomplete observations.

title: Definition:Mellin Transform
definition:
Let f (   )t: â„_â‰¥ 0â†’â„‚ be a function of a real variable t.

The Mellin transform of f is defined and denoted as:
:â„³{ f (   )t }(   )s := âˆ«_0^â†’ +âˆ t^s - 1 f (   )t  d t

wherever this improper integral exists.


Here â„³(   )f is a complex function of the variable s.

title: Definition:Legendre Transform
definition:
Let f (   )x be a strictly convex real function.

Let p = f' (   )x.

Let f^* (   )p = -f (   )x (   )p + p x (   )p.

 

 

The Legendre Transform on x and f is the mapping of the variable and function pair:
:( x, f (   )x ) â†’( p, f^* (   )p )

title: Definition:Fourier Transform
definition:
The Fourier transform of a Lebesgue integrable function f: â„^N â†’â„‚ is the function â„±(   )f: â„^N â†’â„‚ given by:
:â„±(   )f (   )ğ¬ := âˆ«_â„^N f (   )ğ± e^-2 Ï€ i ğ±Â·ğ¬ dğ±
for ğ¬âˆˆâ„^N.

Here, the product ğ±Â·ğ¬ in the exponential is the dot product of the vectors ğ± and ğ¬.

In this context â„±(   )f is to be considered the operator.


=== Real Function ===

Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function which is Lebesgue integrable.

Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function which is Lebesgue integrable.


=== Formulation 1 ===
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function which is Lebesgue integrable.


The Fourier transform of f is defined and denoted as:
:â„±(   )f  (   )s = fÌ‚(   )s := âˆ«_-âˆ^âˆ e^-2 Ï€ i s t f (   )t  d t

=== Formulation 2 ===
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function which is Lebesgue integrable.


The Fourier transform of f is defined and denoted as:
:â„±(   )f (   )s = fÌ‚(   )s := âˆ«_-âˆ^âˆ e^-i s t f (   )t  d t

=== Formulation 3 ===
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a real function which is Lebesgue integrable.


The Fourier transform of f is defined and denoted as:
:â„±(   )f  (   )s = fÌ‚(   )s :=  1 âˆš(2 Ï€)âˆ«_-âˆ^âˆ e^-i s t f (   )t  d t

=== Tempered Distribution ===

Let T âˆˆğ’®' (   )â„ be a tempered distribution.

Let ğ’®(   )â„ be the Schwartz space.


The Fourier transform TÌ‚ of (the tempered distribution) T:

:TÌ‚âˆˆğ’®' (   )â„

is defined as:

:âˆ€Ï•âˆˆğ’®(   )â„: TÌ‚(   )Ï• := T (   )Ï•Ì‚

title: Definition:Transformation of Expression
definition:
Let â„° be an expression.

A transformation of â„° is a change in the form of â„° by either of both of:
:by rearrangement of the terms
:by substitution by another expression.

title: Definition:Linear Transformation
definition:
A linear transformation is a general R-algebraic structure homomorphism, where each of those R-algebraic structure homomorphism is a module (usually left).


Hence, let R be a ring.

Let M = ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R and N = ( H, +_H, âŠ—)_R be R-modules.

Let Ï•: G â†’ H be a mapping.

Then Ï• is a linear transformation  if and only if :
:(1):   âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ G: Ï•(   )x +_G y = Ï•(   )x +_H Ï•(   )y
:(2):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ G: âˆ€Î»âˆˆ R: Ï•(   )Î»âˆ˜ x = Î»âŠ—Ï•(   )x


=== Definition in a Vector Space ===
Let V, W be vector spaces over a field (or, more generally, division ring) K.


A mapping A: V â†’ W is a linear transformation  if and only if :

:âˆ€ v_1, v_2 âˆˆ V, Î»âˆˆ K: A (   )Î» v_1 + v_2 = Î» A (   )v_1 + A (   )v_2


That is, a homomorphism from one vector space to another.


=== Linear Operator on Vector Space ===
A linear operator on a vector space is a linear transformation from a vector space into itself.

=== Linear Operator ===
A linear operator is a linear transformation from a module into itself.


=== Linear Operator on Vector Space ===
A linear operator on a vector space is a linear transformation from a vector space into itself.

title: Definition:Evaluation Linear Transformation/Module Theory
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let G be an R-module.

Let G^* be the algebraic dual of G.

Let G^** be the double dual of G^*.


For each x âˆˆ G, we define the mapping x^âˆ§: G^* â†’ R as:
:âˆ€ t âˆˆ G^*: x^âˆ§(   )t = t (   )x


The mapping J: G â†’ G^** defined as:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ G: J (   )x = x^âˆ§
is called the evaluation linear transformation from G into G^**.


It is usual to denote the mapping t: G^* â†’ R as follows:

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ G, t âˆˆ G^*: âŸ¨ x,   âŸ© t := t (   )x

title: Definition:Complex Transformation
definition:
A complex transformation is a mapping on the complex plane f: â„‚â†’â„‚ which is specifically not a multifunction.


Let z = x + i y be a complex variable.

Let w = u + i v = f (   )z.


Then w can be expressed as:
:u + i v = f (   )x + i y

such that:
:u = u (   )x, y
and:
:v = v (   )x, y
are real functions of two variables.


Thus a point P = ( x, y ) in the complex plane is transformed to a point P' = ( u (   )x, y, v (   )x, y) by f.

Thus P' is the image of P under f.

title: Definition:Group Action/Transformation Group
definition:
Let X be a set.

Let ( G, âˆ˜) be a group whose identity is e.


Let G act on X.

Then G can be referred to as the transformation group of X.

title: Definition:Effective Transformation Group
definition:
Let G be a group whose identity is e.

Let X be a set.

Let Ï•: G Ã— X â†’ X be a group action.


Then G is an effective transformation group for Ï•  if and only if  Ï• is faithful.

title: Definition:Transitive Closure of Relation
definition:
=== Smallest Transitive Superset ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


The transitive closure of â„› is defined as the smallest transitive relation on S which contains â„› as a subset.


The transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^+.

=== Intersection of Transitive Supersets ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


The transitive closure of â„› is defined as the intersection of all transitive relations on S which contain â„›.


The transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^+.

=== Finite Chain ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set or class S.


The transitive closure of â„› is the relation â„›^+ defined as follows:

For x, y âˆˆ S, x â„›^+ y  if and only if  for some n âˆˆâ„•_>0 there exist s_0, s_1, â€¦, s_n âˆˆ S such that s_0 = x, s_n = y, and:

 
 
 
 
 
 


That is:

:âˆ€ k âˆˆâ„•_n: s_k â„› s_k + 1

=== Union of Compositions ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

Let:

:â„›^n := â„›    : n = 1 
â„›^n-1âˆ˜â„›    : n > 1

where âˆ˜ denotes composition of relations.

Finally, let:

:â„›^+ = â‹ƒ_i  = 1^âˆâ„›^i


Then â„›^+ is called the transitive closure of â„›.

title: Definition:Reflexive Transitive Closure
definition:
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


=== Smallest Reflexive Transitive Superset ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

The reflexive transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^*, and is defined as the smallest reflexive and transitive relation on S which contains â„›.

=== Reflexive Closure of Transitive Closure ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

The reflexive transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^*, and is defined as the reflexive closure of the transitive closure of â„›:

:â„›^* = ( â„›^+ )^=

=== Transitive Closure of Reflexive Closure ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

The reflexive transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^*, and is defined as the transitive closure of the reflexive closure of â„›:
:â„›^* = ( â„›^= )^+

title: Definition:Transitive Reduction
definition:
=== Relation Theory ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


A transitive reduction of â„› is denoted â„›^-, and is defined as a minimal relation on S which has the same transitive closure as â„›.

=== Graph Theory ===

The concept of transitive reduction is usually encountered in the field of graph theory where it has considerable importance:

Let G = ( V, E ) be a loop-digraph.

Let G be expressed formally as a relational structure ğ’¢.

A transitive reduction of G is denoted G^-, and is defined as a transitive reduction of the relation ğ’¢.

Hence it is a minimal loop-digraph on V which has the same transitive closure as ğ’¢.

title: Definition:Transitive Group Action
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let S be a set.

Let *: G Ã— S â†’ S be a group action.


The group action is transitive  if and only if  for any x, y âˆˆ S there exists g âˆˆ G such that g * x = y.


That is,  if and only if  for all x âˆˆ S:
:Orb( x ) = S
where Orb( x ) denotes the orbit of x âˆˆ S under *.


=== n-transitive Action ===
Let G be a group.

Let S be a set.

Let *: G Ã— S â†’ S be a group action.


Let n âˆˆâ„•_>0 be a non-zero natural number.


The group action is n-transitive  if and only if  for any two ordered n-tuples ( x_1, â€¦, x_n ) and ( y_1, â€¦, y_n ) of pairwise distinct elements of S, there exists gâˆˆ G such that:
:âˆ€ i âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n } : g * x_i = y_i

title: Definition:Transitive Subgroup
definition:
Let S_n denote the symmetric group on n letters for n âˆˆâ„•.

Let H be a subgroup of S_n.

Let H be such that:
:for every pair of elements i, j âˆˆâ„•_n there exists Ï€âˆˆ H such that Ï€(   )i = j.


Then H is called a transitive subgroup of S_n.

title: Definition:Transitive Class
definition:
Let A denote a class, which can be either a set or a proper class.

Then A is transitive  if and only if  every element of A is also a subclass of A.


That is, A is transitive  if and only if :
:x âˆˆ A  x âŠ† A

or:
:âˆ€ x: âˆ€ y: ( x âˆˆ y  y âˆˆ A  x âˆˆ A )

title: Definition:Transitive Closure of Set
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let x be a set.

Then the transitive closure of x is the smallest transitive superset of x.

The following is not equivalent to the above, but they are almost the same.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let x be a set.

For each natural number n âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 0 let:

:â‹ƒ^n x = â‹ƒâ‹ƒâ‹¯â‹ƒ_n x


Then the transitive closure of x is the union of the sets:
:{ x }, x, â‹ƒ x, â‹ƒ^2 x, â€¦, â‹ƒ^n x, â€¦


More precisely:

Let F be the mapping on the universal class defined by letting:
:F (   )A = â‹ƒ a
for each set a.

Let G be the mapping on the natural numbers defined recursively by letting:

:G (   )0 = { x }
:G (   )n^+ = F (   )G (   )n

for each natural number n.

Then the transitive closure of x is defined as the union of the image of G.

title: Definition:Transitive Closure of Relation
definition:
=== Smallest Transitive Superset ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


The transitive closure of â„› is defined as the smallest transitive relation on S which contains â„› as a subset.


The transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^+.

=== Intersection of Transitive Supersets ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


The transitive closure of â„› is defined as the intersection of all transitive relations on S which contain â„›.


The transitive closure of â„› is denoted â„›^+.

=== Finite Chain ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set or class S.


The transitive closure of â„› is the relation â„›^+ defined as follows:

For x, y âˆˆ S, x â„›^+ y  if and only if  for some n âˆˆâ„•_>0 there exist s_0, s_1, â€¦, s_n âˆˆ S such that s_0 = x, s_n = y, and:

 
 
 
 
 
 


That is:

:âˆ€ k âˆˆâ„•_n: s_k â„› s_k + 1

=== Union of Compositions ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

Let:

:â„›^n := â„›    : n = 1 
â„›^n-1âˆ˜â„›    : n > 1

where âˆ˜ denotes composition of relations.

Finally, let:

:â„›^+ = â‹ƒ_i  = 1^âˆâ„›^i


Then â„›^+ is called the transitive closure of â„›.

title: Definition:Transitive Closure of Set
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let x be a set.

Then the transitive closure of x is the smallest transitive superset of x.

The following is not equivalent to the above, but they are almost the same.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let x be a set.

For each natural number n âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 0 let:

:â‹ƒ^n x = â‹ƒâ‹ƒâ‹¯â‹ƒ_n x


Then the transitive closure of x is the union of the sets:
:{ x }, x, â‹ƒ x, â‹ƒ^2 x, â€¦, â‹ƒ^n x, â€¦


More precisely:

Let F be the mapping on the universal class defined by letting:
:F (   )A = â‹ƒ a
for each set a.

Let G be the mapping on the natural numbers defined recursively by letting:

:G (   )0 = { x }
:G (   )n^+ = F (   )G (   )n

for each natural number n.

Then the transitive closure of x is defined as the union of the image of G.

title: Definition:Transpose of Linear Transformation
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring.

Let G and H be R-modules.

Let G^* and H^* be the algebraic duals of G and H respectively.


Let â„’_R (   )G, H be the set of all linear transformations from G to H.

Let u âˆˆâ„’_R (   )G, H.


The transpose of u is the mapping u^âŠº: H^* â†’ G^* defined as:
:âˆ€ y âˆˆ H^*: u^âŠº(   )y = y âˆ˜ u
where y âˆ˜ u is the composition of y and u.

title: Definition:Transpose of Matrix
definition:
Let ğ€ = [ Î±]_m n be an m Ã— n matrix over a set.


Then the transpose of ğ€ is denoted ğ€^âŠº and is defined as:

:ğ€^âŠº = [ Î²]_n m: âˆ€ i âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]n, j âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]m: Î²_i j = Î±_j i

title: Definition:Transversal (Geometry)
definition:
A transversal of two straight lines lying in the same plane is a straight line which intersects them in two different points.

The transversal is said to cut the two lines that it crosses.

:

In the above diagram, EF is a transversal of the lines AB and CD.


It is also apparent that:
:AB is a transversal of the lines EF and CD
:CD is a transversal of the lines EF and AB
although this is not as obvious.


=== Interior Angle ===
:


An interior angle of a transversal is an angle which is between the two lines cut by that transversal.

In the above figure, the interior angles with respect to the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHJ
:âˆ  CJH
:âˆ  BHJ
:âˆ  DJH

=== Exterior Angle ===
:


An exterior angle of a transversal is an angle which is not between the two lines cut by a transversal.

In the above figure, the exterior angles with respect to the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHE
:âˆ  CJF
:âˆ  BHE
:âˆ  DJF

=== Alternate Angles ===
:


Alternate angles are interior angles of a transversal which are on opposite sides and different lines.

In the above figure, the pairs of alternate angles   the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHJ and âˆ  DJH
:âˆ  CJH and âˆ  BHJ

=== Corresponding Angles ===
:


Corresponding angles are the angles in equivalent positions on the two lines cut by a transversal with respect to that transversal.

In the above figure, the corresponding angles with respect to the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHJ and âˆ  CJF
:âˆ  AHE and âˆ  CJH
:âˆ  BHE and âˆ  DJH
:âˆ  BHJ and âˆ  DJF

title: Definition:Transversal (Group Theory)
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let H be a subgroup of G.

Let S âŠ† G be a subset of G.


=== Left Transversal ===
Let G be a group.

Let H be a subgroup of G.

Let S âŠ† G be a subset of G.


S is a left transversal for H in G  if and only if  every left coset of H contains exactly one element of S.

=== Right Transversal ===
Let G be a group.

Let H be a subgroup of G.

Let S âŠ† G be a subset of G.


S is a right transversal for H in G  if and only if  every right coset of H contains exactly one element of S.

=== Transversal ===

A transversal for H in G is either a left transversal or a right transversal.


 
Clearly if S is a transversal for H it contains [ G :   ]H elements, where [ G :   ]H denotes the index of H in G.

title: Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)
definition:
=== Definition 1===
A tree is a simple connected graph with no circuits.


:

=== Definition 2===
A tree is a simple connected graph with no cycles.

=== Node ===
The vertices of a tree are called its nodes.

=== Leaf Node ===
Let v be a node of a tree T.

Then v is a leaf node of a T  if and only if  v is of degree 1.


If T is a rooted tree, this is equivalent to saying that v has no child nodes.

title: Definition:Rooted Tree
definition:
A rooted tree is a tree with a countable number of nodes, in which a particular node is distinguished from the others and called the root node:

:

=== Root Node ===
Let T be a rooted tree.

The root node of T is the node of T which is distinguished from the others by being the ancestor node of every node of T.

=== Parent ===
Let T be a rooted tree whose root is r_T.

Let t be a node of T.

From Path in Tree is Unique, there is only one path from t to r_T.

Let Ï€: T âˆ–{ r_T }â†’ T be the mapping defined by:

:Ï€(   )t := the node adjacent to t on the path to r_T


Then Ï€(   )t is known as the parent node of t.

The mapping Ï€ is called the parent mapping.

=== Ancestor ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Let t be a node of T.


An ancestor node of t is a node in the path from t to r_T.


=== Proper Ancestor ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Let t be a node of T.


A proper ancestor node of t is an ancestor node of t that is not t itself.

=== Child Node ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Let t be a node of T.

The child nodes of t are the elements of the set:
:{ s âˆˆ T: Ï€(   )s = t }
where Ï€(   )s denotes the parent mapping of s.

That is, the children of t are all the nodes of T of which t is the parent.


=== Grandchild Node ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Let t be a node of T.


A child of a child node of a node t can be referred to as a grandchild node of t.

In terms of the parent mapping Ï€ of T, a grandchild node of t is a node s such that:

:Ï€(   )Ï€(   )s = t


Category:Definitions/Descendant Nodes

=== Descendant ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Let t be a node of T.


A descendant node s of a t is a node such that t is in the path from s to r_T.

That is, the descendant nodes of t are all the nodes of T of which t is an ancestor node.


=== Proper Descendant ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Let t be a node of T.


A proper descendant node of t is a descendant of t which is not t itself.


Category:Definitions/Descendant Nodes

=== Sibling ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root r_T.

Two children of the same node of T are called siblings.

That is, siblings are nodes which both have the same parent.


Category:Definitions/Rooted Trees

=== Leaf Node ===
Let v be a node of a tree T.

Then v is a leaf node of a T  if and only if  v is of degree 1.


If T is a rooted tree, this is equivalent to saying that v has no child nodes.

=== Branch ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root node r_T.

A subset Î“ of T is a branch  if and only if  all the following conditions hold:
:(1): The root node r_T belongs to Î“
:(2): The parent of each node in Î“âˆ–{ r_T } is in Î“
:(3): Each node in Î“ either:
::(a): is a leaf node of T
:or:
::(b): has exactly one child node in Î“.


Informally, a branch of a rooted tree is the path from the root to a leaf.


=== Finite ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root node r_T.

Let Î“ be a branch of T.


Then Î“ is finite  if and only if  it has exactly one leaf node.

=== Infinite ===
Let T be a rooted tree with root node r_T.

Let Î“ be a branch of T.


Then Î“ is infinite  if and only if  it has no leaf node at the end.

title: Definition:Tree (Set Theory)
definition:
Let ( T, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let ( T, â‰¼) be such that for every t âˆˆ T, the lower closure of t:
:t^â‰¼ := { s âˆˆ T: s â‰¼ t } 

is well-ordered by â‰¼.


Then ( T, â‰¼) is a tree.


=== Branch ===
Let ( T, â‰¼) be a tree.

A branch of ( T, â‰¼) is a maximal chain in ( T, â‰¼).


Category:Definitions/Set Theory

=== Subtree ===
Let ( T, â‰¼) be a tree.

A subtree of ( T, â‰¼) is an ordered subset ( S, â‰¼) with the property that:
:for every âˆ€ s âˆˆ S: âˆ€ t âˆˆ T: t â‰¼ s  t âˆˆ S

That is, such that ( S, â‰¼) is a lower closure of ( T, â‰¼).

definition:

title: Definition:Trivial Partition
definition:
Let S be a set such that S âˆ….

There are two partitions on S which are referred to as the trivial partitions on S:


=== Singleton Partition ===
The singleton partition on S is defined as:
:ğ’« = { S }

That is, it is a partition with only one component.


Category:Definitions/Set Partitions

=== Partition of Singletons ===
Let S be a set such that S âˆ….


The partition of singletons on S is defined as:
:ğ’« = {{ x }: x âˆˆ S }

That is, it is a partition such that every component is a singleton.


Category:Definitions/Set Partitions

title: Definition:Trivial Quotient
definition:
Let Î”_S be the diagonal relation on a set S.

As Î”_S is an equivalence, we can form the quotient mapping:
:q_Î”_S: S â†’ S / Î”_S.


This quotient mapping is called the trivial quotient of S.

title: Definition:Trivial Relation
definition:
The trivial relation is the relation â„›âŠ† S Ã— T in S to T such that every element of S relates to every element in T:

:â„›: S Ã— T: âˆ€( s, t ) âˆˆ S Ã— T: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›


That is:
:â„› = S Ã— T
the relation which equals the product of the sets on which it is defined.

title: Definition:Trivial Group
definition: A trivial group is a group with only one element e.

title: Definition:Trivial Ring
definition:
A ring ( R, +, âˆ˜) is a trivial ring  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ R: x âˆ˜ y = 0_R

title: Definition:Character (Number Theory)
definition:
Let ( G, + ) be a finite abelian group.

Let ( â„‚_ 0, Ã—) be the multiplicative group of complex numbers.


A character of G is a group homomorphism:

:Ï‡: G â†’â„‚_ 0

title: Definition:Truncation (Geometry)
definition:
A truncation in the context of geometry is the process of cutting off part of a solid figure ğ’® by one or more planes that do not intersect within ğ’®.

Such a solid figure is said to be truncated.

title: Definition:Truncation of Number
definition: Truncation is the process of dropping some of the least significant digits of the decimal expansion of a number.

title: Definition:Truncation Error
definition:
A truncation error is an error associated with limitations in the construction of approximations.

This may arise by:
:the use of an approximation rule
:terminating an iterative method before it has converged
:approximating a derivative by a difference
:taking a finite number of terms of a power series expansion, for example a Taylor series
:and so on.

It can also arise through truncation of a number.

title: Definition:Union of Relations
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Let â„›_1 and â„›_2 be relations on S Ã— T.


The union of â„›_1 and â„›_2 is the relation ğ’¬ defined by:

:ğ’¬ := â„›_1 âˆªâ„›_2

where âˆª denotes set union.


Explicitly, for s âˆˆ S and t âˆˆ T, we have:

:s ğ’¬ t  if and only if  s â„›_1 t or s â„›_2 t


=== General Definition ===
Let S and T be sets.

Let â„› be a collection of relations on S Ã— T.


The union of â„› is the relation â„› defined by:

:â„› = â‹ƒâ„›

where â‹ƒ denotes set union.

:s â„› t  if and only if  for some ğ’¬âˆˆâ„›, s ğ’¬ t

definition:
Let:

=== Finite Set of Mappings ===
Let S = { f_1, f_2, â€¦, f_n } denote a finite set of mappings.


The union mapping f of S is defined when:

:âˆ€ i, j âˆˆ{ 1, 2, â€¦, n }: f_i and f_j are combinable

and is defined as:

=== Family of Mappings ===
Let I be an indexing set.

title: Definition:Union Relation
definition:
Let:

:(1):   â„›_1 âŠ† S_1 Ã— T_1 be a relation on S_1 Ã— T_1

:(2):   â„›_2 âŠ† S_2 Ã— T_2 be a relation on S_2 Ã— T_2

title: Definition:Set Union/Family of Sets
definition:
Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of sets indexed by I.


Then the union of âŸ¨ S_i âŸ© is defined as:

:â‹ƒ_i âˆˆ I S_i := { x: âˆƒ i âˆˆ I: x âˆˆ S_i }


=== In the context of the Universal Set ===

In treatments of set theory in which the concept of the universal set is recognised, this can be expressed as follows.

Let ğ•Œ be a universal set.

Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of subsets of ğ•Œ.


Then the union of âŸ¨ S_i âŸ© is defined and denoted as:

:â‹ƒ_i âˆˆ I S_i := { x âˆˆğ•Œ: âˆƒ i âˆˆ I: x âˆˆ S_i }

=== Subsets of General Set ===
This definition is the same when the universal set ğ•Œ is replaced by any set X, which may or may not be a universal set:

Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of subsets of a set X.


Then the union of âŸ¨ S_i âŸ© is defined as:

:â‹ƒ_i âˆˆ I S_i := { x âˆˆ X: âˆƒ i âˆˆ I: x âˆˆ S_i }
where i is a bound variable.

title: Definition:Union of Adjacent Open Intervals
definition:
Let ( â„, Ï„_d ) be the real number line â„ under the usual (Euclidean) topology Ï„_d.

Then ( A, Ï„_d ) is the union of adjacent open intervals.

title: Definition:Unity (Abstract Algebra)/Ring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

If the semigroup ( R, âˆ˜) has an identity, this identity is referred to as the unity of the ring ( R, +, âˆ˜).

It is (usually) denoted 1_R, where the subscript denotes the particular ring to which 1_R belongs (or often 1 if there is no danger of ambiguity).


The ring R itself is then referred to as a ring with unity.

title: Definition:Multiplicative Identity
definition:
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field.

The identity element of the multiplicative group ( F^*, Ã—) of F is called the multiplicative identity of F.

It is often denoted e_F or 1_F, or, if there is no danger of ambiguity, e or 1.

title: Definition:Universe of Discourse
definition:
The universe of discourse is the term used to mean everything we are talking about.


When introducing the symbols:
:âˆ€ (the universal quantifier)
or:
:âˆƒ (the existential quantifier)
it is understood that the objects referred to are those in the specified universe of discourse.

It is usual to define that universe.

title: Definition:Grothendieck Universe
definition:
A Grothendieck universe is a set (not a class) which has the properties expected of the universal set ğ•Œ of sets in the sense of the Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms with the following properties:

title: Definition:Population
definition:
The population of a statistical study is everything in the universe of discourse that is relevant to the study.

It includes all objects, measures, and observations under discussion.


=== Finite Population ===
A finite population is a population which is finite.

=== Infinite Population ===
An infinite population is a population which is infinite.

title: Definition:Physical Universe
definition:
The physical universe, or usually just universe, is commonly defined as, and understood to be,  .


=== Real-World ===
Used to describe a phenomenon or object that has a genuine existence in the physical universe.

title: Definition:Upper Bound of Set/Real Numbers
definition:
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

Let T be a subset of â„.


An upper bound for T (in â„) is an element M âˆˆâ„ such that:
:âˆ€ t âˆˆ T: t â‰¤ M

That is, M is greater than or equal to every element of T.


=== Upper Bound of Number ===
When considering the upper bound of a set of numbers, it is commonplace to ignore the set and instead refer just to the number itself.

Thus the construction:

:The set of numbers which fulfil the propositional function P (   )n is bounded above with the upper bound N

would be reported as:

:The number n such that P (   )n has the upper bound N.


This construct obscures the details of what is actually being stated. Its use on   is considered an abuse of notation and so discouraged.


This also applies in the case where it is the upper bound of a mapping which is under discussion.


Category:Definitions/Numbers
Category:Definitions/Boundedness

title: Definition:Upper Bound of Mapping/Real-Valued
definition:
Let f: S â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


Let f be bounded above in â„ by H âˆˆâ„.


Then H is an upper bound of f.


=== Upper Bound of Number ===
When considering the upper bound of a set of numbers, it is commonplace to ignore the set and instead refer just to the number itself.

definition:

Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be bounded above by H âˆˆâ„.


Then H is an upper bound of âŸ¨ x_n âŸ©.

title: Definition:Vacuous Truth
definition:
Let P  Q be a conditional statement.

Suppose that P is false.

Then the statement P  Q is a vacuous truth, or is vacuously true.


It is frequently encountered in the form:
:âˆ€ x: P (   )x  Q (   )x
when the propositional function P (   )x is false for all x.

Such a statement is also a vacuous truth.


For example, the statement:
:All cats who are expert chess-players are also fluent in ancient Sanskrit
is (vacuously) true, because (as far as the author knows) there are no cats who are expert chess-players.

title: Definition:Empty Set
definition:
The empty set is a set which has no elements.

That is, x âˆˆâˆ… is false, whatever x is.


It is usually denoted by some variant of a zero with a line through it, for example âˆ… or âˆ…, and can always be represented as {}.

title: Definition:Summation/Vacuous Summation
definition:
Take the summation:
:âˆ‘_Î¦(   )j a_j
where Î¦(   )j is a propositional function of j.

Suppose that there are no values of j for which Î¦(   )j is true.

Then âˆ‘_Î¦(   )j a_j is defined as being 0.

This summation is called a vacuous summation.


This is because:
:âˆ€ a: a + 0 = a
where a is a number.

Hence for all j for which Î¦(   )j is false, the sum is unaffected.


This is most frequently seen in the form:
:âˆ‘_j  = m^n a_j = 0
where m > n.

In this case, j can not at the same time be both greater than or equal to m and less than or equal to n.


Some sources consider such a treatment as abuse of notation.

title: Definition:Continued Product/Vacuous Product
definition:
Take the composite expressed as a continued product:
:âˆ_R (   )j a_j
where R (   )j is a propositional function of j.

Suppose that there are no values of j for which R (   )j is true.

Then âˆ_R (   )j a_j is defined to be 1.

Beware: not zero.

This composite is called a vacuous product.


This is because:
:âˆ€ a: a Ã— 1 = a
where a is a number.

Hence for all j for which R (   )j is false, the value of the product is unaffected.


This is most frequently seen in the form:
:âˆ_j  = m^n a_j = 1
where m > n.

In this case, j can not at the same time be both greater than or equal to m and less than or equal to n.

title: Definition:Valid Argument
definition:
A valid argument is a logical argument in which the premises provide conclusive reasons for the conclusion.


When an argument is valid, we may say one of the following:
* The conclusion follows from the premises;
* The premises entail the conclusion;
* The conclusion is true on the strength of the premises;
* The conclusion is drawn from the premises;
* The conclusion is deduced from the premises;
* The conclusion is derived from the premises.


=== Proof ===

If all the premises of a valid argument are true, then the conclusion must also therefore be true.

It is not possible for the premises of a valid argument to be true, but for the conclusion to be false.

A proof is a valid argument whose premises are all true.


Hence a valid argument that has one or more false premises is not a proof.


Suppose P is a proposition whose truth or falsehood is to be determined.

Constructing a valid argument upon a set of premises, all of which have previously been established as being true, is called proving P.


=== Formal Proof ===

Let ğ’« be a proof system for a formal language â„’.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for a formal language â„’.


Let Ï• be a WFF of â„’.

A formal proof of Ï• in ğ’« is a collection of axioms and rules of inference of ğ’« that leads to the conclusion that Ï• is a theorem of ğ’«.


The term formal proof is also used to refer to specific presentations of such collections.

For example, the term applies to tableau proofs in natural deduction.

title: Definition:Formal Semantics/Valid
definition:
Let â„’ be a formal language.

Part of specifying a formal semantics â„³ for â„’ is to define a notion of validity.


Concretely, a precise meaning needs to be assigned to the phrase:

:"The â„’-WFF Ï• is valid in the â„³-structure â„³."

It can be expressed symbolically as:

:â„³_â„³Ï•

title: Definition:Vanishing Ideal of Set of Prime Ideals
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let V âŠ†Spec( A ) be a set of prime ideals of A.


Its vanishing ideal is its intersection, the set of elements of A that are in each ğ”­âˆˆ V:
:I (   )V = â‹‚ V

title: Definition:Vanishing Ideal of Subset of Affine Space
definition:
Let k be a field.

Let n â‰¥ 0 be a natural number.

Let k [ X_1, â€¦, X_n ] be the polynomial ring in n variables over k.

Let S âŠ†ğ”¸^n_k be a subset of the standard affine space over k.


Its vanishing ideal is the ideal:
:I (   )S = { f âˆˆ k [ X_1, â€¦, X_n ] : âˆ€ x âˆˆ S : f (   )x = 0 }

title: Definition:Graph (Graph Theory)/Vertex
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

The vertices (singular: vertex) are the elements of V.

Informally, the vertices are the points that are connected by the edges.


In the above, the vertices are the points A, B, C, D, E, F, G which are marked as dots.

title: Definition:Polygon/Vertex
definition:
:

A corner of a polygon is known as a vertex.

Thus, in the polygon above, the vertices are A, B, C, D and E.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Vertex
definition: The vertices of a polyhedron are the vertices of the polygons which constitute its faces.

title: Definition:Angle/Vertex
definition: The point at which the arms of an angle meet is known as the vertex of that angle.

title: Definition:Solid Angle/Vertex
definition: The common point through which pass the copunctal half-lines describing a solid angle is known as the vertex of that solid angle.

title: Definition:Cone (Geometry)/Apex
definition:
Consider a cone consisting of the set of all straight lines joining the boundary of a plane figure PQR to a point A not in the same plane of PQR:


:


In the above diagram, the point A is known as the apex of the cone.

title: Definition:Ellipse/Vertex
definition:
:


Let K be an ellipse.

A vertex of K is either of the two endpoints of the major axis of K.


In the above diagram, V_1 and V_2 are the vertices of K.

title: Definition:Parabola/Vertex
definition:
:


Let P be a parabola.

The vertex of P is the point where the axis intersects P.


In the above diagram, V is the vertex of P.

title: Definition:Periodic Wave/Wavelength
definition:
Let Ï• be a periodic wave expressed as:
:âˆ€ x, t âˆˆâ„: Ï•(   )x, t = f (   )x - c t


The wavelength Î» of Ï• is the period of the wave profile of Ï•.


=== Symbol ===

title: Definition:Wavelength (Physics)
definition:
The wavelength of a wave is the distance travelled in the direction of propagation between two points at the same phase of disturbance in consecutive cycles.

That is, it is the distance over which the wave's shape repeats.


=== Symbol ===

title: Definition:Conditional/Language of Conditional/Weak
definition: In a conditional p  q, the statement q is weaker than p.

title: Definition:Initial Topology
definition:
Let X be a set.

Let I be an indexing set.


Let âŸ¨( Y_i, Ï„_i )  âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of topological spaces indexed by I.

Let âŸ¨ f_i: X â†’ Y_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of mappings indexed by I.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let X be a set.

Let I be an indexing set.


Let âŸ¨( Y_i, Ï„_i )  âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of topological spaces indexed by I.

Let âŸ¨ f_i: X â†’ Y_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of mappings indexed by I.


Let:
:ğ’® = { f_i^-1[ U ]: i âˆˆ I, U âˆˆÏ„_i }
where f_i^-1[ U ] denotes the preimage of U under f_i.

The topology Ï„ on X generated by ğ’® is called the initial topology on X with respect to âŸ¨ f_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let X be a set.

Let I be an indexing set.


Let âŸ¨( Y_i, Ï„_i )  âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of topological spaces indexed by I.

Let âŸ¨ f_i: X â†’ Y_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of mappings indexed by I.


Let Ï„ be the coarsest topology on X such that each f_i: X â†’ Y_i is ( Ï„, Ï„_i )-continuous.

Then Ï„ is known as the initial topology on X with respect to âŸ¨ f_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I.

title: Definition:Weakly Locally Compact Space
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


Then T is weakly locally compact  if and only if  every point of S has a compact neighborhood.

title: Definition:Weight (Physics)
definition:
The weight of a body is the magnitude of the force exerted on it by the influence of a gravitational field.


The context is that the gravitational field in question is usually that of the Earth.


=== Symbol ===


=== Weigh ===
To weigh a body is to determine its weight, and thence its mass.

Similarly we can say that:
:body B weighs x
to mean:
:the weight of the body B is x
and both mean the same thing.

=== Dimension of Weight ===
The dimension of weight is ğ–¬ ğ–« ğ–³^-2: mass times acceleration, that is, a force.

=== Units of Weight ===
The SI unit of weight is N (newton).

The CGS unit of weight is dyn (dyne).

title: Definition:Network/Weight
definition:
Let N = ( V, E, w ) be a network with weight function w: E â†’â„.


The values of the elements of E under w are known as the weights of the edges of N.


The weights of a network N can be depicted by writing the appropriate numbers next to the edges of the underlying graph of N.


=== Weight of Walk ===
Let N = ( V, E, w ) be a network with weight function w: E â†’â„.


Let PQ = v_1 e_1 v_2 e_2 â€¦ e_n - 1 V_n be a walk in N.

The weight of PQ is defined as the sum of the weights of the edges that constitute PQ:

:w (   )PQ := âˆ‘_k  = 1^n - 1 w (   )e_k


This definition can also be applied to paths, trails, circuits and  cycles.

title: Definition:Network/Weight Function
definition:
Let N = ( V, E, w ) be a network.

The mapping w: E â†’â„ is known as the weight function of N.

title: Definition:Weight Function
definition:
A weight function on a set S is a mapping from S to the real numbers:
:w: S â†’â„


It is common for the requirements of a specific application under discussion for the codomain of w to be restricted to the positive reals:
:w: S â†’â„_â‰¥ 0


The thing that determines whether a given mapping is a weight function depends more on how it is used.

title: Definition:Weight of Linear Codeword
definition:
Let C be a codeword of a linear code.

The weight of C is the number of non-zero terms of C.

title: Definition:Weights
definition:
A set of weights consists of a number of solid pieces of matter whose mass is measured and known.

They are used as reference masses for the purpose of determining to a certain limit of accuracy the weight of a body whose mass is unknown.

title: Definition:Zero (Ordinal)
definition: The zero ordinal, denoted 0, is the empty set âˆ….

title: Definition:Zero (Cardinal)
definition:
The cardinal associated with the empty set âˆ… is called zero, and is denoted 0.


More informally, this means that zero is defined as being the number of elements in the empty set.

title: Definition:Zero (Number)/Complex
definition:
Let â„‚ denote the set of complex numbers.

The zero of â„‚ is the complex number:
:0 + 0 i

title: Definition:Zero Digit
definition:
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a number.

Let b âˆˆâ„¤ such that b > 1 be a number base in which x is represented.

By the Basis Representation Theorem, x can be expressed uniquely in the form:

:x = âˆ‘_j âˆˆâ„¤^m r_j b^j


Any instance of r_j being equal to 0 is known as a zero (digit) of n.

title: Definition:Zero (Number)/Naturally Ordered Semigroup
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) be a naturally ordered semigroup.

Then from  , ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) has a smallest element.


This smallest element of ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) is called zero and has the symbol 0.

That is:
:âˆ€ n âˆˆ S: 0 â‰¼ n

title: Definition:Zero Element
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


=== Left Zero ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element z_L âˆˆ S is called a left zero element (or just left zero)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: z_L âˆ˜ x = z_L

=== Right Zero ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element z_R âˆˆ S is called a right zero element (or just right zero)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ z_R = z_R

=== Zero ===

An element z âˆˆ S is called a two-sided zero element (or simply zero element or zero)  if and only if  it is both a left zero and a right zero:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ z = z = z âˆ˜ x
